PETITION.TITLE: Fraser Island and Great Sandy Region: World Heritage Listing
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled-
The petition of certain citizens of Australia shows: That Fraser Island and the other parts of the Great Sandy Region qualify for World Heritage Listing because of outstanding Values:
Geological-The World's greatest sand mass and the oldest age sequence of Giant Coastal dunes; perched dune lakes; barrage dune lakes unknown elsewhere.

Biological-Coastal heathlands, freshwater swamps, mangroves, the World's only rainforest growing on high coastal dunes, ancient paperbarks; 750 species of flowering plants and ferns; wallum; wide diversity of marine, terrestrial and avian fauna, some of which is rare or endemic.

Aesthetic-40 Kilometres of coloured sand cliff faces, volcanic outcrops, over 40 perched dune lakes, the majestic Noosa river, wildflower-strewn heathlands, vast surfaces of loose mobile sand, rainforests, crystal-clear fresh-water streams.

Cultural-evidence of large populations of Aborigines in the region-middens, bora rings, canoe trees, implements and other artifacts; historical artifacts from the last 150 years-2 operating lighthouses, shipwrecks.

Your petitioners therefore pray that the Commonwealth Government take action to place Fraser Island and the other parts of the Great Sandy Region on the World Heritage List to ensure proper recognition of the region's international importance and to ensure appropriate management to preserve its unique qualities.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.
I table an erratum page to the explanatory memorandum and seek leave to have the second reading speech incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The speech read as follows-

This Bill contains amendments to the Veterans' Entitlements Act 1986, the Veterans' Entitlements (Transitional Provisions and Consequential Amendments) Act 1986 and the Seamen's War Pensions and Allowances Act 1940. The amendments contained in this Bill include measures to address the reports of the Veterans' Entitlements Act Monitoring Committee and to implement decisions provided for in the 1988/89 Budget. The Bill also contains a number of minor non-Budget measures.

This Bill is primarily aimed at giving effect to those major recommendations of the Veterans' Entitlements Act Monitoring Committee accepted by the Government and requiring legislative amendments to implement.

The Monitoring Committee was set up on 18 May 1987 to determine the extent to which the Veterans' Entitlements Act 1986 met the stated intentions of the Government at the time of its passage through Parliament. The Report of the Monitoring Committee was presented to the Government on 23 May 1988.
Details of the Government's initial response to the Report were set out in a response booklet sent to all Members and Senators in September.

The Government has accepted 28 of the Monitoring Committee's recommendations in full, four have been accepted in a modified form and another 20 are receiving further consideration. I will advise of the outcome in due course.
Nine of the 32 accepted recommendations are considered to require immediate legislative amendment and are presented in this Bill.

The first initiative arises from a Committee recommendation which the Government accepted in full. The Bill provides for the introduction of an Extreme Disablement Adjustment (EDA) to assist those frail, aged veterans who are not adequately compensated by the present disability pension structure. These are veterans who are receiving the 100% general rate disability pension, are severely incapacitated by their war or defence-caused disabilities, have passed the normal retirement age and are not eligible for the intermediate or special rate of pension.

The EDA will be an addition to the maximum general rate pension received by the veteran and will be equal to 50% of that rate. It will mean an extra $42.15 a week for eligible veterans at current rates.

A major focus of the Monitoring Committee's Report was the eligibility criteria for intermediate and special rate pensions. The criteria for these higher rates of disability pension were changed by the Government in 1985 when it became clear that the outmoded terminology in the old Repatriation Act was enabling these pensions to be paid to veterans who had completed a full working life, often retiring on good superannuation payments.

Nevertheless, the Committee was critical of these criteria, arguing that the requirement for war-caused disabilities to be the sole cause of a veteran's inability to work was too harsh. In arguing this way, the Committee was perhaps overlooking the original intention of the intermediate and special rate pensions. This was to provide a higher level of pension to compensate those severely disabled veterans who could not work to support their families on their return from service. These pensions were never intended to be retirement pensions. That is why the Government took the steps it did in 1985 and why the changes to the eligibility criteria for these pensions were carried through to the Veterans' Entitlements Act 1986. The Government does not agree with many of the views expressed by the Committee about those changes and in particular with the Committee's assessment of the intention behind the changes.
The Government could not, therefore, agree to recommendations made by the Committee for major changes to the eligibility criteria.
However, the Government has not rejected the Committee's recommendations on the intermediate and special rate provisions outright.

The Bill proposes major changes to the first of the eligibility criteria for such pensions and to procedural aspects of the scheme of the Act for assessing rates of pension. These changes will be of significant benefit to veterans.

Currently, the first of the criteria for eligibility for an intermediate or special rate disability pension is that the veteran be receiving or be eligible to receive a disability pension at 100% of the general rate. The Monitoring Committee had recommended abolition of this requirement altogether. This was not acceptable to the Government as the requirement for a high degree of incapacity has been an intrinsic part of the intermediate and special rate pensions since their introduction.

However, the Government recognises the Committee's argument that a veteran can be unemployed and unemployable due to war or defence-caused incapacity when the incapacity is as low as that attracting a disability pension at 70% of the General Rate. The Bill will therefore provide for a reduction in the required degree of incapacity from 100% to 70%.
The Committee also criticised the `application day' provisions which were inserted in the legislation in 1987. The Government does not agree with many of these criticisms.

Under the provisions of the Veterans' Entitlements Act, as interpreted by the Federal Court, the day on which a veteran's eligibility for the special rate pension is to be determined has always been the day of his or her application. However a decision of that Court (McGuire) would have permitted decision makers to examine the right of a veteran to continue to receive pension at the special rate even though the eligibility criteria had been satisfied on the earlier application day.

The Government acted quickly by introducing amendments to overcome the effect of that decision. The effect of the 1987 amendments were twofold. The first was to confirm the application day as the relevant day on which to examine a claim. This prevented factors occurring after the application date, such as deterioration in non-war-caused disabilities or increasing age, from being taken into account as reasons why the veteran would have not been working at that later point in time. Such factors would have had a disentitling effect on the eligibility of any veteran for the higher rates of pension. The second was to ensure that, subject to certain exceptions, once granted on the basis of eligibility at the application day, a pension could not be taken away on a subsequent review. That is, the special rate pension was preserved for life.

A veteran who was not eligible for intermediate or special rate pension on the application day was precluded from being granted a pension prior to the 1987 amendments and continued to be so precluded after those amendments. Where a veteran became eligible for a higher rate of pension after the application day, the Act required the veteran to lodge a fresh application for increase in pension. Many veterans for a variety of reasons failed to lodge a fresh application.

The failure to follow this procedure has had an adverse effect in some cases and has meant the issue of a fixed `application day' assessment has continued to be a contentious one. Even recent decisions of the Federal Court indicate a misunderstanding of the scheme of the Act and the intention behind the application day provisions. Due to its contentious nature, I specifically requested that this issue be considered by the Monitoring Committee.

Having regard to the confusion and misunderstanding and the views of the Monitoring Committee, the Government has decided that the application day provisions will be amended. The new provisions would enable a veteran to qualify where he or she meets all the eligibility criteria at a date between the date of lodgment of the claim or application and the date of the decision of the Commission or any review body. While this will not have the effect of altering the existing eligibility criteria under the Act, it will mean that it will no longer be necessary to lodge a further claim or application for increase between the date of application and the date of determination of the claim when circumstances change during that period.

The Committee cited the example of a veteran who is employed at the time when his or her claim is lodged, who expects to and who subsequently does retire due to war-caused disabilities before the claim is determined. This veteran would not be required under the new scheme to lodge a fresh application upon retirement. Such a person will be entitled to special rate pension for life, provided of course that all the eligibility criteria continue to be satisfied in all respects at the date of his or her retirement.

These amendments will allow decision makers to take into account significant variations in the degree of incapacity a veteran may suffer from his war-caused disabilities during the assessment period. At present, review bodies see themselves as restricted to looking at the veterans' situation at the time of the initial decision.
I believe that these amendments will allow a commonsense approach to be taken in the consideration of pension assessment applications and will have a significant beneficial impact.
This Bill also makes a number of minor amendments arising out of recommendations made by the Monitoring Committee. These include:

clarification that the determination of the required degree of incapacity of at least 70% need not be made by a previous decision maker before the Commission, VRB or AAT proceed to consider eligibility for the intermediate or special rate of pension;

provision to ensure that veterans receiving pension at 100% of the general rate for tuberculosis are deemed to meet the required degree of incapacity for intermediate and special rate pension purposes; and

provision to ensure that matters which were commenced prior to the commencement of the Veterans' Entitlements legislation are, for the purposes of the application of that legislation, treated as if the initiating action was a ``claim''.
Through this legislation and administrative measures, the Government has acted quickly to implement as many of the Monitoring Committee's recommendations as possible.

This Bill does not just deal with Monitoring Committee issues. This Bill will also provide for increases in the rates of specific disability allowance, clothing allowance, attendant allowance and recreation transport allowance.
Further minor amendments include:
clarification that a war widow's pension may only be paid to a remarried widow where she remarried after 28 May 1984;
a change to the definition of ``severely handicapped veteran'' for carer's service pension purposes to bring it into line with the equivalent definition in the Social Security Act;
a change to ensure that overpayments arising under the Social Security Act and recoverable under the Veterans' Entitlements Act are subject to Social Security rights of review.
Financial Impact

The introduction of the Extreme Disablement Adjustment, the changes to the intermediate and special rate pension criteria and the application day/up-to-date assessment changes will cost approximately $3.15 million in 1988/89 and $8.85 million in the full year 1989/90.
The increases to minor benefits will cost approximately $168,000 in 1988/89 and $335,000 in the full year 1989/90.
The other amendments are revenue neutral.
I commend this Bill to the Senate.

DEBATE.TITLE: TAXATION LAWS AMENDMENT (TAX FILE NUMBERS) BILL 1988PRIVACY BILL 1988

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 8 November, on motion by Senator Tate:

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Stone Sen J.O.

TALKER.NAME: Senator STONE
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —We are debating the Taxation Laws Amendment (Tax File Numbers) Bill 1988 and the Privacy Bill 1988. I want first to say something about the tax file number proposal. As honourable senators are aware, that proposal has had a long gestation period. In 1986 the Senate debated a much wider proposal which the Government chose to call the Australia Card but which most members of the Australian community came to describe, after some time, as the ID card. Without dwelling upon the history of that proposal, it is a matter of record that it generated the most enormous public protest and was, incidentally, the trigger for the double dissolution which was granted to the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) by the Governor-General last year and which led to the Federal election of 11 July 1987.

SPEECH.PARA: It was in the course of examining the earlier Australia Card legislation that the Senate Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs, while expressing the gravest doubts about the Australia Card proposal, went on to say that in any case a much better alternative, a less intrusive and threatening alternative, would appear to be available in the form of what was then described as a high integrity tax file number. The Committee, of which I was not then a member, because I was not then in this place, so reported to the Senate and indicated that if appropriate proposals for a high integrity tax file number were to be brought forward by the Government, the members of the Committee from both sides of the chamber, at least, were unanimously favourably disposed towards such an alternative. It was some time after that, in fact this year, that the Treasurer (Mr Keating), in his May economic statement, actually proposed the introduction of the enhanced tax file number.

As a result of the earlier debates in this place in October 1987, at the time when the Australia Card legislation was withdrawn, the newly reconstituted Senate Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs-you know, this, Madam Acting Deputy President, as we both have the honour to be members of it-was given on 8 October 1987 an extensive reference which arose out of the defeat of that Australia Card proposal. That reference ran to, I think, some 15 separate terms. I think it would be fair to summarise those terms by saying that, whilst they had nothing to do with the tax file number as such, because that particular proposal at that time was no more than a suggestion floating in the air, they had a certain relevance to the proposal as it finally emerged, because those terms of reference were very much concerned with the whole question of privacy in our society, and particularly privacy in so far as it concerns the amassing of large amounts of data of individuals by government databanks.

Following the Treasurer's announcement in the May economic statement that the Government proposed to introduce an enhanced tax file number, the Senate gave its Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs an additional two terms of reference which did indeed, on that occasion, relate specifically to the tax file number proposal. Those terms of reference were given to the Committee on 1 June this year, and it may be worth my very quickly quoting them. The first was to inquire into:

(a) the taxation file numbering scheme announced by the Treasurer in the May Economic Statement and, in particular, whether the scheme is likely to improve the efficiency of the taxation system and to eliminate fraud and abuses in the taxation and social security systems; and
(b) the possibility of that scheme developing into a de facto national identification card system with unacceptable impositions being made upon privacy and civil liberties.

As you are aware, Madam Acting Deputy President, the Senate Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs began holding a series of public hearings on this matter on 11 July in Melbourne, and concluded those public hearings in Canberra on 26 September this year, having meanwhile visited a number of other capitals and, of course, held other non-public hearings. As honourable senators are aware, the Committee presented its report to the Senate recently, and I hope to come back to that towards the conclusion of my remarks.

Meanwhile, a number of other things had been happening with the tax file number. In particular, on 22 June this year the shadow Treasurer, the honourable member for Kooyong (Mr Peacock), the then shadow Minister for Health, the honourable member for O'Connor (Mr Tuckey), and I met with the Commissioner of Taxation and his relevant Deputy Commissioner, Mr Carmody, here in Canberra for discussion of the proposal of the Treasurer. As a result, the Opposition issued a public statement which, while in no way accepting the tax file number proposal more generally, stated quite specifically that there were two aspects of the proposal as unveiled by the Treasurer in the May statement which the Opposition would not accept under any circumstances.

Specifically, the Treasurer's initial proposal was that citizens who were unwilling to quote their tax file numbers when opening or seeking to operate their existing bank accounts would have the penalty applied to them of having those bank accounts frozen. We made it clear that such a draconian measure by the Government-in passing one can only express one's astonishment that such a measure should ever have been contemplated-was totally unacceptable to the Opposition. Similarly, we also made it clear that the Treasurer's original proposal that people seeking to buy or sell shares or other securities would also be required, when placing orders for these purposes, to quote their tax file number to their stockbroker or whatever other agent was involved was totally unacceptable to the Opposition.

I mention those two developments not merely because they form a necessary part of the recitation of the long drawn out history of the proposal we are discussing today but also because those reactions were to two specific and particularly offensive provisions of the Bill. In my own case, at any rate, they were also symptomatic of a more general reaction to the tax file number proposal. Having looked initially at the proposal, so far as the use of the tax file number was directed to the requirement for employees to quote the number when seeking employment or for that matter when persons were seeking an unemployment or equivalent form of benefit, which as far as the tax law is concerned is actually treated as wage and salary income, I had little real objection to the proposal in that narrow and confined form. I emphasise those last words `narrow and confined'.

As honourable senators are aware, under the existing income tax law all wage and salary earners, even before the passage of this legislation, are asked to include their tax file number when each year or whenever they change employment they fill in their claim for the personal rebate. It is true that some taxpayers do not do that. As far as I am aware, the Commissioner does not pursue them for failing to do so, but most taxpayers comply with the request and provide to their employer, and through him to the Commissioner of Taxation, their tax file number. It seemed to me, and it still seems to me, that in that narrow respect the proposal contained in the tax file number Bill was little more than a formalisation of the situation which already exists.

My concerns with the tax file number proposal, from the beginning, therefore, focused not on the proposed use of the file number in that way but on the other aspects of the Bill: in general terms, what one might call the proposals to link up individuals' tax file numbers with their bank accounts or other financial dealings, stockbrokers' records, if they happen to be in the category of people who deal with stockbrokers-I do not happen myself to be in that fortunate situation-or any other transactions which, so to speak, took the proposals into people's private lives or which could, at any rate, be seen as doing so. Let me repeat: it was that aspect of the tax file number proposal to which I therefore personally paid the greatest attention as we have moved along with its examination.

Clearly, that approach raises several questions. Firstly, should those other uses of the tax file number be approved at all? That is the threshold question. Should the use of the number go beyond that narrow use in respect of employment and social security, or a particular range of social security benefits? Secondly, if a wider range of usage were to be approved, should there be some means provided whereby those who have a deeply held and what one might almost call conscientious objection to these proposals could avoid them, provided, of course, that in doing so they did not avoid tax as well? It never has been any part of the Opposition's attitude towards this proposal that we should in any way look favourably upon the activities of-I was going to say tax avoiders, but the more correct term in this case is-tax evaders. Thirdly, and more generally, whatever the final shape of the tax file number Bill should prove to be-if it were to be enacted at all, that is to say-it was clearly of the greatest importance that, first, there should be safeguards against improper use of the tax file number within the tax file number Bill itself, and that those safeguards should be strengthened as far as possible; and secondly, that more general privacy legislation should be enacted to provide taxpayers with assurances of an even wider kind that their personal privacy would be respected.

In that last respect, the matter of privacy, I have to say that I do not think we have been well served by the Government and that indeed until very recently, I think the gravest doubts continued to exist-and certainly that includes in my own mind-as to whether the Government's proposals in the privacy area would be sufficiently reassuring to the Opposition, and to myself personally, that we would be able to actually give approval to the tax file number proposal as amended. For one thing, although privacy legislation had been promised during the Australia Card debate-I think I am correct in saying that a Bill was actually unveiled at that time-that earlier Bill was, in a great many respects, defective and, more importantly for the current debate, no new or revised Privacy Bill was produced by the Government until a few weeks ago, notwithstanding that, as I noted earlier, the tax file number proposal itself had been formally unveiled by the Treasurer in the May economic statement and that, of course, we know it to have been in gestation within the Government for some time before that.

Even when the Privacy Bill was produced it was not formally published. It is true that a copy of the draft Bill was provided, as I understand, by the Minister for Justice, Senator Tate, to the shadow Attorney-General, Mr Neil Brown, MHR, on a confidential basis so that he would have advance knowledge of what the Government was proposing and be able to react to the form of the draft Bill and to form, as indeed things turned out, the basis of discussions on the draft legislation between him and the Minister for Justice. However, I have to say-I do so with great respect to both gentlemen concerned-that I do not think that a procedure which involves publishing the Bill in a formal manner to attract the wider comments from the public at large-is something which a publication procedure would have enabled.

I would be the first to assert that there is much wisdom in the shadow Cabinet, particularly in the person of Mr Neil Brown himself. There may be a little less wisdom than there was until recently; but I will let that point pass. But, as a general rule, proposals of this kind are best handled by exposing them to the more general and public light of day. That was not the course taken by the Government. In what might almost be described as the Government's usual secretive manner, it sought to suppress knowledge of the details of the draft Privacy Bill from the public more generally until after that prior consultative process with the Opposition had been concluded.

Speaking personally, that of course puts me under some disadvantage. I am sure it put other non-members of the shadow Cabinet on the Opposition side at a similar disadvantage in assessing for themselves the adequacy of the privacy proposals. Perhaps more seriously, I believe that procedure helped to prolong the wide-ranging and, in some cases, quite passionately held fears which had been expressed about the whole tax file number proposal itself. Let me say a little more about that. I have said, ever since the tax file number proposal was first unveiled, that the final view of the Opposition towards the proposal would, no doubt, have to be arrived at after weighing two clearly conflicting considerations, seeking to balance one against the other and to determine where the balance fell. On the one hand, we have the clear public benefit of intensifying, through the introduction of this proposal, the crackdown against tax cheats and, to a lesser degree, welfare fraud perpetrators. A measure-not the only measure, but a significant one-of the effectiveness of the pursuit of those universally held objectives, held on both sides of the chamber, would be given by the estimates of the net revenue gain to be had from the proposal. Obviously, if the net revenue gain was to be only a very small amount, by that test the proposal would not be very effective in pursuing the objective of cracking down on tax cheats and welfare fraud perpetrators.

On the other hand, and to be weighed, therefore, against that public benefit, there has been all along the question of the private cost which would be involved in any further intrusion into personal privacy which the introduction of the tax file number proposal might involve. I would say to the Government-the point is perhaps no longer material, but one should seek to learn from what I believe on this occasion to have been a past error-that the more that we in the Opposition and, indeed, the public more generally could be assured about the adequacy of the promised privacy legislation, the more likely we should have been to find ourselves balancing those two conflicting objectives in what one might call the Government's favour, and the more successful the Government would have been in banishing the fears in the community, in many cases genuinely held fears, about the potential threat to privacy which the measure was believed, particularly initially, to involve.

The holding of this draft privacy legislation as confidential until virtually the last moment was a thoroughly counterproductive method of proceeding, and I hope that the Government will not follow that course on such occasions in the future. Indeed, as a consequence of that we had a reliance by the Government on the Opposition-virtually the Opposition only, because the non-publication of the draft privacy legislation meant that almost nobody else was in a position to comment on it-in the Senate in particular, to fix up the errors which the Government's legislation in this case, as, unfortunately, in so many others, has involved.

The rest of what I have to say is largely history. The shadow Attorney-General, the honourable member for Menzies (Mr N. A. Brown), after a series of discussions with the Minister for Justice (Senator Tate) put to him finally a series of very significant amendments to the proposed Privacy Bill, in particular an amendment which would have the effect of including in the draft Bill provisions which were addressed specifically to the tax file number proposal. In that respect and in a number of other detailed respects, which will no doubt be covered by other speakers, we have seen a major-a really major-improvement in the quality of the amended final version of the Privacy Bill, which is now before the Senate. In light of that development and in light of the fact that in the course of deliberations of the Senate Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs it clearly emerged that there would be a significant increase in net revenue arising from the tax file number proposal if that system were to be enacted, the final view of the Opposition was that it should accept the tax file number proposal.

It should do so by assisting the Government, in this case, to fix up its own defective legislation. That having been done and a great deal of additional assurance having thereby been built into the Privacy Bill in particular it was felt that the Opposition should not stand in the way of what, taken by itself, is undoubtedly likely to be a quite effective means of pursuing further crackdown on tax cheating and welfare fraud. I repeat that the latter is an objective which is shared on both sides of the chamber and one from which certainly the Opposition has never swerved.

Our concerns about this proposal from the beginning have been particularly in the area of the privacy legislation. We now believe that both through our repairs to that legislation and through the introduction of what I might call the conscientious objection clause-the voluntary element whereby if people do not wish to provide their tax file number to an agent they can agree to having their income taxed at the top marginal rate-the measures have been sufficiently improved to allow us to approve of them.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Haines Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Following the Government's Tax Summit three years ago it decided that having a national identification system with a national identification card complete with photograph and a magnetic strip or maybe even a smart card with a computer chip on the front of it was a good way of catching tax cheats and the social security defrauders that the Government claimed were littering Australia in their hundreds of thousands. The hundreds of thousands of ordinary Australian citizens who pay their tax, do not get unemployment benefits when they are holding down a job, and do not get age pensions when their income is over the prescribed amount, supported the senators who stood out against the Australia Card proposal.

SPEECH.PARA: More by good luck than by good management we managed to foil the Government's proposal, not because we were able to defeat the legislation because the Government had the capacity for a joint sitting after the double dissolution but because it was revealed that the whole thing hinged on a regulation which could be disallowed in only one House of Parliament and the numbers were in the Senate to disallow it. That much is history. The legislation was proposed, it was opposed and, to all intents and purposes, it was defeated. The Government's reaction was predictable. It screamed that it was being denied vast amounts of lost revenue. It screamed that those of us who oppose the legislation were friends of tax cheats and organised crime and social security defrauders, if not actively taking part in all or any of those activities ourselves. It made all of these claims following the defeat of the original legislation despite the fact that in the period between 1985 and the defeat of the legislation the Government had, through a variety of legislative and administrative means, recouped something like $800m of the $1,000m that it claimed it had been losing. I recall on a number of occasions, most recently I think in October of last year, listing the legislative measures, the administrative actions taken by this Government to recoup revenue lost previously through people who were able to rort the tax and social security systems. In 1985 the Government was quite accurate in its assessment that $1 billion was being lost. Where it was wrong was in believing that introducing an Australia Card was the only way to recoup that money. The Government proved that itself by introducing those measures.

I point out, too, that the charge of being friends of tax cheats can hardly be levelled seriously at the Australian Democrats, no matter to whom else it may be directed. I remind the Senate that we-not the Liberal and National parties-supported the Government's major tax reforms in its first few years in government. The capital gains tax legislation and the fringe benefits tax legislation covered two areas where often extremely well off people were able to pay less tax than they should have by getting benefits in kind instead of in cash, by avoiding the speculative capital gains prohibition in the tax legislation, but nevertheless making unearned gains, windfall gains, which until 1985 were not taxed.

We also supported this Government's main attack on the cash economy, a very real problem in the community whereby people were willing to pay small builders, for example, less for cash than they would have had to pay by cheque. We supported the prescribed payments system and did not resile in any way from doing so. However, what we can be accused of doing is being concerned that tax collecting zeal, well meant and justified though it may have been, could have led to a big brother society in which a centralised databank contained all financial, health and other details about every one of us. If this sort of thing had occurred with an Australia Card or if it occurs in the future-I believe it may well do so as a result of the passage of this legislation, the only difference being that, instead of being given a new number, an existing number, namely, the tax file number (TFN) will be used-it will make it very easy indeed for governments to control, manipulate, if not actually tyrannise, groups and individuals in society.

I know that there are those-there are plenty of journalists among them-who say that if people have nothing to hide they have nothing to fear. They say, `I do not care who knows what my tax file number is. I will put it at the top of this article that I am writing on this legislation'. That is fine. I suppose that if one has nothing to hide one has nothing to fear, so long as the situation exists where one knows what it is that one has to fear. If one does not know that, I guess one does not really know what it is that one ought to be hiding. Our society is not based on a system of legislation hinged on the idea that if one has nothing to hide one has nothing to fear. Our system is hedged about with protections of people's privacy. Would those people who say, `Of course we need this sort of legislation' or `Of course we need an Australia Card' and `If you have nothing to hide you have nothing to fear' feel happy if a State government changed its laws relating to police search warrants so that at any time of the day or night the local constabulary could knock on their front door and say, `Excuse me, but we are looking for some stolen goods or drugs or illegal firearms; can we just rifle through your bedroom cupboards'? This is what we are talking about when we say that we should base society on the idea that everybody should know everything about everybody else and have access to all sorts of private information because if one has nothing to hide one has nothing to fear. That is not the sort of society I want to be part of.

Letters appear regularly in newspapers from people who object to having their bags searched at supermarket checkouts, on the ground that they are being judged potentially guilty from the minute they walk into the store with a bag. How much more intrusive is it, then, to give a government the capacity to search our financial dealings, Medicare rebates, family assistance benefits and so on? I accept that the remaining areas of revenue loss-the remaining $200m to $300m a year that is lost, the remaining 26c a week per person that is being lost-needs to be recovered. We need to attend to the problems that are causing that loss. The major problem is undeclared interest on invested money, and that can be fixed up without going through this exercise.

What is worse is that this legislation will not stop tax fraud. Let us look at what has to be done. People commencing employment with an employer after November 1988 must quote their tax file number on an employment declaration. All employees-including recipients of unemployment and sickness benefits for the purpose of defining what an employee is-must lodge a fresh instalment declaration with each employer on 1 April 1989 and quote their tax file number. By April of next year everybody will be quoting their tax file number to their employer, and there are other areas where the number has to be quoted, such as bank accounts, building society accounts and so on. All employees, all those who open and run bank accounts, must lodge an instalment declaration and quote their tax file number. We all know that there are people in the community who have several jobs. They operate them, if they are smart, in several names-and if they are even smarter, they have several tax file numbers to match those several names. They will go on operating in the same way under the legislation.

My younger daughter entered the work force and paid tax for the first time last year. I said to her when she was filling out this year's tax return, `How did you get your tax file number?'. She said, `I filled out the form and they sent it to me'. She filled out the form in absolutely correct detail, but it is possible that someone in her position is also working at night with another name and another tax file number, handed out when that person filled out the first form. Such people are getting two tax-free thresholds and paying a lower marginal tax rate than they should be paying. I doubt very much whether this system would pick that up. The criminal elements, of course, will go on getting away with murder, real and metaphorical, because they have access to all of the false documentation that they need anyway to prove that they are the people or the several people they claim to be-or indeed that they are no-one in particular, if it comes to that.

The worst of it all is that, since the original Australia Card legislation met its doom, the Australian Taxation Office appears to have done nothing of any consequence to improve the integrity of the tax file number. The integrity of the tax file number does not mean spreading it around to all and sundry. It means improving its credibility. At the moment it has less credibility than a passport number. The cosy deal that was done between the Opposition and the Government to pass this legislation has achieved nothing except to get their rich mates off a hook. They come into this chamber and say, `Look what we have done-aren't we clever? We have said that it is no longer illegal for people not to quote a tax file number to their employer, bank or whatever. However, the sanction will still apply: 50.25c in the dollar will be deducted from their interest, taxable earnings, and so on'. That is a terrific help to the people you, Madam Acting Deputy President, and I are usually most concerned about, people on average weekly earnings or less! People on $100,000 a year can afford to wait until the end of the year to get back from the Tax Office overassessed tax paid. People on $25,000 a year or less, with a couple of kids and a spouse at home, are not in that position. The Opposition cannot walk into this chamber and say that they have made this scheme voluntary. It is voluntary only to the extent that people may be wealthy enough to be able to afford the top rate of tax.

The two pieces of legislation before the Senate today, the Taxation Laws Amendment (Tax File Numbers) Bill and the Privacy Bill, which is supposed to protect everybody from infringement, are both still massively flawed and both need amendment. As I have said, tax file numbers are to be used for both employment and investment purposes. The Opposition's agreement with the Government on the non-compulsory quotation of the number is a convenience only for the wealthy. The Australian Democrats intend to move an amendment which will genuinely give all people, whatever their income, a choice about whether to supply their tax file number to the relevant private sector institutions. We have said to the Government, `Yes, create a nexus between the employee or the investor and the institution where people are employed or investing and the Tax Office. If you want that little triangle, you can have it, but don't make it go clockwise all the time. Don't insist that people have to give the number to an institution so that the Tax Office knows they are on the level. Give those individuals a choice. Give them the opportunity within, say, 30 days to let the Tax Office know that that is where they are working and what their name and tax file number are. Then let the triangle be completed anti-clockwise so that the Tax Office gives them the Good Housekeeping seal of approval in regard to the investing institution or employing institution'. That way people will not face the choice, which is not a choice, of either giving their number over to the institution and paying the correct amount of tax or not giving it over and having over half their assessable income deducted.

The Democrats will move an amendment to the motion for the second reading which attacks both Government and Opposition. Indeed, increasingly we have been criticising both sides in this place in the last five years. Indeed, I now move:
At end of motion, add: `, but the Senate notes that-

(a) the Government's tax file number system is unacceptably intrusive in that the tax file number will be given to a range of private sector institutions which will not be adequately covered by the Government's privacy legislation;

(b) the Opposition parties' amendments to the tax file number legislation are meaningless to the ordinary taxpayer in that they only provide wealthy people with a real option not to supply the tax file number to private sector institutions; and

(c) the Government and Opposition parties are both to be condemned for their failure to support an alternative system which would have caught people who were cheating the tax system and protected the privacy of Australian taxpayers and would not have laid the foundations of a national identification system'.

The Privacy Bill is a piece of legislation for which we have been arguing for as many years as we have been members of this Parliament. It is long overdue. However, in the form in which it is presented to us today it is still very deficient. Worst of all, it will not be an effective protection against misuse or abuse of the tax file number or the legislation behind it. A number of areas require improvement and to at least some of those we will move amendments at the committee stage. The legislation should apply to the private sector. Most of the problems that are occurring with regard to the invasion of privacy come from the private sector. Certainly, they also come from the public sector, but there is no justification for the private sector being omitted from coverage in the legislation.

The information privacy principles (IPPs) need to be strengthened and there needs to be a provision to sue for damages for breach of privacy. I understand that the Opposition will move an amendment concerning the right to sue for damages for breach of privacy and we will support that amendment. I understand that it will also move an amendment regarding the Administrative Appeals Tribunal's review of a decision of the Privacy Commissioner and we will support that amendment also. However, it is a pity that previous actions by the Opposition parties, in conjunction with the Government, have put this appeals mechanism out of the reach of an awful lot of ordinary people. It is a very real pity that the Opposition supported the Government's increased freedom of information and Administrative Appeals Tribunal charges and costs, because the information that many people will need and the appeals they may wish to take will probably become prohibitively expensive, again, for everybody except the well off. I will detail the amendments more fully at the committee stage.

Some of the information privacy principles are still of concern. Principle 2 deals with the solicitation of personal information from the information subject. One would have thought that the collector of information would be obliged to advise the subject-I love the terminology that draftspeople use-of the purpose of the collection in specific terms. That is not just something we have dreamed up to be difficult. It is, of course, as per Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development recommendations and indeed the Australian Law Reform Commission's recommendations. According to the principle, advice should be in specific terms-not just making people generally aware of what is happening, as is the requirement in the current draft.

Principle 3 relates to solicitation of personal information generally. Again, the collector should be obliged to take reasonable steps-indeed, in some cases even unreasonable and extraordinary steps-to ensure accuracy of information. Again, that is the Australian Law Reform Commission's approach.

Principle 5 deals with information relating to records kept by the record keeper. The Australian Democrats believe that agencies should be required to disclose additional matters, including purposes for obtaining categories of sources; purposes for which they will be used; purposes of disclosure to third parties; policies and practices with regard to storage; the record keeper's authority for maintaining the system; and whether the information is exempt from access.

Principle 6 deals with access to records containing personal information. As it is drafted, application of the Freedom of Information Act could be used to deny corrections to inaccurate information. That is simply not good enough. Heaven knows, the original Freedom of Information Act has become what used to be called laughingly in the early days the freedom from information Act. This will only make matters worse.

Principles 10 and 11 deal with limits on the use and disclosure of personal information. There are far too many and far too broad a series of exceptions to this. For example, they permit the use and disclosure of information for purposes other than simply its collection by most agencies for most purposes. That certainly needs to be tightened. Information privacy principles 10 1.(d) and 11 1.(e) permit the use and disclosure of personal information where it is reasonably necessary to do so for the enforcement of the criminal law or of a law imposing a pecuniary penalty. I guess nobody will quibble about the first of those and, quite possibly, the second, but they also extend to the protection of the public revenue. I cannot think of too many things that we do in this world that are not somehow or other connected with public revenue-giving it or not giving it or getting some of it back. Talk about a catch-all clause! It covers every purpose for which information may be used by all tax collecting and benefit providing authorities of the Commonwealth. No information will be safe. It would, in effect, make most government departments exempt from the two most important information privacy principles contained in the legislation for most of their activities. So I do not know why the Government bothered.

The second problem relates to the non-regulation of information contained in law enforcement databases. This type of information unquestionably can be the most damaging information compiled by governments on individuals. Sometimes the compilation is not necessarily accurate or in context. There is no doubt that both arbitrary and systematic matching of this sort of information occurs at present and this Bill will not impose any review or control by the Privacy Commissioner. We have only to look at the United States or listen to stories from friends in Australia about the problems that arise out of inaccurate computer information being used to accuse individuals falsely. Sometimes that is just information taken out of context; sometimes it is information being maliciously misused; and sometimes it is just because two people with similar names have been confused with each other. Numbers are not a great deal different from names. It is quite possible to see transfers of letters and it is just as possible to see transfers of numbers that are not really there. The need for public disclosure review and assessment of these programs is overwhelming.

It should also be noted that law enforcement agencies already have adequate powers to obtain information. The legal processes of search warrants and subpoenas include privacy protection by virtue of the prior requirement that an independent judicial officer must be satisfied that the invasion of privacy is justified. That is why we do not have knocks on the door at midnight by the local constabulary wanting to search for a missing stereo unit or the video that disappeared from the house next door. The approach taken in IPPs 10 and 11 removes that protection and that is quite unsatisfactory. IPPs 10 1.(c) and 11 1.(d) are too broad. The only laws which should be included are those which refer specifically to the category of documents or information concerned. We will be moving amendments to cover those areas.

It is interesting to note, on an academic level, that, unlike most Commonwealth laws, the Privacy Bill does not contain an objects clause, even though the Privacy Commissioner's powers are constrained by reference to purposes in clause 29. I am not sure whether it is a matter of irony or a matter of suspicion, but some of those purposes-the general desirability of a free flow of information, for example-cut right across the presumed privacy protection purposes of the Bill. This apparent conflict is going to present the courts with a massive problem of interpretation and contrasts adversely with the Freedom of Information Act, which clearly expresses Parliament's intention that the right of access to information should be the dominant value except to the extent necessary for the protection of essential public interests and personal affairs.

An objects clause should have been included in the Bill. This clause should include provisions such as `personal information acquired for one purpose should not be used for other purposes' and `a national identification scheme should not be established'. Other matters could also have been included, but those are the two major ones. The interpretation section in clause 6 is also deficient. `Personal information' is inadequately defined in that unique identifiers other than names are not included. For example, numbers or symbols can also be used as identifiers. Nor, of course, is information which is computer linked to personal information included. Again, the full privacy protection elements seem not to have been thought through thoroughly.

The definition of tax file number information, crucial to the workability of the legislation, is an interpretation problem. As it stands, the definition means information `that records the tax file number of a person in a manner connecting it with the person's identity'. This excludes information associated with the TFN or information not directly connecting them with a person's identity. Clause 7 excludes the National Crime Authority from the Bill. I will have more to say about that at the committee stage because there are some concerns in that respect. Clause 15 deals with the application of the IPP but could well prove to be destructive of personal privacy.

Overall, we acknowledge that the Bill is an improvement on the 1986 version on the grounds that any privacy is better than none. I suppose one would have to say that. But it is not sufficient to cover the needs of the tax file number legislation.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable senator's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Aulich Sen T.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak on the Taxation Laws Amendment (Tax File Numbers) Bill 1988, which is part of the Government's program to clear up the tax system. I do not think anyone in this chamber or, for that matter, most people in the community at large can have any doubts whatsoever that this Government, from the day it was first elected in 1983, has been sincere about ensuring that the tax system not only works fairly but also is seen to be working fairly. All members of this House will recall, some vividly and some less vividly, that the tax summit was an attempt by this Government to bring together all the groups in the community-from business to unions to consumer organisation-and to get their views about what should be done to make sure that the tax system in this country works fairly and is seen to be working fairly.

SPEECH.PARA: Australia is in a unique position. We are a young country which so far does not have an entrenched minority of people across the nation who accept that they have certain privileges with regard to taxation or any other part of government activity and who feel that they are above the law. So far, this is the ethos of a very small minority in the community-that is, the rich, the wealthy, the powerful, the greedy and the cynical. So far that group has not been able to dominate the scene in this country as has been the case in a number of other countries. If we examine the tax compliance record of countries such as France, Italy and the United States of America we will see that they have a whole subculture of non-compliance with taxation laws which most people take for granted.

As yet, we have not got to that stage. But the danger signs certainly began to be apparent during the Fraser period with bottom of the harbour schemes, cherry picking schemes and a variety of other schemes drafted by tax accountants and sought by the smarter people in the business community-and I use the word `smarter' in the pejorative sense-to the point where taxation was becoming a laughing matter. I know that John Howard, as Treasurer, was given proposals by his Department and was in the position of discussing options with the business community. For example, he had before him a Cabinet submission relating to a consumption tax which he examined and discussed with some of his colleagues but never brought to fruition simply because it was too hard.

I know that at various times Prime Minister Fraser was given advice by high level public servants that the tax problem was about to get out of hand. The bottom of the harbour issue made the front page headlines of many newspapers around Australia for a very long time. The unfortunate sequence of events, for Malcolm Fraser, which emanated from the Royal Commission on the Activities of the Federated Ship Painters and Dockers Union suddenly brought home to the average Australian just how deep and widespread tax cheating was throughout this country.

Since coming to power, this Government has followed through some of the minor and half-hearted reforms that John Howard was forced to bring in. We have looked not only at some of the issues raised by the Royal Commission on the Activities of the Federated Ship Painters and Dockers Union but also at the whole issue of tax reform. We accept that in a Federal system it is not possible for a Federal government totally to reform the tax system and the company system without the cooperation of the States. That is, of course, the great difficulty. A fair tax system has two prongs. The first is to ensure that the tax regime itself is appropriate and fair and is seen to be fair. The second, of course, is the reform of the company law itself. We can assume that individuals in the community who wish to evade their tax obligations and responsibilities can manipulate the company code and corporate affairs legislation in various States.

Obviously, there will not be complete and effective tax reform in this country until we are able to bring together the States and the Federal Government in pursuit of more effective corporate affairs legislation. I will give the Senate one example. The case for penalties for non-compliance with corporate law in this country, relating especially to annual returns of companies, is very much a problem primarily because the penalties themselves are so weak and because investigative bodies, the corporate affairs organisations around this country, are usually understaffed and there are difficulties in pursuing and prosecuting cases in the courts. As I said, much of this comes back to the establishments of corporate affairs commissions or the various corporate bodies that carry out State responsibilities. The second reason is the law itself relating to companies. To this point I have dealt with this matter with a broad brush.

This Government has already begun the process of tax reform. We have examined the consumption tax proposal to see whether such a tax would bring in some fairness and equity, but in the end we have looked at clamping down on the rorts and the ramps that existed in the system. We examined, for example, the capital gains tax. We looked at Australia in comparison with overseas countries. We saw, for example, that a capital gains tax existed in virtually every Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development (OECD) country. Yet, such a tax did not exist in Australia, except in terms of section 26aaa of the Income Tax Assessment Act, which even for business was an intolerable tax in terms of the way it could be interpreted and operated. So, the Treasurer (Mr Keating), the Cabinet and this Government, despite enormous protests orchestrated by the Liberal Party and the National Party, brought in a fringe benefits tax and substantiation requirements.

Basically, they brought in the principle that people should not have a lifestyle which is tax deductable. One should not be able to drive a Jaguar which is used primarily for private purposes and expect the taxpayer to pay for it. One cannot drive a Mercedes-Benz or a Porsche and write it off as a tax deduction in the way that people were doing in the past. One cannot offer a brilliant young manager the opportunity to have his house totally paid for by the company without any tax being paid on it. One cannot offer a young executive the opportunity to go out on a Saturday night with a dozen people and write the whole lot down on his bill in order to have it as a tax deductible night out. One cannot send one's children to private schools and expect the company to pay for it and then have it tax deductible.

All those rorts and ramps had to be brought to an end, and this Treasurer, Paul Keating, did that. He is a politician who has looked at the long term future of this country and said that fairness and equity must be brought into the tax system, that there cannot be one law, one system of practice in terms of tax deductibility, for one group of people and another law or system for ordinary pay as you earn taxpayers. Nor, for that matter, can we have one system for companies which rort the law and another system for companies which try to compete with them but which do things honestly.

In my experience one of the strongest protests about the tax system that existed before we came into government came to me from people in the business community. Admittedly, they were in Tasmania and probably were not used to some of the schemes that operated in a wide open town such as Sydney, where the ethos may be different. These people said to me over and over again, in letters, interviews and discussions we had when we were discussing industrial relations matters, `How can we compete as an honest company, as an honest business, against our competitors who are prepared to use and rort the system in every possible way, who can afford the best tax lawyers, who can afford to argue with the Australian Taxation Office over a two- or three-year period and cop the penalties, but at the end of the day accept the compromises that the Tax Office, understaffed as it is, inevitably has to agree to?'. The loudest complaint coming to me was from those honest people in the business community who did not want to be involved in the twilight and shadowy systems that some of their competitors were involved in.

I must say by way of anecdote that my first experience with tax rorting was when I first went to work in Sydney in the middle 1960s as a storeman and packer. I worked in an extremely big store in Botany, which was full of woollen and nylon waste. All it did was pick up the scraps from industry and resell them to countries in the system. The company chose us by simply asking us to lift a series of weights, and if we were strong enough we got hired. I am much older now, so I do not think I would pass the same test now. The interesting thing was that my job for the first five weeks was simply to move a quarter of the contents of that wool store from one end to the other and to re-label bales for no other purpose than to allow that company to write off stock in an appropriate way which gave it what I saw as an enormous tax advantage. When it discussed the system with me I was quite surprised that people in this country somehow operated a business on that basis, a complete rorting of the tax system with total impunity. It considered that that was the only way it could compete with the people up the road. There were about 14 or 15 companies in that area which were operating in the same type of business.

I have progressively watched Australia change as more and more people have sought the advice of tax lawyers and tax accountants and have practised that advice, to the point where in 1983, when this Government came to power, there was a growing discontentment on the part of business, pay as you earn taxpayers and ordinary householders about the way the tax system was working. I believe that we reach a point at which confidence in the system goes completely and the general ethos in the community as a whole is one of `I'm all right, Jack; I will look after myself. If I can rort the system, I will'. When we reach that point, when sufficient people in the community start to believe that, we are in real difficulties. As I have said, some OECD countries have already reached that situation. From discussions I have had with some French and Italian people, I believe that the French and Italian systems are beyond improvement. They will never have a fair tax system. They will simply have to accept the existence of a black economy. They will have to accept that a significant part of their gross national product simply goes out the back door to people who operate in an illegal manner.

This Government has begun the process of tax reform. I have indicated that that process cannot end until we change company law in this country, and that involves a very long and complicated series of discussions being put into operation not only now but also in the future. It means that we genuinely have to believe that company law in this country has to be reformed. But that is down the road. At this stage the Government has looked, first of all, at a consumption tax. We decided that we could not go ahead with that. I think the general feeling in the community was that there were too many questions about the proposal left unanswered.

We looked at the Australia Card proposal. As we all know, that did not pass the Senate for various reasons, partly I think because people were concerned about alleged attacks on civil liberties and privacy. I think the Government learnt from that exercise. I do not think it was a failure. I thing that on the whole everyone in this Parliament was forced to examine those three issues of tax equity, civil liberties and the protection of privacy much more closely than they had done before. The Opposition can say, `We won. We got someone to find a loophole in the Australia Card legislation. It died in the Senate and therefore we won'. But it is not as simple as that.

I think that on the whole the debate had enormous value, as did the work done by the Joint Select Committee on an Australia Card, in the sense that it forced at least a minority of this Parliament to examine the issue in depth, to call in people who otherwise would not have been consulted and to put before the Senate a significant body of information, ideas, options and alternatives which is valuable and has been valuable for the Government as it has drafted its tax file number legislation and which has been valuable for the Tax Office and also for the community at large. It is very significant that an option proposed in a minority report, which was partly agreed to by the majority as at least a second-best option, has now appeared before us as Government legislation.

The Australian Democrats may have some problems in remaining consistent, but then no-one has ever really expected the Democrats to be consistent through their political life. They are the pimple on the backside of politics in that sense. They are important in the process of getting debate going in this chamber, but no-one in the long term expects them to be consistent on matters such as this. They will always find a way out because they appeal to a special interest group out there. They calculate it to be as high as 20 per cent of the electorate; I would put it at about 11 per cent and diminishing.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is when Senator Vigor was around.

—I think it was diminishing even more quickly than at any other time when Senator Vigor was around. Senator Vigor may have been responsible for the massive decline in the membership of the Democrats in this country. He ought to be thanked by this Senate. The Democrats will always find problems with legislation such as this. They will always, like a dancing partner, take one step backwards and keep taking one step backwards until ultimately, I suppose, they are out the door. I can see that Senator Lewis is smiling; when he sees the last of the Democrats walk through that door it will be a dream come true. He has often said that in this chamber. However, we do have to take seriously some of their concerns. We certainly did as a result of the report of the Joint Select Committee on an Australia Card. We looked at the protection of privacy and civil liberties, and for the most part I think their concerns are met in this legislation.

SPEECH.PARA: I move on to the question of civil liberties and privacy. Many countries are attempting to examine that issue not just in relation to tax laws and corporate laws but in general. How does one protect ordinary citizens of this country against autocratic and insensitive actions on the part not only of government but also of bureaucrats-public servant bureaucrats as well as bureaucrats of large private enterprise organisations? I ask the Democrats: which is preferable? Is it preferable to have sections such as 263 and 264 operating in the current tax Act, under which tax officers can search a house or premises without a warrant, enter that property and take records and documents, invade the privacy of individuals, or do they wish to move to another system where the Tax Office does not have to rely upon those sorts of methods to pull back revenue that has been forgone through tax cheating?

It seems to me to be a logical approach to say, `Yes, let's have a tax file number system; let's have a universal identifier which works in the interests of honest taxpayers, which makes it easier for the Taxation Office to do its job', rather than say to the Tax Office, `We don't want a tax file number system. We don't want an Australia Card system. We don't want anything which enables you to do your job effectively and efficiently. We want you to use sections 263 and 264 to invade people's privacy, to rely upon those particular sections', which I have always regarded as very dangerous in terms of civil liberties. Are the Democrats telling us to rely upon those sections or do they want to get back to the legislation which the Government is bringing forward today?

The second point I wish to make about civil liberties and privacy is that I have heard very little from the Democrats about privacy per se; that is, privacy across the board. It is not just a question of what governments do to restrict or to invade privacy. What sort of system do we want? Do we want proper protection of civil liberties across the board, starting with government, or do we want to be like the Democrats, who raise only the question of invasion of privacy by government and neglect what is happening out there in private enterprise?

Everyone who has an American Express card or other credit cards such as that knows that at the bottom of the application one signs to get a credit card there is a line which states that the person applying for credit agrees to allow that organisation to share the information provided with other organisations. I am sure that half the Democrats have credit cards and have signed those forms, yet I have not heard one Democrat in this chamber raise the question of uncontrolled invasion of privacy by those credit organisations. Where were the Democrats when the Australia Card and civil liberties and the invasion of privacy were being discussed? We brought to that Committee information which showed that around four million people in New South Wales and Victoria alone are on some form of credit register and do not know that they are on that credit register. They just assume that somehow or other banks know about them.

Anyone who has been involved in the subpoenaing of individuals in civil matters will know that banks can be required under subpoena to give up to a court all their notes about particular individuals. There is really not much protection of privacy there. I will take Senator Michael Baume as an example--

TALK.START.PARA: —Where will you take me?

—I will take the honourable senator to a bank. We will assume that he goes in to borrow some money. He may or may not be divorced, he may have had problems with companies in the past. The bank will simply make a note of what he has told them and what it knows about him. In many cases, the bank will make some very personal notes about his behaviour, his credibility and his past record-that is, the record he has provided and its records of him from other sources. This is on file not only for that bank manager to look at but also for other bank managers who come after him, who may very well mix in the same social circle as does Senator Baume.
—I must have passed the test. I got an overdraft.

—That is no passing of test; that is a sort of suck-in for greater loans later on. I must warn the honourable senator about that. Banks alone keep an enormous amount of extremely personal information on people which can be made available to courts of law and other individuals. Again being personal, the first time I ever saw one of these notes was when I read, upside down, my bank manager's notes on my card. It stated, `Poor but honest'. One wonders whether that has changed.
—On how many scores was he wrong?

—On both, I would say! I did not know that bank managers wrote those sorts of comments. I then asked a few of them, `What do you write?'. They said that they wrote some very personal information about people. If a bank manager does not give a full documented history of a person as he sees him and knows about him his credibility is on the line. I have not heard anything from the Democrats about those potential invasions of privacy in the private area; nor have I heard from the Democrats about some of the files kept on individuals in the private sector relating to their employability. I do not wish to bring this before the Senate in any detail today but I will be addressing it at a later date.

SPEECH.PARA: There are indications in this country that at the moment certain private enterprise organisations, employers, are coming together and sharing information about the employability, credibility, honesty and political viewpoints of executives they have employed or might employ in the future. Great Britain has already been through that problem, with one organisation having more than a million people on file. The inaccuracies that have appeared in some of those files would astonish us. Where were the Democrats when that issue was raised?

TALK.START.PARA: —Out to lunch.

—Out to lunch. It is not tax deductable nowadays, but certainly out to lunch. So the problem then is, I suppose, one of unctiousness for the Australian Democrats: that if a government moves to protect civil liberties and privacy, we will never do well enough; just as if we move on conservation issues, we never do well enough. They are after a certain constituency. I will at least give members of the Liberal Party praise in this area. They were prepared to discuss our privacy legislation; they were prepared to propose amendments; and they were prepared to talk about the tax file number and our privacy legislation accompanying it. I believe that out of those discussions this Parliament will be presented with legislation which will take us a long way down the track of having a fair taxation system in this country, a taxation system which is seen to be fair by everyone, and a system of privacy protection which will be the equal of those of most countries in the OECD.

SPEECH.PARA: For that reason I support this legislation, having been involved in the Joint Select Committee on an Australia Card as its chairman, having been involved in industrial relations discussions with many business organisations as chairman of the Caucus committee for industrial relations with this Government. I know that many of the requests and requirements that business, the trade union movement and the community in general have made of us are being satisfied by this Government. If this Government is starting to satisfy the community in terms of fair taxation, if this legislation goes through the Senate as part of that process, the Senate can be commended for once taking a positive view in the interest of all Australians.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —Let us recognise that the Taxation Laws Amendment (Tax File Numbers) Bill is being supported by the Opposition only because it has been radically changed. It is now acceptable, whereas when it was first introduced by this Government it was an appalling, offensive, intrusive, badly drafted Bill which gave excessive powers to the Australian Taxation Office and had a hidden agenda of information-seeking which was far removed from its stated purpose of providing additional revenue. That Bill was a disgrace. It showed that, in fact, the Government had learnt nothing from its experience with the ID card.

SPEECH.PARA: I must say that I was intrigued to hear Senator Aulich-I commend him for much of the sweetness and light, particularly the part where he praised the Opposition and attacked the Australian Democrats-and I was interested in his rewriting of history where he commended the Senate for what proceeded from the ID card debate, the Senate inquiry and so on. I remind Senator Aulich that the Australian Labor Party took a negative position on those matters. The Labor Party wanted to ram the ID card through the Parliament and impose it on Australians. It was thwarted in that objective, and now Senator Aulich seeks to rescue something from that mess by saying, `Isn't it wonderful that out of that mess has come much better legislation?'. I say to Senator Aulich: it is no credit to the Labor Party that this has happened. It tried to ram through the ID card and it proposed legislation which was oppressive and intrusive. We have come to this situation we are now in, where we have an acceptable and reasonable Bill, only because of an inquiry that the Labor Party did not want and of amendments to this Bill that the Labor Party was forced to accept because it would have been shown to be even more crooked and dishonest in its approach had it rejected our proposals. This is a vastly different Bill from the Bill that originally came to this House, not simply in relation to privacy but in relation to what the Bill actually does.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is a far better Bill.

—As Senator Messner says, it is a far better Bill; it is a dramatically changed Bill. We had a couple of options when this son of ID card was first presented to this place: we could either reject it as another example of this Government trying to get in through the back door what it failed to achieve with its intrusive and anti-democratic ID card, or we could set out to fix it up. Fixing it up involved an immense effort. We took the view that it was worth trying to fix it up and we have succeeded in doing so, not only on the score of privacy but by removing Labor's hidden agenda from this Bill. That hidden agenda was to make the tax file number not simply an instrument of collecting tax but a universal identifier. It was at that point son of ID card.

SPEECH.PARA: I believe that the Opposition took the responsible and decent course. Of course, there were many people who said, `Look, you are in opposition; why should you try to fix up the Government's legislation so that it is acceptable?'. We took the view that oppositions have not only a duty to oppose; they have a duty to try to ensure that the people of Australia are not harassed and oppressed by improper legislation; and we also wanted to ensure that this Government could not dishonestly use rejection of this legislation as yet another excuse for yet another double dissolution, another early election, from a Prime Minister who has consistently said, `We will, of course, allow governments, under the Hawke Ministry, to run their full course'. None of them has yet; of course, they probably never will. This is the last one and presumably the Prime Minister will go early-probably at the end of next year-provided the economy is capable of sustaining such an approach to the people.

The fact is that this Government has shown itself to be so dishonest on this matter. For example, on the double dissolution last year, on the ID card, it has shown itself to be so dishonest that this Opposition took the view that it was far better to prevent that dishonesty and to fix up this legislation. As I said, that took a great amount of effort.
