I will not deal with the privacy elements-Mr Neil Brown, the shadow Minister in the other place, did an outstanding job in ensuring that Labor's hidden agenda in that area would be defeated-but I want to concentrate on the Bill itself and how we fixed that up. We fixed it up in such a way that the Treasurer (Mr Keating) says that it is now a much better Bill than the one he introduced. When Mr Keating said that I began to wonder whether we had made a mistake, but this may be one of those occasions on which the Treasurer was not speaking with a forked tongue and maybe he has recognised, as Senator Aulich has, that the Opposition has created through its amendments a most acceptable flower. I suppose one can say that a flower always requires some manure to bring it to fruition. We have produced the flower; the Government has produced the fertiliser.

Getting rid of Labor's hidden agenda was done very simply with this Bill-it was to make the tax file number totally optional. I believe that that was an essential and saving element. It is no longer compulsory for people to provide their tax file numbers. The upgraded tax file number will now be required only in the relationship between the Australian Taxation Office and the taxpayer. Just as we now have a tax file number, this new system will represent an improvement on that tax file number but the only people who will have a requirement to use that number will be those in the Taxation Office and the taxpayer; just as it is now.

No longer will a taxpayer have to reveal his tax file number to an employer. No longer will he have to reveal it to anyone with whom he invests or does business, as under the original proposal. That is simply dramatic. It prevents the Commissioner of Taxation from building up a profile of all taxpayers-a profile which would be available to other departmental sources. It is all very well for people to say that maybe the Taxation Commissioner could not do that. There is no doubt in the light of experience around the world that function creep goes on. In every country in which there is this kind of identifier there is clear function creep. Despite assurances and even legislative restraints, the tax file number and the information backing it slowly become a passport. For example, in Canada, in order to get a duck shooting licence, one has to quote one's tax file number, or Social Insurance Number as it is called. This sort of nonsense is simply unacceptable.

Making the provision of the number totally optional destroys the capacity of any government to build up a coherent information pattern, a base of information, or to use the tax file number as a passport for all sorts of other purposes. Of course, we believe that it is absolutely vital not to give more power to the Tax Commissioner at the moment because, as I have said here before, we believe the present Tax Commissioner has stepped over the bounds of being an independent public servant into becoming a spokesman for government policy through things such as advertisements, signed by the Taxation Commissioner, instead of the Treasurer, advertising and promoting controversial matters that are still subject to political debate. That is simply intolerable.

There has been much discussion about the nature of raids on various private enterprise organisations by officers of the Taxation Office. It was admitted in one court hearing that the object of the raid, with its drama, its huge backup of people and the refusal to allow the private sector people involved to get appropriate advice, was to create an `atmosphere of terror' under which people would be very reluctant to be involved in any devices which may or may not involve tax evasion. It is no wonder that one of the many serious problems we faced in deciding whether we should fix up this legislation, concerned the behaviour of the Tax Commissioner himself. That added to our difficulty in convincing many people that it was worth while fixing up the legislation. In other words, the behaviour of the Tax Commissioner himself prejudiced our chances of convincing many people in Australia that we should do anything that would give an appearance of adding to his powers. This legislation does not add to the Tax Commissioner's powers. It does one simple thing: it catches tax cheats without in any way adding to the bureaucratic information base, unless the taxpayer chooses to provide his tax file number.

Of course, there is another benefit involved in fixing up this legislation rather than rejecting it outright. It prevents the Hawke Government from using the shabby sort of excuse that it would have inevitably used and now will not be used when next year it fails to deliver its promised tax cuts. We have already seen signs of it. The Government tried to suggest that if this Bill does not go through-at its peak it will raise something like $300m-the proposed tax cuts, which would have to be something like $3 billion to $4 billion to be meaningful, would be in jeopardy. This Government has the capacity and the dishonesty to pretend that if this legislation does not go through it will have been prevented by the swinish Opposition from providing the money for the tax cuts that the people of Australia deserve. That is totally dishonest, but it would not prevent the Government from doing it. We have already heard the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) threatening to use that kind of rhetoric, accusing the Opposition of being a friend of tax cheats and making other offensive and dishonourable attacks on us, as some kind of precursor to an attempt next year to blame us.

Now the Government cannot blame us for anything. Under the massive changes we have proposed to this legislation revenue will be collected, but it will be collected in an honest and honourable way, not by using a device with the hidden agenda of compiling secret banks of information against the wishes of individual taxpayers. The Government has been deprived of an excuse for failing to supply next year's tax cuts. It will be interesting to see how this Government will now explain its failure to provide anything meaningful next year in accordance with its promises. No-one should be surprised that the Government will break its promise yet again; but at least it will no longer be able to blame us.

I said earlier that had we rejected this legislation instead of radically fixing it up there would have been a double dissolution. It does not take a genius to work out why the Australian Democrats are opposing the legislation. It is absolutely essential for that Party to have double dissolutions. The Australian Democrats look to situations in which they can create a double dissolution by getting the rejection of important legislation twice in this Senate. I say to the Australian Democrats that they will have to try a little harder for a double dissolution because we are strongly of the view, as is Senator Aulich, that they have not contributed in a positive way to the democratic process in Australia. As one of my colleagues recently said, the Australian Democrats are so unreliable these days that it appears from the Labor Party's criticism of them that they can no longer be bought but have to be rented by the hour.

I believe that it will be to Australia's benefit if we get out of the habit that seems to have developed in recent years of having double dissolutions whenever a Prime Minister feels like it and whenever the Democrats seek to have one. The reason the Government wants so many double dissolutions is that it prefers to deal with a large number of Australian Democrats because it feels that it can horse trade with them rather than rely on the vote of Senator Harradine if the Democrats are wiped out.

TALK.START.PARA: —We had only one and we won it.
—The Labor Party is braying over that issue. I am certain I have hit it on a very sensitive nerve.
—No, we won it. Fraser had one and lost it.

—I am overjoyed to hear the Labor Party Deputy Whip saying that he wanted to get rid of the Democrats. Obviously, he was overruled by his Leader, who enjoys calling double dissolutions at the drop of a hat simply to keep them in this place.
—He is sick of doing deals with them in here.

—Yes, of course. The Deputy Whip would understand because he is the man who has to try to deal with the Australian Democrats and tie them to deals in this chamber. I can understand his frustration. Let us get back to the question of how massively the Opposition has improved this legislation. The report of the Senate Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs on this legislation clearly pointed out that there is a danger of any widely dispersed tax file number becoming a de facto identification number, notwithstanding provisions which prescribe penalties for improper use of the number. An examination of overseas evidence supports this view. That simply cannot happen under the alterations we have made. Under the original arrangements, tax file numbers would have had to be quoted. For example, a person who became an employee would have been required to make an employment declaration stating his or her tax file number. That simply will not happen now. We recognise that there is a consequence of no longer quoting that tax file number, and that is that tax will be withheld at the source at the maximum rate. Of course, the object of that is simple: it means that those people who have multiple jobs, who work under false names, will not have a tax file number, will not be able to provide one and therefore will be taxed.

SPEECH.PARA: Those honest taxpayers who simply do not wish to reveal their tax file numbers will initially have tax withheld, but when they put in their tax returns they will receive rebates, so they will not be worse off except, of course, in terms of timing. Many taxpayers in Australia regret that in recent years their rebates have been so small. Many taxpayers prefer receiving a reasonable tax rebate-particularly if it comes in September or October-to help them over the Christmas holidays. So honest taxpayers will hardly be affected by this situation. Many will prefer to provide employers with their tax file number because, now that the amendments moved by the Opposition to the privacy legislation have been passed, there will be no major disadvantage to a taxpayer in doing so.

However, tax cheats who cannot provide tax file numbers because they do not have them since they are working under false names will be taxed at source. This means that the Australian Taxation Office will not have to divert hundreds or even thousands of people, computer time and heaven knows what in trying to chase employees who may be working under two or three names. All that bureaucratic nonsense will be cast aside, as will the collection of so much information. It will be simple now. If someone is working under a false name, his or her tax will be deducted at source at the maximum rate. We have shown the Government how to proceed without huge bureaucratic waste; without huge intrusions into the privacy of Australians, and that is why I say we have dramatically changed this legislation.

What we are doing involves raising just about the same amount of tax. There could be some leakage, but there will be very little. It may well be that the tax is raised earlier than it would have been under the Government's incompetent and intrusive system, because those taxpayers who prefer not to reveal their tax file numbers and have the tax withheld at source will be giving the Government a free loan for a while, although those people who pay provisional tax will not be greatly disadvantaged because their withholding tax could no doubt be applied against their provisional tax.

It is true that some people may still try to cheat, but they will have very little chance of getting away with it. One could find a situation where a taxpayer who did not give a tax file number put in his tax return and, having had the tax deducted at the full rate, claimed a return of the withholding tax, but a false declaration of that kind could be so easy for the Australian Taxation Office to chase that there would be very little prospect of it happening. When a person applies for a rebate, having not quoted a tax file number and having been taxed at the maximum rate, he is almost signalling to the Tax Office that it should at least make a quick check to ensure that the rebate being claimed is correct. So the legislation targets a matching capacity which, I might say, the Tax Office has had for a long time and has simply chosen not to use.

One of the reasons we are getting this kind of legislation, particularly as it was in its original form, is that the Tax Office has taken a conscious decision not to use the information that every Australian taxpayer is required to provide on his or her tax return. That may startle a lot of Australian taxpayers, but when people fill in their tax forms and those who have investments quote their investments and where they come from, that information is ignored by the Tax Office except for an occasional spot audit. The only thing that is taken into account is the total. Clearly, if the Commissioner of Taxation chose, he could feed all the information taxpayers provide into his computer, match it against the list of dividends paid by the companies that are named on the tax returns and find the names of people who have not filed tax returns. Facilities are available to the Commissioner of Taxation to do all this anyway. The reason it is not being done is that it is too expensive, and I accept that.

The Liberal Party has strongly taken the view that it does not want to see excessive spending on bureaucratic devices and that there must be a cost benefit. One of our objections to the Government's initial tax file number proposal was that it was not cost effective in collecting the tax. Frankly, we do not believe that the figures that have been delivered to us are accurate. In fact, the Tax Commissioner has almost an unenviable record of being wrong in his forecasts about what various taxes will provide. So we did not believe that it would be cost effective to have a big bureaucracy. This will be avoided by using the withholding tax system that we have provided for.

This legislation does not effectively eliminate tax fraud because the black economy-the cash economy of $3,000m or so-will not be touched one bit by the legislation. What we have fixed up is a peripheral bit of reform-because we have certainly reformed the legislation. The other requirement we had was that the legislation should not unreasonably intrude upon personal privacy and civil liberties. On those three scores we felt that the original legislation was simply defective. It did not effectively eliminate tax fraud; it was not cost effective in so doing-certainly on no evidence that the Commissioner gave-and it did intrude unreasonably upon personal privacy. We have fixed up those criteria so that tax fraud will now be eliminated in terms of employees' and investment income by use of the withholding tax if people choose not to provide their tax file numbers. It is cost effective because it will prevent the enormous growth of the bureaucracy prying into taxpayers' personal information, as would have been the case under the tax file number arrangements as originally proposed. We made certain that it did not unreasonably intrude upon personal privacy and civil liberties by our massive privacy legislation amendments.

I wish to make it clear that the Government is pretending that the Opposition's amendments are only minor, that they are of little consequence. When we made our first request for an amendment some months ago, which the Government accepted-this was when there was a major change-we said, `You cannot have those terrible penalties for not providing a tax file number'. The Government agreed and said, `Okay, we accept your position that there should be a withholding tax if you do not provide your tax file number'. I stress that in the Bill that recently came into this place it was illegal, according to this Government, for a bank or investment institution not to get a tax file number. A bank or investment body was required under the law to get that tax file number. It is all very well the Government saying, `That did not matter because the only penalty was that the taxpayer had to pay withholding tax'. Can anyone see banks and investment companies happily breaking the tax law even though there was no penalty against them? Obviously they would have demanded from people their tax file number or else refused to open their accounts. What we have done has made this totally optional.

Our dramatic changes to this legislation not only have made this workable and made it certain that tax cheats will be caught but also have got rid of Labor's hidden agenda. We have got rid of its capacity to use the tax file number as a universal identifier. We have done the right thing by Australians. By stopping those tax cheats, those pay-as-you-earn taxpayers who have formed the bulk of the Australian population will be grateful to us not only for protecting their privacy but also for ensuring that this legislation will collect revenue from tax cheats without being intrusive.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Maguire Sen G.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —We are debating the Taxation Laws Amendment (Tax File Numbers) Bill 1988 and the Privacy Bill 1988. As a Government senator I support this very important taxation legislation. There has already been extensive public debate and negotiation on this particular matter. This is an indication of the importance of the legislation. The extent of public concern, especially regarding civil liberties and the right to privacy, has been noted by the Government and absorbed into the legislation for the tax file number. The particular legislation we are debating is the culmination of countless hours of hard work, fine tuning, redrafting and ensuring that all concerns expressed in the community have been met adequately. I would like to congratulate the Minister for Justice, Senator Tate, as the Acting Attorney-General, for his efforts in this particular field, particularly in relation to the question of privacy. I would also like to commend the Opposition for its constructive input on this occasion and the bipartisan approach it finally adopted in respect of the tax file number system.

SPEECH.PARA: In the wake of the defunct Australia Card proposal this legislation has generated confusion, scepticism and even hysteria in the Australian community. Initially allegations were made by some members of the public and by the Opposition that this legislation would be a back door method of obtaining a national identification card system. But the Government has repeatedly stated that this is not the case nor was it ever meant to be a national ID system. There is to be no card. There is to be no requirement to carry or even quote the tax file number. At all times the Government has given careful regard to civil liberties and privacy issues whilst looking at this particular legislation. In the past the Australian Taxation Office has been scrupulous about protecting the private information of taxpayers made available to it. The safeguards that are already in place-those that were there beforehand-are very stringent. They are sufficient to ensure the integrity of the tax file number and to protect the rights of the Australian people. However, the new safeguards for this legislation will become even more stringent. There will be severe penalties for abuse or breach of confidentiality. There will be new privacy provisions. These will provide maximum protection of people's rights to privacy in the Australian community. I believe that these new safeguards will meet community concerns about interferences with privacy.

The legislation will not give the Australian Taxation Office more information than it presently obtains under existing laws. It will not involve a new data base. It is simply a logical extension of a system already established and in operation. Tax file numbers have been used by the Australian Office since the 1930s. The majority of Australian taxpayers already have one. The principal aim of the new legislation is to enable the Tax Office to more easily match information it already receives from employers and financial institutions with the actual details displayed by individuals in their tax returns. In that way it will help ensure that assessable income is declared to the taxation authorities. The current reliance on matching names and addresses of taxpayers on their tax returns with the names and addresses applied by financial institutions is ineffective, inefficient and full of holes. For example, more than four million reports of interest earned cannot be matched by the Tax Office each year.

I would like to refer to some allegations which have been made to me as a senator for South Australia by a tax agent in my State who is in favour of the upgraded system. He came to me to ensure that we go ahead with it. In his professional capacity he recently had a client in his office in South Australia who asked him to do his tax return. When the tax agent said, `Fine, I will do your return, this is my fee', the person pulled out not one but six different tax file numbers. This one individual in a tax agent's office in South Australia produced six different tax file numbers and asked the tax agent to do his tax returns for him. This is a stunning case of what has been going on under the existing system where fraudulent names are presumably attached to particular tax file numbers. In all probability in this particular case five numbers were in false names.

I am sure you would agree, Madam Acting Deputy President, as would most honourable senators, that this sort of behaviour is completely antisocial, criminal and cheating on the rest of the community. When looking at that particular individual who had six different tax file numbers-that is, the first $5,100 of income which is exempt from tax-and assuming a 40c in the dollar tax rate, which is a conservative assumption, being applied to that $5,100 of income then that particular individual was saving a minimum of $2,000 per annum on every fraudulent name. Presumably, with five fraudulent names he has picked up a cool $10,000 otherwise payable by him and dumped it onto the majority of honest taxpayers in the Australian community.

My constituent, the tax agent, refused to proceed with this particular gentleman's tax return. He showed him the door. In conveying to me his concern about this matter he pointed out that he had people in his office in Adelaide in the past with three or four different tax file numbers. This apparently is a fairly common occurrence in the community. It was nothing new to him to see somebody with three or four different tax file numbers. He felt that the situation was totally outrageous. As most honourable senators would agree there are cheats out there who are ripping off others in the community. They are not paying for vital public services. After all that is what taxation is about. It is not money that is given to the Government. It is a way of paying for vital public services such as roads, hospitals and schools. These people who are not paying their tax are simply preying on the rest of the community and forcing other members of the community to pay for the provision of these vitally important public services.

A recent investigation of the cleaning industry, an industry with many casual after hours employees, by the Tax Office at Chatswood in Sydney gives some idea of the problems faced by the current tax file numbering system. A random check of five cleaning contractors in the industry revealed that an average of 68 per cent of group certificates issued, over two-thirds, were not claimed for tax returns. A total of 3,468 group certificates were not lodged. Most were found, on investigation, to include false names and addresses. In this way a substantial sum of income tax revenue is being lost each year to the detriment of honest taxpayers. The majority of people-honest taxpayers-are being ripped off by these cheats and forced to pick up the bill for the payment of important public services. It is estimated that in the next decade some $2,000m will be picked up by this legislation-and that is a conservative estimate. That will ease considerably the burden on ordinary taxpayers and will consolidate the underlying objectives of this Government's tax reforms.

The legislation is not intended to increase the total taxation burden in the community, but to ensure that it is more fairly and more equitably borne by taxpayers. These measures will further broaden the tax base, and the Government has given an unequivocal commitment that all revenue raised will go to reducing personal income tax. The next instalment of those reductions will occur probably around the middle of next year. I am sure that the majority of Australians who are pay as you earn taxpayers will welcome these income tax cuts and I am sure there will be substantial reductions in tax which will lead to significant increases in the disposable incomes of taxpayers.

As a result of the legislation it will be a lot harder for tax cheats to continue to leach off honest taxpayers in the community. The upgrading of the tax file system will be a major deterrent to tax evaders. An employee who chooses not to provide a tax file number will be taxed at the top marginal tax rate of 49c in the dollar, plus the Medicare levy. The individual who chooses that course of action will receive a refund only when submitting a return at the end of the financial year. It is unfortunate that such stringent measures are necessary to deter tax evasion in the community. It is unfortunate that many people in our society consider that cheating the tax system is fair game. They see it as cheating the Government and do not regard it as cheating their neighbours-which it is.

People working under false names and welfare fraud have become all too common in the community. This new system of upgraded tax file numbers will make those devices harder. Anybody starting a new job or applying for unemployment or sickness benefits will be asked to quote their tax file number or, if they choose, will initially pay tax at the highest marginal rate, plus Medicare levy, and seek to obtain a refund at the end of the financial year. The tax file number will not have to be used by those persons receiving age or other social security and Veterans' Affairs pensions and benefits. Children under 16 who do not earn enough income to have tax taken out of their pay will not have to quote the tax file number.

The upgraded tax file number legislation builds on the unprecedented tax reforms this Government has undertaken since coming into office. Under the Hawke Labor Government reforms of the Australian taxation system, and the personal taxation system in particular, have been unprecedented in Federal history. The Hawke Government has continually demonstrated that it is willing to place tax reform on the political agenda and to make substantial and long overdue reforms to the tax system. For too long successive governments have left tax reforms in the too hard basket. The state of affairs we inherited in 1983 was that for the extraordinarily wealthy income tax had become voluntary. I understand that some members in the legal profession in my home State arranged their affairs at that time to pay the tax they thought was fair. They did not pay the tax that was required of them, but arranged their affairs and determined what they thought they should allocate to pay for vital public services in the community. Substantially we have stopped that sort of behaviour in the community. The Liberal Opposition knew that it had to be done, and yet failed to do so in government. The Liberals knew that reform was urgent. They knew that pay as you earn taxpayers were bearing the burden of tax avoidance schemes designed for and only accessible to the very rich. Instead of reform, Mr Howard, as the then Liberal Treasurer, let tax avoidance and evasion become a national scandal and a permanent disgrace to the coalition parties.

When in office Mr Howard ignored tax evaders and burdened honest taxpayers with an increasing share of the Australian tax burden. Instead of killing tax avoidance, the coalition government up to 1982-83 nurtured it. In fact, the tax avoidance industry was the only growth industry in the dying days of the Fraser Liberal Government. The economy stagnated, but the tax avoidance industry surged further and further ahead. Mr Commissioner Costigan said in the first report of the Royal Commission on the Activities of the Federated Ship Painters and Dockers Union in 1982 that the tax avoidance industry was the fastest growing industry in Australia.

Despite the coalition Government's professed concern to crack down on evasion and fraud, that Government did the opposite. The truth is that the Liberal and National parties have a shameful record of tax reform. In government they failed to introduce any reforms to the tax system at all. They presided over the most scandalous deterioration of the tax system ever. The former Treasurer never brought a tax reform package to this Parliament. All he achieved was an increase in taxes or the imposition of more taxes. That Government did not reduce taxes as the Hawke Government has done. I refer to the subject of sales tax, which points to Liberal priorities when that party is in government. In Mr Howard's last two Budgets, in 1981 and 1982, he increased sales tax rates across the board by 2.5 per cent. The result was a 66 per cent increase in revenues collected from sales tax-a massive rise in tax on commodities in just two Budgets. No wonder inflation surged ahead in the early 1980s, because of the boost to prices as a result of the sales tax levied by the then Federal Government. All that the then Government achieved was an increase in taxes and the imposition of more taxes. The 1978 Budget introduced by Mr Howard taxed the South Australian brandy industry to the brink by increasing brandy excise by 80 per cent in that one Budget, his first. Under the Fraser coalition the top marginal rate of tax was 60c in the dollar. Under the Hawke Labor Government the top marginal tax rate has fallen to 49c in the dollar. Under Mr Howard the lowest marginal tax rate in any tax bracket was 30c in the dollar. As a result of Labor's tax package the bottom rate is now 24c in the dollar.

The Liberals still have the cheek in the community, in the face of that evidence and of those reductions in marginal tax rates, to talk about the need for incentive in the community. Liberal Party rhetoric about tax cuts was highlighted by broken election promises and increased taxes. I well recall the fistful of dollars in the 1977 election, which were taken back within months of that Government's re-election. In the very next Budget, in 1978, not only were those so-called tax cuts taken back, but Mr Howard and the Liberals, who now run around the country parading themselves as the friends of the elderly, took away pensioners' cost of living rises. Despite the fact that they now say that they support the aged and the elderly in this community, in 1978 when Mr Howard was Treasurer and brought in his first Budget he suspended cost of living rises for the aged on their pensions for 12 months. That is the record of people opposite when they get into government.

I am sure that the Liberal's speakers' notes come from their secretariat in Barton because they all seem to be saying the same thing. From what I have heard Senator Parer, Senator Panizza, Senator Puplick and Senator Messner say, my name seems to figure prominently in the speakers' notes. Their claim that Labor is a high-tax government is nonsensical. When one boils it down one has to look at the expenditure side of the Budget, the revenue side of the Budget and the Budget deficit. To look at this claim we must go back to the last Budget that Mr Howard brought in in 1982-83 and its outcome. Despite the claim by honourable senators opposite that the Australian Labor Party is a high-tax party, we find that Mr Howard took the easy road. He did not want to do anything about taxation. He took the easy road and ran up a massive Budget deficit. That is what those opposite prefer to do. In 1982-83 they had a Budget deficit outcome equivalent to 2.7 per cent of Australia's gross domestic product. Their record was a Budget deficit equivalent to 2.7 per cent of this country's national income. They were not prepared to do anything about covering their expenditures by their revenues. They took the easy way out-the Liberal way out-which is to run up massive Budget deficits.

This year's Budget Papers show very clearly that despite the bleatings on Monday night by Senator Panizza and Senator Parer, who attacked me, and the bleatings today by Senator Puplick and Senator Messner, those people in government were not prepared to do anything to make sure that government expenditures were covered by revenues. They were prepared to run up deficits. That was their record. In 1982-83, the last financial year in which the Liberals were in government in this country, they left a Budget deficit equivalent to 2.7 per cent of gross domestic product. Let us not have any more nonsense about Labor being a high-tax government. Those opposite ran up very high expenditures. They were not prepared to fund those expenditures by revenues and they left a legacy of substantial Budget deficits. The Budget Papers show very clearly that they were totally irresponsible financially. They were not prepared to do anything about taxes. They took the easy road by running up very large Budget deficits and simply left it to other governments to clean up.

TALK.START.PARA: —Where was John Stone?

—I do not know. I gather that he was over the road at, I think it is called, Treasury Place-the building across the way where the Department of the Treasury is headquartered. Of course, Mr Stone would have been the Secretary to the Treasury at that time, advising the Government. The Liberals' record in Government leaves them with no credibility at all on taxation. While in opposition for 5 1/2 years-they are looking at another 1 1/2 years in opposition at least-they have repeatedly opposed every major measure taken by the Hawke Labor Government against tax avoidance and evasion. Despite all the evidence that it was an outrageous rort, they said that the restaurant industry in Australia would be on its knees and that the end of the world as we knew it was nigh. In effect, what they were really saying was that people would stop eating. That is what their arguments really boiled down to. SPEECH.PARA: What happened as a result of that crackdown? We saved honest Australian taxpayers substantial revenues. I am not talking about $3m or $33m: I am talking about $330m which will be gained every financial year simply by abolishing the rort that those opposite still seem to defend to this day. Would they bring back the free lunch and take away $330m from government revenue? I will be waiting to see what those people do when the next election comes up.

I am pleased to see that the Opposition has decided to support this legislation. But, of course, it would have lost even more credibility in the Australian community and would have been labelled as being hypocritical had it not done so. It has been brought to my attention that the Western Australian Division of the Liberal Party, which is in your State, Madam Acting Deputy President, still opposes the legislation. While Mr Howard and the Opposition front bench support the legislation to introduce an upgraded tax file number in the tax system, the Western Australian Division of the Liberal Party, populated as it is by nouveau riche speculators and other sorts, still opposes it. I have before me a letter from the Western Australian Division of the Young Liberal Movement of Australia signed by Mr Simon Ehrenfeld to a person who is, presumably, a Liberal Party member of parliament. It begins `Dear James'. I am not sure whether that means Mr James Porter: I do not know whom it is addressed to. The letter states:
The tax file numbering proposition being put forward, we feel, is totally repugnant to the people you claim to represent.
So obviously it was sent to a member of parliament. To continue:

Our policy of opposition to this threat has been unanimously supported by the Liberal Party's Western Australian Division, who further supported the view that the proposal represents a gross invasion of civil liberties.

That letter is not old; it is not something from the dark ages. It is dated 26 October 1988, only two weeks ago. That is a further indication of the cracks and divisions in the coalition and the Liberal Party in Australia. While we have a united Labor Government bringing in reforming legislation of this sort, and while Mr Howard and his front bench are on the record as supporting the legislation to introduce an upgraded tax file number system in Australia, the Western Australian Division of the Young Liberal Movement, through Mr Simon Ehrenfeld, the Administrative Director of the Western Australian Division, says that the legislation is repugnant. Senator Crichton-Browne is a member of the Western Australian Division and I will be listening with great interest to what he says about the legislation in this debate. I notice that he is on the speakers' list. But one part of this hopelessly divided Liberal Party is still taking a position opposite to that taken by its leadership and front bench.
The Hawke Government is doing exactly what was commended by the Leader of the Opposition, Mr Howard, on 7 October 1987, when he said:
We will support moves to upgrade the tax file numbering system.

Of course, in recent times various parliamentary committees have also recommended the introduction of a high integrity tax file numbering system. I believe that an upgraded tax file number should receive widespread community support in Australia. Most Australians are fed up with and resentful of the unfairness associated with the substantial tax avoidance by a minority in this community. The only group which has any reason to fear the tax file system is that group which has exploited and cheated the system through avoidance and evasion at the expense of the vast majority of honest taxpayers. Honest citizens have nothing to fear-in fact, they have much to gain-from this legislation. Once again under the Hawke Labor Government, the number is up for the tax bludgers in the Australian community. This time we are to have an upgraded tax file number. The sooner we get it into operation the better it will be for the majority-the honest taxpayers of Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs and I ask: Why has the Government chosen to abdicate its responsibility to Aboriginal Australians by instituting a series of in-house inquiries into the administration of Aboriginal affairs which will involve no community participation? How will the Minister guarantee that opportunities are available to persons wishing to contribute when the routine procedures of the Auditor-General, the Public Service Commissioner, the Department of Finance and the special investigator, Mr Menzies, discourage involvement by people outside the Government?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —First of all, I wish to say very firmly and adamantly, if that is not a tautology, that the Government has not abdicated its responsibilities in relation to these matters. Indeed, both the Prime Minister and the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs have said, right from the beginning of this parliamentary inquisition into the affairs of the portfolio and particularly into allegations of mismanagement and maladministration, that no stone would be left unturned in uncovering the facts to enable the Parliament to make its proper assessment of the validity of the allegations that have been made. As Senator Tambling would know, the hundreds of questions he provided in writing, the several hundred with which he supplemented those written questions when he questioned, face to face as it were, officials of the Department and the Aboriginal Development Commission at Estimates Committee E, further supplemented by his very many questions that were incorporated for further answer, went largely to the allegations of maladministration and mismanagement. ANSWER.PARA: So it is very proper that the Government should respond in the way in which it has, namely, to ask the Auditor-General not only to look at the Aboriginal Development Commission but also to extend his inquiries into the Department and for the Commissioner of the Public Service also to conduct an inquiry. At the end of the day, if those inquiries are judged by Mr Menzies to require supplementation, he will undertake those further inquiries which, as I have said, will give the fullest and most complete picture possible to Government for the compiling of a report to be made available to the Parliament. I believe that those persons who can best assist these inquiries will feel no difficulty about contacting the Auditor-General, or Mr Menzies if it comes to that, as indeed they have done on past occasions when, for example, Mr Menzies has conducted other inquiries. TALK.START.PARA: —I ask a supplementary question, Mr President. ANSWER.PARA: As to the gales of synthetic indignation that we have been hearing from Mr Toohey this morning, and which have been partially repeated by his hitherto not known as accolytes on the front bench opposite, I would be prepared to take those public protestations a little bit more seriously if Mr Toohey was prepared to swear as follows: that he has no previously unpublished material in his possession or control purporting to identify ASIS personnel, areas of operation or activities, and that he has no plans to publish such material in a subsequent edition to The Eye or through any other avenue.

It is not possible for me to make any comment on the substantive matters involved in this case, not least because it is still before the court. Neither I nor the Government make any apology whatsoever for acting as we see fit in the national interest, and we will continue to so act in this matter as elsewhere.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: AUSTRALIAN NUCLEAR SCIENCE AND TECHNOLOGY ORGANISATION REPRESENTATIVE

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce. First, is the Minister aware that the Australian Nuclear Science and Technology Organisation (ANSTO) withdrew its representative Gil Greenslade from hearing in camera evidence given to the Senate Standing Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade by the Department of Defence on nuclear weapons handling? Secondly, is the Minister aware that this was done because of ANSTO's interpretation of the limitations on the areas of its research under section 5 (2) of the Australian Nuclear Science and Technology Organisation Act? Thirdly, is the Minister aware that when ANSTO sought to confirm its interpretation by seeking the advice of the Attorney-General, it was surprised to find that his interpretation was that Gil Greenslade could in fact offer advice on nuclear weapons accidents? Finally, is the Minister aware that Gil Greenslade was detached from ANSTO to become technical adviser to the Senate Standing Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade? If so, is this why he could offer advice on nuclear weapons notwithstanding section 5 (2) of the Act?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Dunn has asked me a number of questions regarding the involvement of Mr Greenslade as an officer of the Australian Nuclear Science and Technology Organisation in the Senate committees and elsewhere. The answer to the questions, as they have been directed to me, is firstly, yes. I am aware that Mr Greenslade, who has acted as special adviser to the Committee for some hearings, was withdrawn on 17 June 1988 from an in camera hearing of the Senate inquiry dealing with nuclear weapons issues. An ANSTO officer explained that the ANSTO board considered that it did not want ANSTO officers involved in the safety assessment of nuclear weapons capable ships. The answer to the second part of the question as to the interpretation of the existing Act is yes; I am aware that this was done because of the ANSTO board's view that such involvement may be contrary to section 5 (2) of the ANSTO Act.

ANSWER.PARA: Thirdly, the advice received from the Attorney-General's Department was that the organisation would not be in breach of the Act. That was contrary to the view of the Board. The Chairman of the Committee has provided a written assurance that the duties of the specialist adviser do not constitute research or development into nuclear weapons. The Government would view very seriously any such work being undertaken. Finally, Mr Greenslade has been seconded for short periods to act as special adviser to the Committee. ANSTO, including Mr Greenslade, has no competence on nuclear weapons design, storage or safety but has provided considerable technical assistance to the Committee. It is considered that in relation to the provision of assistance on nuclear weapons or other nuclear explosive devices ANSTO's competence is limited to the dispersion and health consequences of nuclear materials and does not include the safety of or accident probability associated with such devices.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Attorney-General. Why is the Government refusing to support an inquiry that will go beyond merely pursuing what can be obtained from creditors? Is there no other public interest involved, including the breach of law that is within the legal domain of the NCSC?
—What breach of law?
—That is what we are asking him to tell us about.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Attorney-General has declined-not that he was ever formally asked; it was merely by way of matters raised in the House of Representatives and this chamber-to exercise his power under the Companies Code to order a special investigation into the affairs of Rothwells. I believe I indicated that, given the present canons of ministerial responsibility into the activities of the National Companies and Securities Commission and its being under the governance of the Ministerial Council; the far preferable course-and, as I believe it, the adequate course-is that the National Companies and Securities Commission report to the Ministerial Council on its investigations. I believe that that can be achieved.

ANSWER.PARA: Indeed, the National Companies and Securities Commission, as I have already reported to the Senate, is undertaking such investigations and has never indicated to the Ministerial Council, as far as I am aware-certainly not to the Attorney-General of the Commonwealth-that its powers and its capacities and its role in this matter are in any way inadequate or circumscribed in a way which would not enable it to discharge the responsibilities that the statutes place upon it. I believe that the present arrangements will allow the various matters to do with Rothwells Ltd and the role of the provisional liquidators and the role of the NCSC to be adequately dealt with under the law.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. How can the Minister be so certain, in the circumstances, that no laws have been broken? Indeed, can he assure the Senate that there is not a real possibility that such has occurred? He should be making all possible effort to ensure that an investigation does occur to satisfy the public of Western Australia and Australia.

—I have confidence in Mr Bosch, the National Companies and Securities Commission and its capacity in these matters. In the absence of any indication by Mr Bosch that his powers are inadequate or circumscribed or that he is not able to achieve the task, I believe the present course will prove to be adequate.

—I direct my question to the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade. Following media reports of a savage earthquake in southern China where, according to preliminary estimates, at least 600 people have been killed, thousands more injured and countless numbers rendered homeless, I ask the Minister: Is the Australian Government monitoring the situation with a view to providing financial or other aid, particularly in the area of medical supplies, which clearly will be needed as a matter of urgency in those remote areas?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government has been saddened, as I am sure will all members of Parliament, to learn of the devastation caused by a very large earthquake, measured at some 7.6 on the Richter scale, which has hit in Yunnan Province in southern China, near the Burmese border. Reports now indicate that over 900 people have been killed and many more injured. Almost all the houses in the epicentre-that is, in the Lancang and Menglian counties-are believed to have been destroyed. The Government is closely monitoring the situation and reports have been received from the Australian mission in Beijing. Further reports are also expected shortly from United Nations agencies. The Government is concerned that the area affected is a remote region and that the initial reports may in fact have understated the number of casualties.

ANSWER.PARA: On behalf of the people of Australia, the Government wishes to express its very sincere sympathy to the Chinese Government and condolences to the Chinese people for the loss of life and damage to property arising from this tragedy. We understand that a major relief effort has been mounted by the Chinese authorities. As in the past, the Australian Government stands ready to provide assistance to the victims of the earthquake in the event of an appeal for such assistance. China does not always seek external assistance for victims of natural disasters. Australia needs to remain sensitive to the wishes of the Chinese and, in particular, to their strong feelings of self-reliance, but if a request for assistance is made we shall certainly give it urgent and sympathetic consideration.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Consumer Affairs and follows the question he was unable to answer last Friday on the significance of the status as an authorised trustee investment of Rothwells Ltd. As a preface to the question I advise the Senate that the Minister very kindly sent me some documents from his Department following that question, including a booklet called The Retiring Consumer, which gives the valuable advice that before one decides on an investment one needs to know certain information. One of the things one needs to know is the security of investment. I thank the Minister for that helpful advice. I ask the Minister: Has he examined the role of the Western Australian Government, both as the grantor of the status of an authorised trustee investment to Rothwells Ltd and as a one-time guarantor of Rothwells? So that the Minister does not think this is some theoretical matter, I ask him whether he has seen the report on the front page of the West Australian newspaper last Friday that a mother and daughter face the loss of their life savings. The report states:

QUESTION.PARA: . . . they felt they typified the small investor the State Government had said so many times it would protect.

I blame the State Government for letting us down . . . I would not have placed my money with the Bank if the Government and a Who's Who of the business world had not made so much publicity about supporting it through thick and thin.

I ask the Minister: Has he examined this matter? If he has, what are his conclusions? If he has not, will he examine it and advise the Senate whether the protection that is afforded by the description `authorised trustee investment' is adequate, and whether some change should be made, for example, whether uniform standards should be applied?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have not seen last Friday's West Australian newspaper. Having had this question raised with me last week, I thought it was important to follow it up. As Senator Chaney would very well understand, the whole question of authorised trustee investments and the designation thereof comes very much under State law. Across the country we have different requirements as to the criteria a company has to meet before that company can, under State regimes, be classified as an authorised trustee investment fund, which, as Senator Chaney would know, then makes it eligible for investment by trust funds. As I said, the regime is under the State legislation and the criteria are very much part of State legislation.

ANSWER.PARA: If we were to look at the applicable provisions that pertain to this matter, we would find that in Western Australia to be an authorised trust fund a particular company has to have a paid up capital of $5m and a record of paying dividends in each of the 15 preceding years. If this is compared with other States such as Victoria and New South Wales, it will be found that the requirements there are stricter. For instance, in Victoria the requirement is for a paid up capital of $50m, a five year dividend record and an appropriate asset/liability ratio. In New South Wales, a high credit rating is also needed.

In going back to find out about these matters, I discovered that Western Australia has the most liberal laws in this area. They were introduced in 1978-under, I believe, the Government of which Senator Chaney was a supporter.

TALK.START.PARA: —Sir Charles Court.

—The Sir Charles Court Government. Having responded to that particular part of Senator Chaney's point, the other part of the matter that we should all recognise is the point that was made very explicitly today in the Bulletin by Glenda Korporaal and it is one that I think Senator Chaney should understand as well. That is that there is a requirement that a trustee obtain proper advice before investing in such a company. The point that was made in the Bulletin this morning, and the point that I wish to stress now, is that trustees cannot absolve themselves of responsibility on the basis of meeting the criterion because there is still a continuing obligation that they have to meet.

ANSWER.PARA: I believe that other aspects of Senator Chaney's question have been answered, albeit perhaps indirectly, by Senator Tate in answer to other questions this afternoon.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I thank the Minister for the fact that since Friday he has taken the trouble to find out something about the subject matter. I now ask him: Has he made any inquiry, as part of the work he has done, on the method which was used by Rothwells Ltd to obtain the status of an authorised trustee investment? If he has not, will he please do so, and report to the Senate? Following his comment about the obligation on trustees to get advice, can I remind him of that part of the question which he ignored, which was referred to in the quote I gave from the depositor who is so hurt about the Western Australian Government's role? What about the Western Australian Government's role in giving advice effectively on this matter, in standing as a guarantor behind the bank for a good deal of the last year, and giving the impression that this was a safe investment? Has he made any examination of the role of the Western Australian Government in that respect?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is quite strange getting these sorts of questions from Senator Chaney. They are based on a premise that maybe something was done unusually in terms of accreditation of Rothwells. If Senator Chaney is suggesting that, I would like to get some evidence as to what that unusual aspect was. As I said to the honourable senator, there are criteria that are laid down by State legislation. Even though he makes the presumption that something unusual was done, he does not actually claim that in terms of getting that authorisation something unusual or improper was done. If he has any information on that, then that might warrant some need to check out the method of obtaining accreditation.

ANSWER.PARA: In terms of the Western Australian Government's role-cheap shots were made last week about people being lawyers and not being up to scratch in that respect-I am sure that Senator Chaney and others in the Senate would know that if advice was given and if guarantees applied, then the normal course of law would apply and people who have been damaged because of, say, a lack of responsible behaviour or in the presence of negligence, have their rights under the existing law. That is pretty basic. I should have thought that that would have obviated the need for the honourable senator to ask such a cheap supplementary question.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Resources. I refer to the public debate taking place on the tax on gold. Is there a gold tax applying anywhere in Australia? If so, where and in what form? Further, is the Leader of the Opposition, Mr Howard, on the public record as being opposed to a tax on gold production?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —One of the Orwellian newspeak efforts by the gold lobby is to label what this Government is doing in extending normal company taxation to the gold industry as a gold tax. It is not a gold tax; it is an extension of the normal company taxation regime. There is a gold tax, however, in Australia, and it is applied in four of the States and the Northern Territory. There is no gold tax operating in Victoria, and there never has been, or in Western Australia, and there never has been. But in New South Wales there is a gold tax, and it is a tax of 4 per cent of the value of production. In Queensland there is a gold tax-2 per cent of the gross proceeds in excess of $30,000 or 5 per cent of net profit above $30,000, whichever is the greater. In South Australia there is a gold tax-2.5 per cent of the value of production. Tasmania has a gold tax as well. Tasmania has a progressive royalty rate with an option for ad valorem or profit-based royalty ranging from 2.5 per cent of revenue or 5 per cent of profits to 3.5 per cent of revenue or 7 per cent of profits. There is also a gold tax in the Northern Territory. It is 1.25 per cent of ex-mine value of the gold or 2.5 per cent of same value in the case of mining on Aboriginal land or reserves. Mines that commenced construction after 30 June 1982 are charged 18 per cent of profit before income tax.

ANSWER.PARA: They are the gold taxes that apply in Australia. They are State or Territory taxes. Western Australia and Victoria do not apply them. The gold lobby has tried to label what this Government is doing in closing off an anomaly and a loophole in the company tax regime. It ought to be clearly understood in the community that that is not a gold tax.

Senator Gietzelt asked me whether I was aware of whether Mr Howard has done any-thing about that. I am aware that Mr Howard, in a video relay to New York investors, indicated support for the Government's position, as have Senator Stone and Mr Peacock previously, but now that they have been rolled in the party room or, more particularly, within their executive, there is a big backdown and a cave-in to the gold lobby in the Liberal Party. I am not aware whether the Leader of the Federal Liberal Party, Mr Howard, has spoken to the Liberal Government of New South Wales and asked it to remove its gold tax or to the National Party Government in Queensland, to the Labor Party in South Australia, to the Tasmanian Liberals, and to that weird creation the Country Liberal Party in the Northern Territory and asked them to remove their gold taxes.

One of the other problems about a gold tax is that many headline writers seize upon it because the lobby has successfully promoted this misrepresentation as a shorthand way of describing what this Government is doing. I am drawn to an article in the West Australian this morning which refers to gold tax, but I am more drawn to the editorial in today's West Australian. In its opening paragraph, it states:

Despite dire predictions from the gold industry and from soothsayers on both sides of the political fence about the impact of a gold tax, there is no valid reason for continuing the industry's tax-free status.

I suggest to headline writers that rather than fall for the ploy of the gold lobby and call what this Government is doing in closing off an anomaly a gold tax, they would be advised to use some other form of words. Perhaps they could call it, `Company tax on gold (at last)'; perhaps they could call it, `Tax anomaly on gold' instead of `gold tax'; perhaps they could call it, `gold exemption' rather than `gold tax'; or perhaps they could say, `Gold companies to be taxed like other companies' instead, or `Gold loophole to be closed off'-rather than continue the Orwellian doublespeak of gold tax that the lobby has so successfully perpetrated.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: AUSTRALIAN BROADCASTING CORPORATION: BROADCASTING OF PARLIAMENT

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Minister for Transport and Communications. I ask: First, is it a fact that the Australian Broadcasting Corporation (ABC) is at present conducting a so-called trial of proposed new arrangements for the broadcasting of the Parliament; secondly, do those new arrangements involve removing the parliamentary broadcasts from the more powerful metropolitan transmitters and relegating them to much less powerful transmitters on different frequencies from those previously employed, and in a less favourable area of the frequency band; thirdly, is the Minister aware that while these new arrangements may not greatly affect the reception of the parliamentary broadcast by people in, and in the near vicinity of, the capital cities, they are effectively depriving much of rural and regional Australia of the capacity to listen to Parliament; and, finally, is this yet another example of the true regard in which the Managing Director of the ABC, Mr David Hill, holds the country people of Australia, and of what this Government really means when it talks of levelling the playing field?

—As honourable senators would be aware, it is the case that an experiment is presently proceeding as a prelude to what will hopefully be a permanent transfer of parliamentary broadcasting away from Radio National. That interim arrangement involves the broadcasting of Parliament on an interim network where the transmission power is significantly less in a number of areas than is the case under the full-scale Radio National network. It needs to be appreciated at the outset that the statutory obligation which Senator Stone's parties in Opposition have endorsed and not contested or sought to expand in the past is a statutory obligation that confines the need to broadcast to the metropolitan areas. Therefore, if Senator Stone cares to think of it as a bonus-I am not sure that I do-the receipt of parliamentary broadcasts in the past in some areas outside the metropolitan has been in the nature of a bonus rather than something that was involved in the statutory obligation. I would have thought that most of the people to whom Senator Stone referred would regard it as a blessed and merciful relief not to have to listen to his dulcet tones, or those of any other member of parliament for that matter, under the new arrangements. If Senator Stone has a view to the contrary, no doubt he will be able and willing to express it at the appropriate time and place.

—I refer the Minister representing the Minister for Administrative Services to allegations made by Senator Bishop immediately prior to the New South Wales State election concerning incidents which she alleged occurred prior to the Castlereagh by-election in that State in 1980. I ask: Has the Minister received any subsequent information with regard to these allegations? What action can the Government take with regard to the original allegations or the subsequent information?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: IMMIGRATION, LOCAL GOVERNMENT AND ETHNIC AFFAIRS

TALK.START.PARA: —Yesterday I had passed on to me a letter from the spouse of one of the candidates-I think the successful candidate-in the Castlereagh by-election, one Mrs Jean Curran. I will very briefly quote from that letter which says:

ANSWER.PARA: That the allegations were quite unsubstantiated, and were indeed quite ridiculous, was not mentioned.
They were not mentioned by the Press. It continues:

When the new government took office in New South Wales, one would have expected an immediate investigation into such serious allegations, of which the Greiner Government made full use before the election. Nothing happened. The matter was dropped.

Though my husband was quickly identified by the media as the candidate in the Castlereagh by-election and we suffered harassment for 24 hours, that is not the reason why I am seeking a statement from the present Government to set straight the record. I am appalled that an irresponsible and mischievous story was used without the facts being investigated, and that, having served its purpose, it was dropped without any consideration of any damage it had done to innocent people.
I have written to Senator Bishop, but received no answer.
A letter to Mr Greiner elicited an unsatisfactory answer.
The letter concludes:
As I am quite determined to seek from the Senator or Mr Greiner a reason why the story was dropped, I would be grateful for any efforts you may make to help me.

Probably what that brings to mind is that if unsubstantiated allegations are made in this place not only are they made for the purposes of political gain but also there is another side to the story. This particular family has been deeply hurt by those allegations because, obviously, living in that area people ask them about it, or fail to ask about it and just look at them. The allegations also hurt the returning officer who ran that election. The allegations hurt the Federal returning officer who is one of the most diligent officers ever to be employed by the Australian Electoral Commission, who meticulously took off the roll the names of deceased persons. It comes as no surprise to me that in this chamber, two days before the New South Wales State election, these issues were raised and that those who raised them pursued them no further. Not only did they fail to pursue and try to substantiate the allegations before they were made but, having made them, having had their electoral thrill on election day and having overrated their effect, they then dropped the matter and did nothing about it. They did not worry about the people who were hurt by those allegations. What the allegations involved was criminal conspiracy. The Premier of New South Wales and the senator from New South Wales who were involved in those allegations have failed to pursue them in any way whatsoever.

Senator McMullan asked what remedy we have. There is very little remedy. The election was run under State electoral law; our involvement was to provide the rolls. At this stage it would be almost impossible for us to initiate those sorts of inquiries given our limited involvement in it at the time. For the last time I hope, I urge the Premier of New South Wales, I urge that New South Wales senator, to back up those allegations, to provide a proper inquiry and to clear the names of people such as Mrs Curran who have been so viciously smeared.

—I refer the Minister for Finance to a personal explanation made yesterday afternoon by Senator Chaney following the Minister's use of quotations from an article written by Senator Chaney in 1984 in which he referred to the inherent economic irrationality of a tax exemption for income derived from the mining of gold. Senator Chaney in his defence quoted Sir Charles Court as having once suggested that not all problems were solved by logic. —Mr President, I rise on a point of order. The question is obviously quite ridiculous. It is just another invitation for the Minister to give a general tirade of abuse. It also misquotes the piece in the article to which I referred. I suggest that the question be ruled out of order.
—Order! I ask the Minister to confine himself to those parts of the question which relate to his portfolio.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —They certainly do, Mr President. They relate to the financial consequences to the Commonwealth of a decision made by Sir Charles Court that was not trammelled by logic. ANSWER.PARA: The greatest demonstration of the eclipse of economic logic by megalomania was the $7 billion to which Sir Charles Court and the previous Liberal Government of Western Australia exposed Western Australian taxpayers under the misconceived take-or-pay contract in negotiations for the North West Shelf gas. There were many defects in the arrangements in that take-or-pay contract which Sir Charles Court instructed the State Electricity Commissioners to sign, but the financial implications to the Commonwealth were as follows: Following exhaustive negotiations in late 1984 and early 1985, in which the then Minister for Resources and Energy, Senator Gareth Evans, was the principal Commonwealth participant, the State Labor Government rescued the situation by negotiating with the Commonwealth and the joint venture partners a three-way pain-sharing agreement which involved, among other things, the Commonwealth Government forgoing nearly $120m worth of royalties, which had the effect of reducing the State Government's maximum exposure from $7 billion to $2 billion. Even with that massive salvage exercise by the State Government, a huge albatross still hangs around the necks of the Western Australian Government and taxpayers as a result of the Court Liberal Government's self-delusions and obsessions.

Finally, I table a letter from the Ministry of Economic Development and Trade in Western Australia dated last month from a Mr McKee, the Co-ordinator General. My final comment on this matter is that the son of the Sir Charles Court who did not allow logic to impede the pursuit of his self-delusion in exposing the State of Western Australia to a debt of $7 billion, subsequently reduced to $2 billion because of negotiations in 1984 and 1985, has the effrontery to try to make the running on the present issue of concern in Western Australia.

—My question is also addressed to the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories. Was the International Union for Biological Sciences `tricked' and `used for political purposes' when it commended the Australian Government for its actions regarding north Queensland's rainforests, as alleged by the Queensland Minister for Environment, Conservation and Tourism, Mr Geoff Muntz, recently?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: ARTS, SPORT, THE ENVIRONMENT, TOURISM AND TERRITORIES

TALK.START.PARA: —I am aware that on a show called Carroll at Seven Mr Muntz made yet another extraordinary allegation-he is pretty good at those, of course; he has trotted them out for a long time-alleging that the International Union for Biological Sciences (IUBS) had been duped-that it had had a resolution put up about which it knew nothing and passed it because it sounded good, but if it had known the facts it would not have passed it. I am not sure how much more insulted a scientist could get, because to be insulted by Geoff Muntz on the basis that one does not know what one is talking about is indeed an insult that one takes to heart.

ANSWER.PARA: I am advised by Dr David Ride, the Vice-President of the IUBS, that, contrary to Mr Muntz's claim, the IUBS resolution was one of seven general resolutions that were passed by that body at its recent meeting. According to its protocol, consideration of such resolutions is allowed. The resolution and the proposal for listing as well as Queensland's counter proposal and the arguments which Queensland had advanced were circulated to all delegates well beforehand. The agenda committee looked at the resolution and put it up for debate in the final plenary session of that assembly.

The fact that the resolution was passed should not surprise anyone. It should be remembered that this body has delegates affiliated to the Royal Society, the United States National Academy of Sciences, the National Research Council of Canada, and the science academies of West Germany and France, and it was attended by leading scientists from all around the world. Mr Muntz and the Queensland Government have a great problem in ever coming to grips with scientists. Every time they try they run into strife. They set up a committee called NORMA, the Northern Rainforest Management Agency, which was to advise them very cleverly of how wrong we were in seeking to nominate the rainforest area. The reason why that body has never endorsed the Queensland Government's announcements is that it never decided what the Queensland Government decided it should decide-because scientists, being what they are, have some integrity. I only wish Queensland politicians had half as much. The NORMA scientific committee disowned Mr Muntz as soon as he made the announcement. The committee would not wear it. Indeed, several scientists have publicly dissociated themselves from Mr Muntz's statements.

The reality is that a very prestigious scientific body did pass a resolution agreeing with the Commonwealth. So far as scientists are concerned, the members of that body are not the only ones who agree. Over 60 internationally respected Australian and international scientists have written to me already. They include such people as Professor Peter Ashton from Harvard University; Professor Paul Richards from Oxford University and Professor Peter Endress from the University of Zurich, and there are many more. When it comes to scientific evidence, Mr Muntz going on a television program proclaiming that an international body of the distinction of this one did not know what it was talking about is farcical. Mr Muntz will find out in December what the world scientific community thinks when the World Heritage Committee meets. At least a decision at that stage of the game finalises the matter, and even he cannot bring it undone.

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct a question to the Minister representing the Minister for Community Services and Health. It relates to the schedule of pharmaceutical benefits. The Minister will be aware that from 1 August 1988 allergens for the bull ant, the jack jumper ant and the mosquito were removed from the schedule of pharmaceutical benefits, while the allergens for honey bee venom and paper wasp have been left on the list. Will the Minister please find out why people who are allergic to bee stings should be treated preferentially to those who are allergic to jack jumper, bull ant or mosquito bites? Why has this decision been made, taking into account, for example, the fact that, so far as jack jumper and bull ant bites are concerned, there was a $11 vaccine which will now cost more than $100 per injection? Will the Minister accept that this is an unfair discrimination against people who have no control over allergies in relation to those three insects the allergens for which have been removed from the schedule?
—Tell us all you know about jack jumpers.

—I am not sure I know a lot about jack jumpers. I will not enlighten the Senate with my knowledge on that subject, but I will answer the question that Senator Watson has asked. I cannot confirm precisely, because I do not have photographic recall, exactly which drugs were removed from the list at the time Senator Watson specified. I know that a number were removed. The recommendation for which drugs should come off the list was made by a specialist committee on which pharmacists and members of the Australian Medical Association sit. That committee considers that not only are those drugs eligible for coming off the list and should be removed but also that there are also other drugs which are prescribable by doctors for which approval can be obtained and which replace the particular drugs referred to.
