INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —I inform the Senate that I have received the following letter, dated 9 November, from Senator Hill:

INTERJECT.PARA: Pursuant to Standing Order 64, I give notice that today I propose to move-
`That, in the opinion of the Senate, the following is a matter of urgency:

The need to implement the unanimous recommendation of the State Attorneys-General in Darwin on 30 June 1988 that the X-rated video classification should be discontinued and to thereby end the hypocrisy of the Government in claiming a commitment to improving the status of women in Australian society exemplified by their giving priority to criticising the advertising industry for their portrayal of women while declining to take legislative measures to eliminate the exploitation of women in the ACT pornographic video industry.'
More than the number of senators required by the Standing Orders having risen in their places-

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill Sen R.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That, in the opinion of the Senate, the following is a matter of urgency:

The need to implement the unanimous recommendation of the State Attorneys-General in Darwin on 30 June 1988 that the X-rated video classification should be discontinued and to thereby end the hypocrisy of the Government in claiming a commitment to improving the status of women in Australian society exemplified by their giving priority to criticising the advertising industry for their portrayal of women while declining to take legislative measures to eliminate the exploitation of women in the ACT pornographic video industry.

TALK.START.PARA: —Where is Reynolds?

—We are going to talk about the absence of Senator Reynolds from the debate in a moment or two. The refusal of Senator Reynolds to come in here and defend the status of women must set a precedent. But Senator Reynolds is in a particularly difficult position concerning this debate. This urgency motion is all about the hypocrisy of this Government-a government which runs a massive propaganda machine claiming its dedication to improving the status of women. Yet when it comes to the test it condones the demeaning of women through its support for the Australian Capital Territory pornographic video industry, support which it reiterated yesterday. If one is to believe the press there is only one member of the Australian Labor Party, the much beleaguered Attorney-General (Mr Lionel Bowen), who was prepared to get up and put the other side.

SPEECH.PARA: This debate is about a government which will spend tens of thousands of dollars on educating the advertising industry away from sexist portrayals of women and sexual stereotyping yet allows the ACT its jurisdiction-the jurisdiction under its control-to become the pornographic headquarters of Australia with the portrayal and exploitation of women in this most offensive and degrading way. I would suggest-and I am pleased that you are in the chair, Madam Acting Deputy President, and can listen to this debate-that such double standards defy description. It makes a mockery of the Government's claimed support for improving the status of women. It reduces to a farce the operation of a body such as the Office of the Status of Women. This is an office which is not allowed to express an independent point of view-an office which is bound to government policy. In this instance it is government policy to accept the degradation and exploitation of women in this most offensive way.

TALK.START.PARA: —Don't go overboard.

—Senator Button might think that I am going overboard. He accepts the degradation of women. Why did he not get up in the Caucus meeting yesterday and express the counter view? Why did he not express the view of his Attorney-General? He should join with the view that has been expressed by every State Attorney-General around Australia and personally held by the Federal Attorney-General. I remind Senator Button of the resolution in Darwin on 30 June 1988 when the State Attorneys-General unanimously said to the Commonwealth, `We want you to ban X-rated videos not only because of the damage they are doing by demeaning women in the ACT but also, through the mail order business that is run out of the Territory, the damage it is doing throughout Australia'.

SPEECH.PARA: I hope that someone in your Caucus debate yesterday, Madam Acting Deputy President, said that this is the one government which is out of step on this matter in Australia. It is the one government that holds such a critical position because out of the Australian Capital Territory a mail order operation can run and this degradation of women can therefore spread throughout the Commonwealth. Why is the Government not prepared to act in a way consistent with that requested by Attorneys-General from around Australia? I say with some regret that it seems to boil down to the attitude of the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) to women. You might smirk, Madam Acting Deputy President, but I say that with particular regret because the Office of the Status of Women is located in the Prime Minister's office. Senator Reynolds comes in here and says that it is located in the Prime Minister's office because of his deep concern for the status of women in this country. The Prime Minister was not even at the Caucus meeting yesterday when this was done. When he was asked questions about it he responded in an offensive way. But this is what one might expect from this Prime Minister. The Office of the Status of Women is within his Department on the basis that it is supposed to add prestige and strength to the office. But when it comes to the crunch the Prime Minister adds no support for improving the status of women in this country. I wonder that the attitude of the dedicated women who work in that Office is to the realisation that they are but pawns in the Government's game, and that they are used to create a false image. I regard it as very sad. It leads me to the contribution, or non-contribution, of Senator Reynolds in this critically important subject-Senator Reynolds, who is not in the chamber and who refuses to promote the status of women or to put her position or to defend the Government's position or whatever she might want to do in this debate. Yesterday I asked Senator Reynolds:

What is more demeaning to women than the X-rated video industry which thrives in this city with the legislative support of her Government? How can she advocate improvement in the status of women when her Government condones the exploitation of women in this way? When the Government sets such a poor example in matters within its control, how can it expect different standards from others?
In response to that question, Senator Reynolds said:
The important thing to realise when one is standing up for the recognition of the status of women is what women regard as important in the public arena.
That statement is totally meaningless. Senator Reynolds continued:
What women regard as important in the private arena, that is, in the privacy of their own homes and in their relationship with their partners, is entirely a matter for those women.

But we are not talking about what women regard as important in the privacy of their own homes. We are talking of how women are demeaned and exploited by this industry, and how this Government condones that exploitation. Surely Senator Reynolds can see that. One can only presume that she is embarrassed by the Government's position and is not prepared to stand up and support it. I hope that is so, because I have thought in the past that she was genuinely trying to improve the status of women; but I very much regret that she has not had the courage to come in here today and say that that is her goal and that she will stand up against the Government. Certainly one could not say that yesterday's question took Senator Reynolds by surprise, because a similar question was asked by Senator Vanstone almost six months ago. Her answer then was that she would take the matter on notice. That was a simple, straightforward question on the exploitation of women in the Australian Capital Territory through the X-rated video industry, and six months ago Senator Reynolds said that she would need to take the matter on notice. She has been thinking about an answer all that time, and we still have not got it. It is in the too-hard basket.

I say with regret how disappointed I am, as I think women throughout Australia are, that Senator Reynolds is not prepared to stand up on their behalf in this issue. She is not prepared even to participate in this debate, to try to explain the Government's position, or, if she cannot do that, get up and say that she regrets that the Government has made a mistake. That is particularly disappointing, but perhaps what is more important beyond that is that it indicates to the women of Australia just how effective Senator Reynolds is in this area. She has no influence at all on the Prime Minister or on Caucus. If we are to believe the press, she did not even open her mouth in the debate yesterday to defend the position of Australian women. If that is the case-and one can only presume that is so from her refusal to participate in the debate today-that is a great disappointment. If she is not prepared to stand up for women, why does she not acknowledge that she has not that influence and perhaps resign?

TALK.START.PARA: —Have you noted that we have two women speakers out of three?

—If she resigns, Senator Collins, could take over the job, because, as we understand it, Senator Collins led the debate on the other side. He should pick up this brief and perhaps perform better in the interests of Australian women. At least Senator Collins would come in here and have a go, whereas Senator Reynolds is not prepared to come in and have a go. Does Senator Reynolds believe that women have a different view in this matter? We know that the position of the Government is that it responds to public opinion. Yesterday Senator Boswell interjected and said `You are letting Australian womanhood down'. Senator Reynolds said:

SPEECH.PARA: I think it would be best if Senator Boswell were to talk to representatives of women's organisations about this question.

That is exactly what the Opposition will do. Let us look at what this Government has done by taking the example of the advertising industry. The Government spent tens of thousands in taxpayers' money on surveys asking the women what they thought about such advertisements as the Katies' advertisement. Did they regard it as sexist, and were they offended by it? The Government produced a result from that and acted in accordance with it. But does Senator Reynolds ask women what they think of being portrayed in this way by the ACT video industry? Of course not. We will take up that challenge.

TALK.START.PARA: —On a point of order, Madam Acting Deputy President: I would suggest that the honourable senator is quite wrong on that matter. I refer him to the National Agenda for Women, where extensive consultation with women around this country raised this point.
—Order! There is no point of order.

—We look forward to Senator Crowley's contribution to this debate, because she is not doing much for Australian women either. We will write to women's organisations throughout this country and find out their attitude. We will answer Senator Reynolds's questions. We will table all those replies in the Senate whichever way they go. Senator Reynolds is not prepared to ask women's organisations because she knows what the response will be.

SPEECH.PARA: It is a matter of great regret that the Government left its Attorney-General like a shag on a rock yesterday-the only person who was prepared to stand up in the Caucus room and defend the status of women. Why did not the Government, which says that it is so influenced by the union movement, take some notice of the Shop, Distributive and Allied Employees Association? It was probably because 75 per cent of members of that association are women. They lobbied this Government against this industry because their members were so offended by it. But no, the Government did not want to take any notice of that because Senator Collins was so persuasive in debate. We look forward to his contribution in a few moments.

Not only will we find out the attitude of women to this matter, but we will pursue this topic in a private member's Bill. We hope that it will be treated by this chamber with greater respect than was the Bill that was sought to be introduced by the Opposition in the House of Representatives yesterday. When Mr Howard, the Leader of the Opposition, sought to introduce a Bill in terms that a ban be placed on the sale and distribution of X-rated videos and for related purposes, the Government gagged him. That gag was moved by Mr Beazley, the Minister for Defence. When Mr Neil Brown, the honourable member for Menzies, stood up to second the motion, again the Government moved the gag. The Government would not let the Opposition express one word on this subject. That is the way in which this Government operates in the House of Representatives; but it will not work in this chamber. We will bring forward a Bill; we will have this matter debated. We will debate it month in and month out. This Government will respond in the end and will do so before the next election. It knows that women are offended by this subject matter and knows that it is letting the women of Australia down.
I have said that I would be prepared to cut short my contribution to the debate to enable many other senators to participate in this debate-which, I regret to say, will not include Senator Reynolds.

TALK.START.PARA: —Or Senator Bolkus.

—Or Senator Bolkus. As I am reminded of Senator Bolkus, I would say that I contributed to Senator Reynolds's conference on advertising and women. Senator Bolkus was there and spoke. Can Senator Bolkus stand up and talk about protecting the rights of consumers when he is allowing women to be abused in this way? It is another example of confused standards.
—You must not show a woman in a kitchen.

—One must not show a woman in a kitchen because that is sexist advertising, it is a sexual stereotype, but to treat them as sex objects in a filthy industry, to make a trade of the exploitation of women, is legitimate! If that is not double standards, I do not know what double standards are. We will pursue this matter. The Government has to make a choice. Either it has to act in accordance with the resolution of all Attorneys-General in Australia and ban X-rated videos, this filthy business operating out of the Australian Capital Territory-I will put my standards on civil liberties up against those of the Government any day, as I will in terms of its record on the ID card, which showed us what it thought of civil liberties in this country-or dump the hypocrisy and accept that it is legitimate to exploit women in this way. It is particularly depressing to have to raise this matter today, but we will pursue it. We will not let it rest. We know that the Government is very conscious of votes. In the end it will come in here one day and say that it has changed its mind.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Zakharov Sen A.O.

TALK.START.PARA: —I note that the urgency motion is in two parts. Firstly, it refers to the need to implement the unanimous recommendation of the State Attorneys-General and then it goes on to talk about the Government's attitude towards women as exemplified by this issue as compared with advertising. Because of the confusion in the community about what is actually contained in the X-rated classification, I will deal with that part of the motion before coming to the more particular question of a supposed link between X-rated videos and the exploitation of women. At least I think that is what the Opposition is claiming in its motion: the wording is rather confused. I do not know what is meant by the expression `exploitation of women in the ACT pornographic video industry'. To me those words imply that women in the Australian Capital Territory are acting in pornographic videos. I prefer to use the words `explicit sex' or `erotica' because the word `pornographic' is so imprecise and value laden. To my knowledge, the only Australian X-rated film was made years ago and it was not made in Canberra. So I infer that what the motion's framers really meant is that ACT women are in some way exploited by the existence of an industry which hires and sells X-rated videos. I will return to that issue later.

SPEECH.PARA: It cannot be stated too strongly that the unanimous recommendation of the State Attorneys-General in June was based on a lack of knowledge of what is shown in X-rated videos. They are not alone in their ignorance. It is widespread in the community and has been fostered by some people who know better. We have heard from one of them today. I understand that the concern at the Attorneys-General meeting was about violence. X-rated videos are non-violent. I read from the Film Censorship Board's guidelines defining X or extra restricted material:
Material which includes explicit depictions of sexual acts involving adults, but does not include any depiction suggesting coercion or non-consent of any kind.

That is why the Joint Select Committee on Video Material recommended that it be renamed non-violent erotica. That is a far more useful way of describing it in terms that people can understand. The most violent video material which is legally available in this country is that which is classified R. Yet before and after the Attorneys-General meeting we read of interviews with State Ministers-regrettably, of all political parties-who clearly had been wrongly advised and/or had not done their homework because they thought that they had, by recommending the non-availability of X, done something significant to prevent violence. Going by recent statements, many still hold that view. I fear it is because it is easier to look for a single scapegoat, even as in this case an irrelevant one, than to look at matters such as gun laws or the need to provide greater resources to deal with domestic violence. At least one State Attorney-General claimed that the meeting had been responsible for enabling previous classifications to be reviewed by the Film Censorship Board. In fact, that was a recommendation of our Joint Select Committee and the Film Censorship Board, both of which were made before the meeting of Attorneys-General took place.

The then shadow spokesman for the Opposition, Peter Reith, probably contributed to the confusion when he put out a press release earlier this year calling for the banning of material which was already banned, such as depictions of explicit sexual violence. If the Opposition spokesperson was so confused-maybe that is why he is no longer the spokesperson-it is no wonder that his State colleagues were also confused, as were, regrettably, some of my State colleagues. However, the press must also take some of the responsibility for the confusion. Some journalists who rang me after this week's Caucus decision clearly believed that X-rated material contained violence. The difference between them and some top level decision makers is that they were prepared to learn. An example of this confusion was published in the Age newspaper of 15 August-to the credit of the Age it was later corrected-under the headline `43% want X rated videos banned, opinion poll shows'. The question asked in the poll was:
There has been some discussion recently about X rated video cassettes. Some people say that videos depicting explicit sex or violence should be banned.

It then went on to ask specifically what should be banned and it produced a very contradictory result-that, 43 per cent wanted X banned but only 3 per cent thought that explicit sex should be banned; in other words, the real contents of X. In view of this urgency motion, it is interesting to note that only 3 per cent of women thought that explicit sex should be banned in videos. In other words, 3 per cent thought that real X-rated videos should be banned and the other 40 per cent were confused by the incorrect information in the question.

The motion alleges hypocrisy on the part of the Government. If there is any hypocrisy in this whole debate it is not in the area referred to in the motion; it lies with people who act in ignorance-I believe, in some cases, wilful ignorance-to trample on the rights of Australian adults to view material when no harm can be demonstrated to result from such viewing.

The second part of the motion deals with women. I note that Senator Hill did not say a great deal about it. This Government's commitment to improving the status of women in Australian society is by no means confined to criticising the advertising industry for its portrayal of women. That is a small, although important, part of our commitment. The Opposition's allegation comes very strangely-one could say hypocritically-when we remember its stance, with a few notable exceptions, on our sex discrimination and affirmative action legislation. This Government has done infinitely more in the last 5 1/2 years to advance the status of women than all the conservative governments have done since Federation, and Australian women know that.

I am a feminist-in fact, I was one probably before I had even heard of the word-and I reject strongly the allegation that X-rated videos degrade women. With a few exceptions, the women who have written to me and those who appeared before the Joint Select Committee shared that view. The ones who put forward the view that X-rated videos are degrading to women are, on the whole, the ones at the extreme conservative end of the spectrum-bodies such as the Women's Action Alliance. This is because non-violent erotica, which is what the X-rating contains, does not exploit or degrade women any more than it does men. Some mention has been made of the Office of the Status of Women and I quote from what it said when it appeared before our Committee:
The Office is satisfied that the guidelines as they now stand-
that is, the present guidelines-

will operate in such a way as to prohibit such material as is likely to cause direct or indirect physical or psychological harm to women, while maintaining the rights of individuals to develop their own view of life, without direction from the state or the majority.
In answer to a question about X-rated material it said:

By saying that we do not object to that material we are not saying necessarily that we would like to see it encouraged in any way. We said in our submission that a fine balance exists. Where we on examination of the guidelines have drawn the line in that balance is in the area of gratuitous violence and cruelty that are covered by the new guidelines. That is not to say that we are very pleased about that sort of material. In fact, there is a lot of non-pornographic material in the media generally which depicts women as subordinate or in exploited situations that we are not happy with.
The Office went on to talk about advertising. I understand that my colleague Senator Crowley is going to address that issue.

In many X-rated films it is in fact the women who take the initiative in sexual activity. Perhaps it is this that some people are objecting to. Perhaps it is really that some people object to the portrayal of women as enjoying sex. The social conservatives on the Joint Select Committee implied that view and even gave examples such as fellatio and cunnilingus as activities to which women are subjected. It amazes me that they believe that no woman would enjoy these activities as they apparently believe, against the evidence here in the Australian Capital Territory, that all X-rated videos are bought and hired by men. In fact, 30 per cent of the hirers are women and 70 per cent of the total hirers are couples.

That group of conservatives on the Committee also attacked X-rated material on the grounds that it contains little plot or character development. They said that it appealed only to a `prurient interest in sexual matters'. On those grounds we would need to ban vast quantities of material presently sold in bookshops and newsagents, including some weekly and, particularly, Sunday newspapers and quite a lot of advertising.

I see that Senator Harradine is now in the chamber and is to speak later in the debate. He will no doubt tell us that the viewing of explicit sex has been shown to be harmful. I have read and heard the same evidence as he has, probably more critically in a methodological sense because I am a psychologist by trade. I have found no evidence that harm results in the absence of other pathology. We do not usually base legislation on what deviants or psychotics might do in response to certain stimuli.

One allegation that we heard on the Committee-and this was anecdotal, as much of the evidence was-was that there is a link between domestic violence and X-rated videos. I recently attended a three-day conference on domestic violence which was attended by a wide range of service providers, including psychologists, doctors, police, judges and victims of domestic violence. Videos got one mention during those three days, and that was in regard to a banned video. Surely, if there were some evidence of such a link, it would have surfaced at a conference such as this. However, firearms and other weapons did get frequent mention at the conference. Yet Senator Julian McGauran, in a recent interview on Australian Broadcasting Corporation radio, said that pornographic videos in the home were much more dangerous than guns.

I was interested to receive this morning a copy of a letter sent to a video industry representative by a body called the Conservative Action and Victory Fund, which describes itself as `an independent parliamentary lobby supporting conservative candidates and causes'. Its letter includes these points:

1. The Conservative Action and Victory Fund is totally opposed to the imposition of any censorship on literature or viewing material-in addition to any attempt by government to decrease the ordinary rights of law abiding Australians.

2. As such, it is the consideration of CAVF that the Industry should not be subject to any government action, and that any public concern should be dealt with internally by self-regulation and examination.
3. Irrespective of the success or otherwise of current national proposals, it is the intention of CAVF to pursue with the next federal government-i.e. a Howard-led federal Coalition-
that shows its politics-
the reversal of impending legislation with a view to putting in place point No. 2.
In other words, the right of self-regulation and internal censorship. I trust that the Opposition will take note of this body, which clearly supports conservative candidates and causes.

TALK.START.PARA: —What about child pornography?
—What about it?

—It is banned, and Senator Walters knows it. I trust also that the Opposition will cease trying to turn the clock back towards the time when Lady Chatterly's Lover and the Golden Ass were banned in Australia. Finally, I would like to quote a few sentences from an excellent contribution to the Committee's inquiry by Professor Gus Brannigan, who was then and I think still is a professor in legal studies at La Trobe University. He said:

SPEECH.PARA: I would like to believe that most people remain sceptical of the third party victimisation arguments. One must wonder how the Minister, the parliamentarian or the experimental psychologist who has been making a special study of the offensive literature-
or videos-
has remained personally unaffected while others-especially youth and the working class-are thought to be vulnerable.
I might also add, women. He went on to say:
One must wonder, if the basic imitation thesis is correct, why we are not all made petty thugs by watching `Minder', adulterers by watching `Dallas' or blithering idiots by watching `Monty Python'.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jenkins Sen J.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —This is a matter about which people have very deep, often emotional and, for the most part, sincere feelings. In the time available I shall attempt to deal with all aspects of Senator Hill's urgency motion. The deep and personal feelings are there because the matter that we are debating formally in this place deals with an aspect of our human lives that affects us all most personally-that is, our sexuality and our sexual behaviour.

SPEECH.PARA: In our so-called civilised society, what is said and what is done as far as sexual matters are concerned are often in conflict with each other. I can take an example from a recent era in our history. In the Victorian era piano legs were covered so that ladies' sensitivities could be protected. But at the same time, upper-class brothels and prostitutes flourished for the convenience of those same gentlemen who were so eager to protect the sensitivities of their ladies at home by covering piano legs and table legs and so on. But what about the women in the lower classes in the Victorian era who could not claim to be ladies and who, therefore, were not allowed their sensitivities? These women's status was somewhat different. They often had to carry out hard physical work and if, by some misfortune, a woman in service became pregnant to the master of the house, this would usually result in an instant shamed dismissal. So much for the status of women in Victorian times. But at least piano legs were covered!

What of the status of women today? Matters have improved. Some women now have the choice between home duties and a career. Some women are in a position to have a career and to afford a support system for child, husband and home care. Some women, despite equal opportunity legislation and despite affirmative action in some areas, are still subject to exploitation, which is the matter under debate today. The women in our community who continue to be the most exploited are Aboriginal women and women of migrant backgrounds. This has nothing to do with X-rated or any other sort of videos, because their exploitation dates back to long before video recorders and even before television itself. Aboriginal women, like their menfolk, have had the legal status of citizens for only just over 20 years. Migrant women continue to be exploited daily in low paid, boring and unpleasant jobs.

I will refer to the issue of the portrayal of women in the advertising industry before I return to the matter of X-rated video classification, which is the main thrust of the motion moved by Senator Hill, presumably on behalf of the Liberal Party of Australia. In her speech opening the public forum on women and advertising, Senator Margaret Reynolds, the Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women, described how the Federal Government became aware of the extent of women's dissatisfaction with the way they are portrayed in the media, particularly in advertising. She said that 28 per cent of the 25,000 women who outlined their concerns and priorities to the Government cited the way they were portrayed in the media as a major issue. She said that they complained of sex role stereotyping of women in advertising as being a major concern to a large proportion of women.

Senator Reynolds said that some research had been carried out in that area. She said that the first stage consisted of a comprehensive and unique content analysis of 901 different advertisements from all media and that this showed an overwhelming use of male presenters and voice-overs; a concentration of women in domestic duties and nurturing roles, `a marked under-representation of Aboriginal, non-English speaking, older and disabled women, to the extent of their invisibility', and a certain usage of irrelevant sexual portrayal and innuendo to promote products. She went on to say that the second stage of the research was in-depth consultations with 407 women to gauge their reactions to a representative sample of advertisements. She said:

The results show that women firmly believe that advertising acts against their achievement of equality. They object strongly to being shown as submissive, sexually available, cute, dim-witted and frivolous. They are concerned that their portrayal reinforces social stereotypes-an overemphasis on physical appearance, being slaves to their homes and families, being superwomen able to pursue full-time jobs, family responsibilities and home duties. They are concerned at the effect of constantly reinforced stereotypes on their children's behaviour and expectations.

A further random telephone survey of 1,002 women reinforces these findings, with between 54 and 68 per cent thinking that women were too often shown as young, slim and good looking, as valued for sex, as silly, incompetent and childish and as seldom able to provide expert advice.

So much for the matter of advertising. I believe that this matter is being addressed in conjunction with the advertising industry. I dispute the coalition Opposition's thesis implied in this motion that the Government is merely claiming a commitment to improving the status of women. I am sure that the Liberal Party and the National Party believe that they can do much better. No doubt at some stage in the future we will have an opportunity to judge that for ourselves.

I now turn to the matter of X-rated videos and that portion of the Opposition's motion which says that there is a `need to implement the unanimous recommendation of the State Attorneys-General in Darwin of 30 June 1988 that the X-rated video classification should be discontinued'. First and foremost, what are X-rated videos? As a member of the Joint Select Committee on Video Material I can inform honourable senators that they are boring, repetitive and of no artistic merit. I would like to see them banned on the last proviso, that is, that they lack artistic merit. But that precedent could result in much being banned in our culture, so it is unlikely to happen on that ground. The definition of X-rated videos is that they are restricted to people 18 years and over and they have:
Material which includes explicit depictions of sexual acts involving adults, but does not include any depiction suggesting coercion or non-consent of any kind.

Depictions that are refused classification and are banned are those of child pornography and bestiality, and `detailed and gratuitous depictions of acts of considerable violence or cruelty; explicit or gratuitous depictions of sexual violence against non-consenting persons'. This category also includes terrorist-type weapons and acts, and the abuse of hard drugs. The definition of R-rated videos, which are also restricted to those 18 years of age and over, includes:
Adult material which is considered likely to be possibly harmful to those under 18 years and possibly offensive to some sections of the adult community.
The language may be `sexually explicit and/or assaultive'. As far as sex is concerned, it may be:
Implied, obscured or simulated depictions of sexual activity; depictions of sexual violence only to the extent that they are discreet, not gratuitous and not exploitative.
As far as violence is concerned, it may be:
Explicit depictions of violence, but not detailed and gratuitous depictions of acts of considerable violence or cruelty.

I put it to the Senate that, if any grade of videos is to be banned, I personally would put the R before the X, because not only can R-rated videos contain sexual depictions, but they can be violent depictions. There is a most unfortunate misconception in the community that X-rated videos contain violent depictions of sex. This is simply not so-at least not in Australia. It can be so in the United Kingdom and the United States of America; hence, I think, the confusion.

That is why the majority of the Committee decided that a better name for X-rated videos would be non-violent erotica (NVE), because that is descriptive. Whether this should or should not be banned is a matter on which public opinion is divided, because in essence the public debate is censorship versus explicit sexual material on the screen. I do not believe that public opinion is divided on whether it should be restricted. In fact, the recommendation of the Joint Select Committee on Video Material was that both X and R-rated videos should be severely restricted to those 18 years and over; that the videos should be viewed in a separate room from other video classifications, or in a folder if a separate room is not available; and that no promotional material should be visible in public places. I hope that it would also include newspaper advertising, some of which is most offensive. People sometimes find their privacy invaded in that way. I agree that it is simply one of our human rights that we should not have to view material of any sort, including promotional material, that we do not wish to view.

I turn to the decisions of the Attorneys-General made earlier this year. In brief, those decisions were: that X-rated videos should be banned, that films and videos close to the top of the R category should be banned, that films and videos currently close to the top of the M category should become R, and that video packaging should contain more information about the contents. In other words, the recommendation for the banning of X-rated videos was one of a whole selection of conclusions that were arrived at. The current situation is that the sale and hire of X-rated videos is banned in all States of Australia. These were decisions taken by the various State governments. However, the possession of X-rated videos is not banned in any State. The sale and hire of X-rated video materials is currently allowed in the Australian Capital Territory and the Northern Territory. However, the Northern Territory Legislative Assembly has legislated to restrict the availability of both X and R-rated videos, much on the lines of the recommendations of the Joint Select Committee about which I spoke earlier. When the Australian Capital Territory Assembly comes into being-I hope, early next year-it will be interesting to see how the elected representatives of the people of the Australian Capital Territory will legislate on this matter.
Yesterday the Australian Labor Party Caucus quite correctly, to my way of thinking, opted to obtain more information before addressing the matter further. I quote from its resolution:
Caucus is concerned about the ongoing confusion over the contents of X and R-rated videos in the community.

Accordingly, Caucus determines that a working party be formed to resolve this confusion and to examine means by which a reduction in the level of violence in all categories of publicly available video, especially in the R-rated category, will be brought about.

Those are the matters that Caucus will consider. I ask this question publicly: When Caucus debates these matters, will it consider the research work done by the Australian Institute of Criminology over the last two years, which has revealed, firstly:
those who watch X-rated videos, besides being predominantly male-
that is about 60 per cent or so-
represent, in other social and demographic characteristics, a cross-section of all video viewers;
Secondly:

that our society is far more accepting of filmed aggression and violence than it is of consenting adult sexual activity and the community appears willing to expose its young to large amounts of filmed violence;
Thirdly:
that there is no evidence that sexually explicit media material leads to an increase in crime generally or sex crimes specifically.
Other matters have been brought forward by the Institute of Criminology, and I certainly recommend that Caucus debate those also.

I do not claim to speak on behalf of the Australian Democrats, of my parliamentary colleagues or of all women. However, I do claim to represent a rational and valid viewpoint which I know is supported by a section of the community. The Australian Democrats have a conscience vote on every issue, and therefore they most certainly will have a conscience vote on this issue. I believe that all parliamentarians should have a conscience vote on more issues than they already do, and on this issue in particular. I personally find the coalition Opposition's motion self-righteous and hypocritical and I will be voting against it.
For perhaps a last word on hypocrisy, I refer honourable senators to an article in the Melbourne Age earlier this year headed `The tragedy that is a national disgrace', which states:
My sister came to stay with me for a while. She went down the street to get some milk and came back in tears because of what she had seen out there-girls of 13 and 14 prostituting themselves.

It suddenly struck me that it was outrageous in a wealthy society like this that we are allowing kids to be exploited and abused in very large numbers. The degree is comparable with Dickensian England.
That, Madam Acting Deputy President, is exploitation.

We have also been told that the child pornography that is at present banned does create extra problems for children. I agree with that wholeheartedly, and I also agree wholeheartedly that the denigration of women in this filthy X-rated stuff does women immeasurable harm. We have been told by both Senator Zakharov and Senator Collins today that there is no violence; that it is just ordinary sex between men and women. What absolute bunkum. We on the Joint Select Committee have never seen any type of affection demonstrated between men and women in this rubbish that so many people are making millions out of. There has been no display of affection; just pure sex for sex's sake. Senator Collins today has said that sex is always with us. Of course it is always with us. I hope it always will be with us, and I hope that the average man and woman in Australia believe there should be affection and love associated with that action, but honourable senators opposite delight in talking about it, delight in viewing it, and believe beyond any shadow of a doubt that it ought to be a free-for-all.

TALK.START.PARA: —On a point of order, Mr Acting Deputy President: I think the honourable senator has gone way over the top. I would ask her to withdraw the statement that people on this side of the House are viewing at length and all the other things that she said, imputing to us all sorts of negative values.
—The honourable senator is not in breach of standing order 418.

—Thank you, Mr Acting Deputy President. We have been told that X-rated videos will go underground if they are banned. We have not been told in the same breath, of course, that child pornography would go underground if banned. We have got some of it underground, but at least one cannot go down to the shop beside the supermarket and get it as one can with the other stuff. That is how the young fry get it.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Collins piously says that it is up to the parents. It would be unhealthy for parents to watch every move of their 14- 15- and 16-year-old children. They cannot stop them going to friends' homes. To stifle them in that way would be unhealthy. They have to trust their children, and I defy any parents who see that X-rated stuff to say that is what they would like their children's first impressions of sex to be. It is revolting, rubbishy stuff with no love and affection at all. Way-out homosexual sex is depicted and all sorts of stuff is shown, but the mob opposite say that is all right. It is too dirty to be shown in the films for the public, but it is all right for home entertainment-let us have it for home entertainment! That is what the mob opposite is all about.

Let us look at the figures on violence. In the past 10 years the incidence of rape has increased from 6.08 per cent per 100,000 of population to 14.51 per cent. The incidence of serious assault has increased from 24.75 per cent to 81.18 per cent. We are going to be told by Senator Crowley, who is to follow me, that one cannot take any notice of that rape figure because people now report rape whereas previously they did not. What she is going to say about the serious assault I am not quite sure, but these new figures have been standardised to make sure that they are as close as possible to the figures that applied 10 years ago. She will say we cannot take any notice of them, but we know, as does any honourable senator who has gone around the community doorknocking, as I did during the last elections, that a woman on her own in the house is very reluctant to open the door. We all know that the secure feeling that women once had is gone. The majority of women are very worried about walking the streets at night, about opening their doors. We have all sorts of places set up as secure communities because women have become concerned about their own security. This does not apply only to one type of women but to women across the board.

Evidence has been given to us that one cannot say that X-rated videos definitely, without any shadow of a doubt, cause extreme violence. Of course one cannot say that, nor can it be said about child pornography. But the Joint Select Committee on Video Material heard evidence from Professor Sheehan which I think is extremely valuable. He said:
. . . the critical thing in whether or not there will be these so-called effects of sexually explicit material is how aggressive the person is in the first place . . .

There is no question that a lot of people are stimulated mildly or strongly by seeing sexually explicit material. When one is aroused one tends to behave as a consequence of that arousal and I think if the person is aggressive aggression will out . . . In and of itself, I do not think that sexually explicit material divorced from aggression leads to strong negative effects. Once you combine sexually explicit material with aggression you have a different kettle of fish.

TALK.START.PARA: —That's R.

—That is not R-rated; it is sexually explicit material divorced of violence. We had a survey not so long ago that said that 22 per cent of Australian men think it is all right to touch up their wives now and again. It shows that we have a fair percentage-nearly 25 per cent-of Australian men who have violent tendencies. According to Professor Sheehan those men are at risk, or certainly their wives are. They are watching this X-rated stuff.

SPEECH.PARA: There is absolutely no shadow of doubt that we have a great problem with domestic violence and violence against women in this country. But all this Government is concerned about is the fact that women might be depicted showing that they are nurturing children. Ye Gods! What is this Government on about? I would have liked to quote from the interview that the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) gave yesterday on the World Today program. He was so disgustingly flippant that I would not quote one word he said. It made me sick. I would not be prepared to stand in this chamber and quote one word of it. When I was in the United Kingdom I visited Scotland Yard. It came down with exactly what Professor Sheehan has said-that is, that there have always been the Jack the Rippers but there is a certain degree of violence in various men and the viewing of this X-rated stuff only aggravates that particular violence.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crowley Sen R.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —Today we are addressing an urgency motion brought into this place by Senator Hill which reads:

SPEECH.PARA: That, in the opinion of the Senate, the following is a matter of urgency:

The need to implement the unanimous recommendation of the State Attorneys-General in Darwin on 30 June 1988 that the X-rated video classification should be discontinued and to thereby end the hypocrisy of the Government in claiming a commitment to improving the status of women in Australian society exemplified by their giving priority to criticising the advertising industry for their portrayal of women while declining to take legislative measures to eliminate the exploitation of women in the ACT pornographic video industry.

I draw that to the attention of honourable senators because it would seem to me that very few people from the Opposition have even part way addressed the content of that urgency motion. I ask: What is urgent about it? The answer, of course, is absolutely nothing. This is a motion of massive blatant political expediency; no more and no less. The Opposition says, `This looks as though we have the Government in some kind of contradiction; let's belt them'. Senator Hill and other senators opposite can try that but it does not in any way make this matter any more urgent than it was the day before, last week, for the last five years or for the seven years of the Fraser Government which did so little to improve the status of women in Australian society.

Next we had a referral to the word hypocrisy. Hypocrisy was attributed to the Government. I would have thought that hypocrisy, as Senator Collins and Senator Zakharov said in this place, belongs with the Opposition. Firstly, there is the hypocrisy of Senator Hill claiming urgency when it is merely political expediency and, secondly, there is the hypocrisy of the speakers. In leading off the debate Senator Hill spent all his time addressing the absence in this place of Senator Reynolds. He had almost nothing to say about the content of his motion. He did not address why it was urgent. He did not address the definitions of video classifications. He did not address what it is that so distresses the status of women. He did not address what he means by making the Australian Capital Territory the pornographic video industry centre of Australia. He was certainly taken to the limits of glorious extravagance by Senator Bjelke-Petersen who, I think, talked about `Pornberra'. I heard it from outside the chamber and I must say that that is flying a kite and flying it fairly high. Senator Hill had nothing of any importance to contribute except to throw off at the Government because Senator Reynolds was not here in this debate. He somehow did not think it was curious that he was in the chamber and some of the women from the Opposition were not. All these points are tedious and trivial and his attack on Senator Reynolds was specious and showed how hollow his contribution was.

Finally, he did not say that he attended the public forum on the portrayal of women in the media and advertising. He did not say that at the Saturday session when he was speaking-and there are some 600 witnesses to prove this-he said that he was opposed to censorship. At that forum Senator Robert Hill said, `I am opposed to censorship'. Is it not interesting that he forgot to tell us that that was what his view was when he was talking about the urgency of the Government banning this. Can we believe, as some people have suggested, that Senator Hill is going from small `l' to big `l' liberal very rapidly in the face of preselections in his own State? Today there is an article in the Australian Financial Review pointing out that his position on the Senate ticket is very much in jeopardy and that he will be opposed for that top position by Senator Chapman who believes that he ought to be entitled to the top spot on the ticket. He intends to fight for it on the grounds that he is in South Australia more often than is Senator Hill. I would suggest that that is very wide of the mark. I am quite surprised that this sort of rhubarb has got into the debate. Senator Puplick's case lends a certain amount of value to this point.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise on a point of order, Mr Acting Deputy President. I draw your attention to the speaker's lack of relevance to the subject. I ask that you get her off the preselection arrangements of the Liberal Party and onto the subject before the chamber.
—Do tell them that it is no point of order.
—Order! Senator Crowley, I remind you of the terms of the motion.
—It is a point of order.

—I did not hear the Acting Deputy President say that. The difficulty I have is to watch Senator Hill bring this urgency motion into this chamber. It seems to contradict his position in times past on a number of these issues. I am also reminded that he would lead us to believe that he would want to support the introduction of censorship and the banning of X-rated video classifications. I remind honourable senators again of what he said in the Saturday session on the forum of the portrayal of women in the media. He said, `I am opposed to censorship'. I would have thought that that suggests that Senator Hill was not revealing the full range of his thinking on this subject.

SPEECH.PARA: I do not believe that we can properly address anything Senator Florence Bjelke-Petersen added to the debate because it was largely about euphemisms and generalisations and the amorphous family for which she said that this Government had done nothing. For the record it is important to say that this Government does have a commitment to improving the status of women in Australian society. It is a record that is unmatched by any previous government. It is certainly something that stands us in very good stead indeed. I have a small list-certainly not an exhaustive list-of some of the decisions taken by this Government. They include the introduction of the sex discrimination legislation, the affirmative action legislation and the Government's policies on the education of women and girls to a point where the number of girls retained at school to year 12 now exceeds the number of boys and where for the first time ever we have more than 50 per cent of students in tertiary institutions who are women. We have increased the number of tertiary places so that those very women can finish year 12 and if they want tertiary opportunities now they can expect to have them.

Under sport we have established the Women's Sport Promotion Unit, something which I have been long associated with and which talks about opportunities for women, the status of women, and the presentation and representation of women as fit, healthy, active women able to take their place in society, able to take their place on the sporting field, able to win enormous numbers of gold medals for this country and able to participate in recreation and leisure activities across the nation. The Government has promoted all of those things very actively. It has promoted its Aussie sports program to give girls, as well as boys, the opportunity to take part.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Acting Deputy President, I rise on a point of order with regard to relevance. The Government's so-called achievements are not relevant to this debate and I ask you to draw the honourable senator's attention to that fact.
—Order! The last part of the urgency motion relates to the portrayal of women.

—The words that I am referring to here talk about the Government's claim to `a commitment to improving the status of women in Australian society'. Some of the things that I have listed go precisely to that point. It is a short litany of some of the things the Government has done to ensure that the status of women in Australian society is not a hollow commitment but an active and real one. Of over one million jobs created since this Government came into office, 68 per cent have gone to women. We have introduced a family assistance package precisely to address the needs of families with low incomes, families living on either pension income or income from low paid jobs. All of those things deal with the problem dealt with by Senator Bjelke-Petersen in terms of how this Government has or has not helped the family. Our record stands, and without doubt we are committed to assisting women and the status of women. Labor has increased the number of pensions. It has established and broadened the previous National Women's Advisory Council and extended it to the National Women's Consultative Council, increased the number of representatives, and broadened the numbers of women who have an opportunity to contribute to what government needs to know about women's attitudes and values.

SPEECH.PARA: I move to the National Agenda for Women, which was so widely circulated to women in the community and to which so many women responded. Some 7,000 of the 25,000 women who responded addressed the question as to how women are portrayed in the media. They objected to the way women are constantly portrayed in a less than dignified way, and protested at the way women are often regarded as robots in domestic areas or as sex objects. I would have been surprised if there was much difference between the women in this chamber on this matter. Certainly I object very strenuously to how women are portrayed in the media, whether stereotyped or portrayed as sex objects. Subsequent to that the Minister reminded us of the guidelines to the media called `Fair Exposure', and promised that they will be updated and reworked in case there is any need to improve them, although they were first introduced, I believe, in 1984. At the Public Forum on Women in Advertising the women listed here are to be noted as objecting to the portrayal of women in the media. I seek to table a list of women's organisations which contributed to that Public Forum.
Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Senate. One sees from that list that the women who protested about the way in which the media portray women cover a whole spectrum from conservative women's organisations to radical women's organisations, and to thousands of organisations in the middle of the spectrum. All subscribe to the consensus view about how women are portrayed in the media. One of the things wrong with this urgency motion is that it does not understand the difference between the way in which women are portrayed in the media and how they are portrayed in X-rated videos. In the media women are portrayed, not invariably but in very large part, either as stereotypes or as sex objects. In the advertising or media area people who watch that material do so involuntarily. Very few people say, `Here come the advertisements-I will turn off the television or avert my eyes'. It is a very different issue from the question whether people deliberately set out to provide or procure for themselves a video by means of mail order, though in the ACT the position is not quite the same. People who seek to obtain a video of the sort that is causing so much trouble have to make a special effort to do so. In the media the difference is quite marked and remarkable. The question of how women are portrayed in the media should be properly argued because of the wide reception of such an advertising model. If the Opposition says that it needs to talk to women about this matter, I would remind Opposition senators that we have a forum. We have had the media's attention and an indication that they will reappraise the guidelines to see whether there is room for improvement in the way women are portrayed. I turn to the point of the X-rated videos.
—At last.

—This whole debate, Senator Newman, deals with a number of issues which apparently seem not to occupy the Opposition at all. I have addressed the subject of the status of women, the hypocrisy of the Opposition and the hypocrisy of Senator Hill--
—Order! The honourable senator may not use that word. She should withdraw that statement.

—I withdraw, Mr Acting Deputy President. The difference between advertising and the entertainment industry should be obvious, but it seems not to entertain the mind of Senator Newman. She wants me to talk only of X-rated videos.
—Because you have double standards in your party.

—They are not double standards. There are two serious issues involved here. In the last few minutes of my remarks I shall address the question whether we ban or support censorship. For the record, I am one of those people, like Senator Collins and many others, who totally dislike pornography and almost all the non-violent erotica (NVE) material -except that I am not sure that I have seen anything classified as NVE because I am not sure that that classification applies yet. But in common with most people in this place-perhaps this would be a wild statement-not many would want to watch it, though I would like to test that statement in the corridors outside. I do not see that there is too much redeeming merit to the so-called X-rated or NVE classification. I am also strongly opposed to censorship. We are talking about where to draw the line.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Walters, in her contribution-for the umpteenth time-anticipated what I intended to say, and told me what I should think. She would be very wrong in just about everything she said that she attributed to me. I take very seriously the figures and evidence cited by the honourable senator. All Australian Labor Party senators place serious weight on the matters she raised. Our action does not flow from a total disregard for women, or from a belief that there are not better ways of trying to reduce the problem of domestic violence. All those matters are of great concern to Labor senators. We do not believe that in moving the motion in Caucus yesterday we are moving away from addressing properly the whole issue. The question relates to the confusion about the difference between violence and sexually explicit material. That confusion is obvious all the way to Attorneys-General as was evidenced from the contribution by Senator Zakharov. There is no difference of opinion in the Government.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable senator's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yesterday's Caucus decision to establish a further working party on videos was a complete sham. It was a public relations exercise to camouflage the Federal Government's continued legislative support for the hard-core porn industry-and that against the express and unanimous wishes of all the States of the Commonwealth and of the majority of the Joint Select Committee on Video Material which had studied the problem over a period of three years. The decision is a rejection of and an insult to State Attorneys-General and the Ministers for censorship and to the majority of the Joint Select Committee who recommended that X-rated videos be banned from the home video entertainment market.

SPEECH.PARA: The Caucus gave two lame excuses for its decision. The decision was to set up a working party to resolve the confusion and to examine means by which the reduction in the levels of violence in all categories of publicly available videos, especially in the R category, will be brought in. They are lame, sham excuses. Are members of Caucus saying that all State Attorneys-General, all their advisers and all the Ministers responsible in the States for censorship did not know the content, the intent and the nature of X-rated videos? If they are saying that, it is an insult. Are they saying that Mr Sumner in South Australia did not know it? Are they saying that the Labor Attorney-General in Victoria did not know it?

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes.
—So Senator Zakharov is saying that the Labor Attorney-General in Victoria is an idiot?
—No, I am not saying that.

—If Senator Zakharov is saying that he does not know the fundamentals of his portfolio, I suggest that he should resign as well as Senator Zakharov. I know that they do know what is contained in this material and they do know the harm, as we knew the harm, that it engenders. On that basis they recommended that it be banned. We are talking about X-rated material which is described officially in the Federal Government's own explanatory memorandum to the Australian Capital Territory ordinance as `hard core pornography'. I seek leave to incorporate that part of the explanatory memorandum in Hansard.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.
The document read as follows-

Printed matter is classified into 3 groups: unrestricted, (objectionable) Category 1 and (objectionable) Category 2. Films/videocassettes are classified in accordance with the current classifications for theatrical film: `G'-For General Exhibition, `PG'-Parental Guidance (replacing the `NRC'-Not Recommended for Children), `M'-for Mature Audiences and `R'-For Restricted Exhibition; an additional classification-`X' is applied to hard core pornography.

TALK.START.PARA: —We are talking about material that treats women, `as sexual commodities to arouse the sexual desires of its target audience' and `reduces persons to objects or occasions of sexual pleasure'.
—Whose words are they?

—That is in the majority report of the Joint Select Committee. Although physically non-violent, this material portrays women `as eager for sexual experience of any kind and ever ready for any opportunity for sexual activity. This is frequently manifested in the group sex scenes depicting diverse sexual activity, which are a feature of much of the material'. We are talking about group sex being a feature of the material and anal sex being included in the material. According to the evidence cited by the majority of members of the Joint Select Committee, such material engenders in the viewer a `sexually calloused and manipulative orientation towards women'. It mediates in the mind of the habitual viewer a perception of women in general as being highly promiscuous and available. The majority observed that these viewers of pornographic videos come to accept and endorse the values represented in this material.

SPEECH.PARA: Where is the confusion? We knew and the State Attorneys-General knew what the material contained. What is the Caucus committee going to do to get the confusion out of the mind of the public? The Government's lame excuse was that the committee's job would be to examine means by which a reduction in the levels of violence in all categories of publicly available videos, especially those in the R category, would be brought about. It is seven months too late. The majority of members of the Joint Select Committee recommended that. The State Ministers ordered the Chief Censor and the Chairman of the Films Board of Review to apply tighter restrictions to violent films in M and R categories. That order was made on 30 June 1988. I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard the official document of the Office of Film and Literature Classification dealing with that decision.
Leave granted.
The document read as follows-
VIOLENCE IN `M' AND `R' FILMS AND VIDEOS

The Ministers made a unanimous request to the Chief Censor and to the Chairman of the Films Board of Review to apply tighter restrictions to violent films in the `M' and `R' categories. In particular the Ministers were concerned about violent films and videos at the top end of the `M' and `R' classifications.

The Ministers, reaffirming the view they expressed earlier in Brisbane, also took into account the views expressed in the report of the Joint Select Committee on Video Material about films and videos featuring violence in the upper reaches of the two categories.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Zakharov and the minority of the Committee refused to go along with the majority in asking that films of relished violence be refused classification. Who is strong on violence and who is not? Those people who are parading around the place and suggesting that they are strong on violence were the ones, including Senator Jenkins of the Australian Democrats, who did not support the motion. That is a disgrace. The decision of Caucus is a blatant abdication of the Government's responsibility to act on the burden of evidence placed before the Joint Select Committee of Parliament over four years and on the clear call of all the States.

SPEECH.PARA: Generally, I do not raise my voice to more than a boring monotone, but it disturbs me that Senator Collins goes round the countryside calling everybody hypocrites. He calls those who oppose his point of view `mewling, puking hypocrites'. I will not accuse Senator Collins of being a puking hypocrite, or anywhere near it, but I do accuse him of being an utter humbug. He went on radio in Tasmania today and said, as he has before, and as reported in the Canberra Times, that when he became a member of the Committee he was initially in favour of banning X-rated videos. He joined the Committee in October 1987. I quote from what he said in the Northern Territory Legislative Council on 6 March 1985:

There are members on this side of the Assembly-and they will be free to say so-who want to see X-rated videos banned completely in the Northern Territory. I am sure there are many members on the opposite side of the Assembly who have also that view. That does not happen to be my personal view.

He went on to speak in support of X-rated videos and voted for them to be made freely available. Who is a humbug? Then he accused Joe de Bruyn of the Shop Distributive and Allied Employees Association (SDA) of not knowing what he was talking about. He refused-if not dishonestly, something near to it-to quote from Joe de Bruyn's letter that went to every member of parliament on 3 November which indicated clearly that the decision of the council of the SDA was based on a complete and utter knowledge of the nature and content of videos which bear the X classification. Yet he continues to go on with that when both Joe de Bruyn and I know that, so far as rape is concerned, there is a lot of that material in R. That is the sort of stuff that needs to be reviewed also. That was his view and it is mine. I do not say that Senator Collins is a humbug in all areas, but he is in this one.

What does the Government do when all its arguments fail? It resorts to the slogan that people should have the right to view what they wish. Of course adults are free to look at and read what they choose. That is not the issue. Adults are also free to take poison if it is produced. What this Government is saying virtually is that this is not in the nature of a principle to be applied universally and uniformly, but rather a slogan to be used selectively and arbitrarily in a manner which lacks credibility. In the case of video pornography it resorts to its use rather than admitting to giving priority to the exploiting pornographers' claimed right to freedom of expression over all other individual and societal rights. All this goes back to the late Lionel Murphy and Senator Gareth Evans. When they tried to dump this hard core pornography on the community they said, `We want uniform legislation'. All the States have said that they do not want X-rated material. The Federal Government is the only one out of step.

I have a clear view on censorship. I would define censorship as the application of a carefully balanced and judiciously evaluated assessment of that which is conducive to the essential common good of an equal liberal and life affirming society. This material does none of that. I agree entirely with what Professor Zubrzycki, Emeritus Professor of Sociology at the Australian National University, said of video pornography. He said that video pornography functions quite similarly to anti-Semitic or racist propaganda: it serves as a tool of anti-female propaganda. He went on to say that the intent of all three is to distort the image of a group or class of people, to deny the fullness of their humanity and to depict them as objects for exploitation. That is precisely what X-rated video material does.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Dunn Sen I.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —In rising to address this motion, I do not wish to align myself with the wowsers and moral majority of this country but to express a point of view that represents, I believe, the views of a large number of women of all political persuasions. The Labor Caucus decision not to ban X-rated videos in the Australian Capital Territory (ACT) shows that the Government has resiled from its stated commitment to equality for women. X-rated videos which portray explicitly sexual scenes between men and women almost invariably portray women as passive, sexually submissive and devoid of human characteristics, and dehumanise them as persons worthy of dignity and respect. The Government justifies its decision to allow non-violent erotica in the ACT on the basis that it does not portray any coercion on the part of the women who participate in such videos. But there are many subtle ways in which these videos can denigrate women. Even where they are seen to take the initiative, it is in response to the fantasies of a masculine script writer.

SPEECH.PARA: Such videos are merely one end of the spectrum of sexual exploitation of women in the media and, as Senator Hill and others have said, it is quite inconsistent of the Government to express concern for the portrayal of women in advertising while supporting the development of a hard-core porn industry in the nation's political capital. One can only wonder whether the move is designed to satisfy the jaded sexual appetites of the male members of the Labor Caucus when sitting hours are over.

In 1977, I lost a job for using my business card to identify myself in a complaint against the sexist advertising of the multinational employment agency, Westaff. The subsequent publicity brought me many letters from women who wrote of the sexual harassment they had received from their workmates and bosses. Advertisements have unfortunately not changed a great deal since then. If we ban such advertisements from our television screens and billboards, is this to be regarded as censorship? Unfortunately, the Media Council's ethics committee, a body dominated by seven elderly men, has failed to include guidelines on sexism and sex role stereotyping in the new code of ethics for the advertising industry. Is it too much to ask the Government to establish a code of ethics in relation to video material?

X-rated videos are only a symptom and not the cause of a much more deep-seated problem of sexual exploitation in our society. It may have been useful to ban X-rated videos as a sign of public disapproval, but is the Government doing enough to counter the attitudes which lead to the production and demand for such videos? Psychological justifications for such videos are highly specious, often defending them for their therapeutic influence on sexually deprived males, and the alleged role of the videos in preventing rape. This is nonsense.

We have a right to decide what kind of nation we want to be. We have a right to choose whether we receive and promulgate material that is degrading to women and therefore degrading to humanity. If we can choose advertising standards and ban cigarette advertising because it is bad for human health, we can also choose not to have such videos on the grounds that they are offensive to our notions of humanity, not to mention aesthetics, as Senator Jenkins said.

In defending such videos, civil libertarians are, I believe, misguided in the principles they apply to their judgment. We know how advertising operates in a subliminal way to affect consumer behaviour. In the same way, these videos influence how we regard women. The Government has not done enough to discourage the idea that female sex is a commodity like any other, and to establish mechanisms to encourage positive attitudes to women. Allowing X-rated videos in the ACT will certainly not contribute to this.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to make a small contribution to this debate, if for no other reason than to point out that the motion put forward by the Liberal Party of Australia was promoted by a man and that women led in the debate for both the Australian Democrats and the Government.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the paper.

I want to deal with just that section of the annual report of the Department of Finance which deals with government business enterprises. The main functions of the Department are listed on page 2 of the report, and they include:
the provision of advice to the Government on appropriate overall budgetary and financial policy issues generally;
fostering the efficient and effective use of resources-
Of course, it means in the public sector. The last one is:
conduct of major asset sales as required.

I move to the question of the selling off of some of the Government's business enterprises. I draw the Department's attention to the following words of the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) last year, when he was talking about government business enterprises:
The question should not be: `why should we sell a given enterprise?' but `Why should we continue to tie up our resources in it?'.
In the same speech he went on to say:
Efficiency in the achievement of national goals is the key, not some ideological debate about appropriate aggregate levels of public ownership.

As can be seen from that statement, at that stage the Government was talking about getting rid of some of its statutory authorities which are, in effect, in the business of being in business rather than in the business of providing services to the nation.

I refer the Senate to a speech of the Minister for Finance, Senator Walsh, on 24 October of this year in which he, in effect, says that the Labor Government is not going to go down the same road as indicated by the Prime Minister last year in that speech, because he objects to the policy of the Liberal Party and the National Party of privatising or partially privatising the following statutory authorities: Australian Airlines, Qantas Airways Ltd, domestic and international airport terminals, the Australian Industry Development Corporation, the Overseas Telecommunications Commission, Aussat Pty Ltd, the Housing Loans Insurance Corporation, the Snowy Mountains Engineering Corporation, Medibank Private and the Pipeline Authority. He refers to the Liberal and National Party coalition policies with regard to the privatising or partial privatising of these bodies, and he is critical of them. Senator Walsh goes on to claim:
This Government has embarked upon a major program of microeconomic reform, an important part of which is improving the efficiency of government enterprise.

I say to the Senate, and to Senator Walsh in particular, that all the Government has done up to now is deal with the peripheries of changing the names of these organisations and changing their controllers from their present statutory authority controllers to a board of management which will consist of the same people but will be under a different name; but there has been no major micro-economic reform at all in this area. It is about time the Government either fulfilled that role which it sees for itself-in other words, brought about major micro-economic reform in this area-or got on with the job of privatising these bodies and selling them to private enterprise, thereby giving private enterprise an opportunity to make these bodies financially worthwhile instead of the taxpayers of Australia having to continue to carry them. All this Government is on about is talking about reform and not acting in relation to reform. The sooner this Government gets on to actually doing something about reform, the better off this country will be.

DEBATE.TITLE: TAXATION LAWS AMENDMENT (TAX FILE NUMBERS) BILL 1988PRIVACY BILL 1988

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Powell Sen J.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is very important, in entering the debate on this legislation, that I make one point quite clear: the Australian Democrats have no objection whatsoever to what is perceived to be the Government's goal in this exercise, which is to provide the most efficient means possible for the Australian Taxation Office to do its job. That job is to collect taxation from those people in our community who are liable to pay tax.
