Nevertheless, as I made the point in a few short minutes before the debate was adjourned earlier today, such efficiency has to be within the bounds of what is socially acceptable. At that time, I made the point that we could have a very efficient economic system in this country if we were to remove from our economy all economically dependent people. We would not include children because they might grow up and become economically efficient in our society but we would have to eliminate the aged, the infirm, the disabled, and the unemployable-young or old. That would be efficient in economic terms. But of course we do not consider that kind of option because it is socially unacceptable, and thank goodness.

SPEECH.PARA: In the same way we have to look at what we want to do with the Tax Office and its ability to perform its task. Perhaps the most efficient system was that proposed some time ago in which all citizens would have a card with a photograph, a number and relevant data. Perhaps even more efficient would have been a tattoo on our foreheads. That was not proposed; the Australia Card was. The community said that that was not acceptable, so the Government went down another track. It has proposed an extended use of the tax file number. Again, it is important to make it clear that the Australian Democrats have no objection to the Taxation Office and the taxpayer using the tax file number in a more efficient way. But that is where it stops.

I will go to an article in the Melbourne Herald of 7 October last year in which Senator Haines said she would `support extension of the number's use to banks and other financial institution accounts only if it was made optional'. Indeed, in a number of other statements then and since the point has been made quite clearly that the tax file number should be for use between the taxpayer and the Tax Office only. In the earlier part of this debate we had claims from the Opposition-no doubt there will be more-that they have in their negotiations forced radical changes, to use Senator Michael Baume's words. He said that under the legislation, which the Opposition is now supporting, it is no longer compulsory for people to give their tax file number to financial institutions and that it is-again quoting Senator Baume-totally optional.

We have to define what is an option. As far as the Australian Democrats are concerned, an option is not an option unless it is realistic. Certainly the deal done between the Opposition and the Government has a degree of option within it, but only for those people who are on high incomes and for whom the sanction of not spreading their tax file number all over the place is simply that their tax will be taken out at source at that time. It will be taken out at the top rate of tax, plus the Medicare levy. For high income earners who are paying that rate of tax anyway, it is not a problem. For them it is an option.

The arrangement that has been made between the Government and the Opposition and which will see unchanged passage of this legislation is not presenting an option for lower income earners. Indeed, it is a punitive situation for those people. People in the community who are concerned about the privacy aspects of this legislation but who are paying less than the top rate of tax are to face a sanction in terms of their choice, should they exercise it, in that their tax will be taken out at the top rate. It is only when they have filled in their tax returns and get their tax rebates that they can be refunded for the taxation which has come out. Of course, low and middle income families are so much under stress. This stress has been focused on by the Opposition in all sorts of debates, especially the recent debates in this chamber in relation to tax legislation. These are the people who will be very much hurt by what is called an option but is not an option. It is certainly not a poor person's option, although it may be an option for the rich friends of both the Government and the Opposition, or even the comfortable in our community. It seems that privacy is something one can have if one can afford it, according to the arrangement that has been made between the Government and the Opposition.

Senator Baume talked about the fact that these massive changes had been made to the legislation. The Opposition has persuaded the Government some way down the track. Of course, the removal of the provision for the freezing of bank accounts should the tax file number not be given is a positive move and is supported by the Democrats. Certainly, the inclusion of guidelines in the schedule to the Privacy Bill with regard to privacy provisions relating to the tax file number is a positive step forward and is supported by the Australian Democrats. Senator Baume said that this was now no longer Son of ID card. It is certainly not Daughter of ID card. I suggest it is a big brother exercise, at least for lower income people in our community. It is rubbish that this is now a totally optional system, as Senator Baume said. It is rubbish that there have been radical changes to the tax file number legislation. It is a deal made by the Opposition and the Government to the disadvantage of low income people. It is no problem for the rich and influential.

Senator Baume in his contribution made the point that the Opposition does not want to give the Commissioner of Taxation more power. I reiterate that as far as the Democrats are concerned this is not a problem. We do not want to put in place a system where extensive data bases are built and then able to be misused. It is very important that unnecessary intrusions of privacy are not made possible. The Opposition does want to deny the Tax Commissioner more power. However, it does not seem concerned about the intrusive and draconian powers of the Department of Social Security in the area of information collection and disclosure which have led to incredible invasions of privacy in the lives of many people in our community since changes were made to the social security legislation following the 1987 mini-Budget. That does not seem to be a matter of concern at all to members of the Opposition. So I think it is clear whose privacy they are concerned about-the rich and influential, the employed, investors, taxpayers or people with tax liability; not low income earners and certainly not people who are dependent in one way or another in this society for income support from the Department of Social Security.

I would like to pass to some of the comments made by Senator Aulich in the debate. I had been off at a conference and came back into this House, switched on my speaker and heard Senator Aulich waxing lyrical about the dangers of the large amounts of information held on individual members of the community by banks, credit reference agencies and all sorts of private industry employers. He went on about how employers were now linking their databases and communicating with each other about issues of people's employability and said that people in the community do not necessarily know what is on these data banks. I was then staggered to hear him say that he had heard nothing from the Democrats on concerns about this kind of information held within the private sector. I could scarcely believe my ears. Certainly Senator Aulich cannot have read my addendum to the report of the Senate Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs in which I made it very clear that one reason I saw fit to add to what I considered to be a reasonable report under very difficult circumstances from the Committee looking into the whole broad issue of the feasibility of a national ID scheme and the tax file number over quite a long period was the very fact that I was concerned. I am an Australian Democrat and designated so in that report and I am surprised that the Chairman-this is the point Senator Aulich keeps reminding us of-of the Joint Select Committee on an Australia Card of historical note should not have read the report of a Senate standing committee on a similar issue some years later. My motivation was that I was very concerned about the very facts that Senator Aulich appeared to be concerned about today in the chamber. I say `appeared' because he, along with his Government colleagues and the Opposition, will vote for this legislation, which is absolutely deficient in the area-here I am referring specifically to privacy legislation-of giving any protection at all to members of the community as far as the private sector is concerned.

Senator Aulich and many other people in the community are concerned about the extent of databases which are being developed, the lack of knowledge that those databases exist and what is on them, the lack of access or the lack of the right to see what is there and to change if it necessary and the lack of any control over the use of such databases. All of this ought to be in adequate privacy legislation, and it was adequate privacy legislation that the Senate Committee suggested should be in place. `Appropriate privacy legislation' are the words from recommendation No. 9. I would also add that the Committee said that such legislation should be in place not later than the commencement of any enhanced tax file number legislation. So I challenge Senator Aulich quite strongly on a personal basis when he says that he has never heard from a Democrat on that issue.

I do know that Senator Haines-although I did not hear all her contribution in the debate earlier-made a point about that in this very debate. I do know that whenever Democrats have had an opportunity to speak on this issue this has been an issue of major concern. So I do not know where Senator Aulich has been. Mind you, I think he said, `I have never heard in this chamber a word from the Democrats'. All he has to do is absent himself from the chamber, as he has at this moment and does a great deal of the time, according to my observation of things. So perhaps we can excuse him from the point of view that he does not know what is going on in this chamber or perhaps anywhere else.

Certainly one of the major issues of concern for the Australian Democrats in this whole package is that the private sector remains untouched. That is not a surprise. What we have is a government which has pulled the rug of big business and privileged people in this community out from under the feet of an Opposition which thought it had that sewn up politically in this country. So we have an Opposition scrambling further and further to the right, looking for a place to exist in the political scene and looking for a lost constituency, and all the time both parties are falling over backwards not to upset their corporate mates.

I will move to another aspect that needs to be made very clear and is always made clear by the Australian Democrats in this debate but, of course, is ignored: that is our attitude, as I have said, to the approach of the responsibility of the Government and the Australian Taxation Office to ensure that people who have liability do pay their tax. I remind the Senate that the Australian Democrats have supported and congratulated this Government on its taxation reform over its period in office. We have been supportive of the introduction of the fringe benefits tax, the demise of the business lunch, and the capital gains tax-just taxes. Of course, they needed some adjustment and some amendment, which we have been able either to negotiate with the Government or to have passed on the floor of the chamber. But those sorts of tax reforms have had our support and will continue to have our support.

On the other hand, we have had an Opposition during that period-again, I think Senator Aulich pointed this out this morning-which has for month after month bleated in this chamber about the inequity of the fringe benefits tax, the capital gains tax and certainly the business lunch; yet it is prepared to support this legislation. One area where both the Government and the Opposition agree, however, on the question of who should and should not, and who does not pay tax, is in the large corporate area. We want to see the Government make some more reforms. We want to see a situation where we will not have Bond Corporation actually boasting-that is the way it sounds at the moment anyway-about the fact that for the next two years it will not pay any company tax at all. It was expected to pay almost 1c in the dollar, but through the legal ability to purchase other companies and organise its corporate structure suitably, it is even able to avoid having to pay that amount of tax.

If we look at the latest figures, published in the Sydney Morning Herald on 22 October, we see tax paid as a percentage of pre-tax profits by some of the major companies in this country: Quintex Australia, 0.11c in the dollar; Quintex, 0.15c; Adelaide Steamship Co. Ltd, 0.43; Equiticorp Aust Ltd, 0.80c; Bond Corporation was supposed to pay 0.97c, but it got out of even that; Northern Star Holdings Ltd, 1.30c; Westfield Capital Corporation, 1.54c; Southern Farmers, 2.21c; Westfield Holdings, 2.50c; and David Jones (Aust) Pty Ltd a massive 4.11c. If we want tax justice and we want to ensure that the Tax Office collects the taxation and that the Government's revenue is as adequate as it ought to be, there is an obvious need for further tax reform in this area if not in others yet.

I think it would be much more appropriate, and I would certainly feel more comfortable, if the climate were different in this place, if it were not always only the Australian Democrats who pointed this out. One of the means by which this is able to happen is by the retention of negative gearing on foreign borrowing for company takeovers. This has been a scandalous exercise over the past few years and is escalating because the Government does nothing about it. Of course, it would not be able to get support from the Opposition for doing it. But we have said again and again that that is exactly the sort of measure that we would support. It would be a major advantage to the revenue of this country and a major move in taxation justice. We have no objection at all to that sort of thing happening and that is not the reason for our concern about this legislation.
The Legal and Constitutional Affairs Committee stated that if the tax file numbers Bill were enacted it should:
. . . be strictly limited in its terms so that it applies only in relation to taxation purposes and those purposes be so framed as to prevent a progressive extension of the ambit of the Bill.

The Senate Committee recommended that the tax file number should be limited to taxation purposes. The Australian Democrats agree with that. That was another reason why I felt it necessary to add to that Senate Committee's report. Clearly, this legislation, even with the welcome but very minor changes that the Opposition has been able to get the Government to agree to, will mean that this is not going to be the case, except of course for those well off people who can choose not to give their tax file number. Ordinary Australians, unless they want to face a taxation sanction, will be required to give their tax file numbers to private employers, stock brokers and private banks. All of these institutions will have access to the tax file number-the key to a significant database on individuals. Those people who receive income support in the education area through Austudy, those people-mostly female sole parents-involved with the Child Support Agency, which has been rather cleverly put under the control of the Australian Taxation Office, are included. I suggest that that is stretching the idea of tax purposes just a bit.

In my addendum to the report I clearly pointed out that the options put forward by the Australian Democrats ought to have been picked up by the Government. I believe that the Taxation Office would have been rendered far more efficient than it currently is, perhaps marginally not quite as efficient as it would like to be and will be under the system that will come in-at the risk of the privacy of individuals in the community-if it had taken up any of the options proposed by the Australian Democrats. We will continue to propose those options by way of amendment in the committee stage of this debate. However, even before we get to the committee stage of the debate we make it quite clear, by the second reading amendment moved by Senator Haines, what is necessary to make this legislation acceptable in order to achieve the Government's goal-which we support-of increased efficiency in the Taxation Office while, at the same time, protecting the privacy of Australian citizens. We propose to add at the end of the second reading motion:
``, but the Senate notes-

(a) that the Government's tax file number system is unacceptably intrusive in that the tax file number will be given to a range of private sector institutions which will not be adequately covered by the Government's privacy legislation;

(b) that the Opposition parties' amendments to the tax file number legislation are meaningless to the ordinary taxpayer in that they only provide wealthy people with a real option not to supply the tax file number to private sector institutions; and

(c) that the Government and Opposition parties are both to be condemned for their failure to support an alternative system which would have caught people who were cheating the tax system and protected the privacy of Australian taxpayers, and would not have laid the foundations of a national identification system''.

What we will be asking of the Government by way of amendment in the committee stage of the debate is an alternative system that gives people 30 days in which to notify the Taxation Office that they wish to exercise a genuine option not to distribute their tax file number to all and sundry and not to have their tax file number placed on the private data banks-something that so worried Senator Aulich earlier in the debate. Let us imagine for a moment that we are employed by IBM, Ciba-Geigy, or any other large multinational company. What would we know about where those databases go and what is on them? Many people in the community have said, `I do not mind who knows my tax file number'. That is fine. However, we do not know; we cannot know-there are no provisions to ensure that we do know-what use might be made of that information.

When there is a tax file number which is more universal than any other number-I grant that the proposed number is not as universal as was proposed under the Australia Card system; nevertheless the interchange of information between government departments was a major concern of the Committee-that number will be substituted for other numbers. Let us take the situation applying to students in this community-and we have more legislation coming up in regard to students and higher education. If one were running a tertiary institution-of course, they will become bigger if the Government gets its way with amalgamations; again, this is a measure the Australian Democrats will be opposing-one's students, at least those on Austudy, would have to provide their tax file numbers to that institution. How long would one continue to use another number such as the student's file number, within the institution? How long would it be before it would become more efficient for that institution to use the tax file number? It is a number which the institution can use to communicate with the Australian Taxation Office but one hopes and one presumes that no links will be established should a person who is involved in the child support scheme, which is under the control of the Department of Social Security and the Australian Taxation Office, decide to take a course of study under the Austudy system. The possibility for establishing those links is there. There is no provision either in the privacy legislation or the tax file numbers legislation to protect those people. Again, these are some of the most disadvantaged people in the community.

The Opposition's agreement with the Government in regard to this legislation is a convenience only for the wealthy. The proposed Australian Democrat amendments will enable people to choose whether they supply the tax file number to the relevant private sector institutions. That amendment should be supported by those people who are concerned that individuals, should they want to-it is immaterial whether the majority do or do not want to-can retain the option of privacy. Individual privacy ought to remain an option for us in this democracy. Under this legislation, as a result of the deal between the Government and the Opposition, our privacy will not remain an option to us unless we can afford it. I suggest that that is a disgrace.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate is dealing with two very major pieces of legislation in the one debate. The first Bill, the Taxation Laws Amendment (Tax File Numbers) Bill 1988, introduces a tax file number system. The second Bill, the Privacy Bill 1988, introduces, for the first time in Australia, major privacy legislation. In my opinion it is unfortunate that these two pieces of legislation are being dealt with together. Although they are related in some respects, the Privacy Bill is a major new piece of legislation which deserves a separate debate and separate consideration on its own merits because of the many problems that arise from it.

SPEECH.PARA: The tax file number legislation is, of course, of equal importance. The Opposition has decided-I support that decision-to support both pieces of legislation. I do not propose to say very much about the tax file proposal; I have risen in this debate to speak mainly on the Privacy Bill. However, I believe that the tax file number system, as it has been redrafted by the Government-under a great deal of criticism and pressure from the Opposition-has become a workable piece of legislation. In company with the provisions of the Privacy Bill, there are a number of provisions-there are also a number of penalties-in the tax file numbers legislation to give reasonable protection for people's privacy when the tax file number system comes into use.

I have come to the decision to support the tax file number legislation with some misgivings. I believe that it is a piece of legislation that has to be very closely watched to ensure that the system does not lead to a de facto Australia Card with the very large numbers of people, institutions and so on that will have access to the tax file numbers of individual taxpayers using them as an identification system. The legislation makes it clear that that is not to be the case, and it provides for some very severe penalties for people who misuse the tax file number system. Nevertheless, the concern I have and I am sure many other people share is that there will be a temptation to misuse it. Therefore, it will need to be carefully monitored by the Government and the Opposition, and, indeed, by everybody who is concerned about his or her privacy.

As a result of the efforts of the Opposition, major amendments have been made to both pieces of legislation. Specific provisions have been introduced into the Privacy Bill to deal with the tax file number question as well as general privacy matters, and amendments have been made to the Taxation Laws Amendment (Tax File Numbers) Bill which make it clear that people will have an option not to provide tax file numbers, albeit that in that case tax will be withheld at the highest rate, and, therefore, their receipt of a credit will be delayed, until they finalise their taxation return for that year. So there is that severe penalty for people who do not provide a tax file number; nevertheless, they are given that very clear option in the legislation. Many people decide under the ordinary pay as you earn tax system to allow greater deductions to be made from payments to them as a means of saving, so the option given to them in this legislation of not providing tax file numbers if they do not wish to do so is not an unreal one.

As I said, I entered this debate to speak about the Privacy Bill and a number of concerns I have on the general question of privacy. I wish to refer to some particular provisions of the Bill, which is the Government's proposed solution to the problems in this area. I welcome the introduction of a Privacy Bill, but I must say that the Government has not really shown much attachment to providing some protection for privacy in our community. Under the Fraser Government, Attorney-General Ellicott gave a reference to the Law Reform Commission in 1976 on the question of protecting privacy. So it is not a new problem; it is one which has been around for many years. Over the 12 years since the matter was first referred to the Law Reform Commission by Mr Ellicott it has been a growing problem, and it will continue to be so. Nevertheless, the Government has taken what I can only call a very cavalier attitude to the Law Reform Commission's report, which was received by the Government in December 1983, nearly five years ago. The Government's only other attempt to act on that report was in conjunction with the Australia Card proposal. The privacy legislation has been brought in now only in regard to the Government's tax file number proposals.

It seems that the Government's only motivation for taking action in relation to the protection of privacy concerns its revenue-raising exercises. In many other respects this Government has shown a disinterest in the whole problem of privacy. Indeed, in its current attitude to the Australian Bureau of Statistics household expenditure surveys it has shown no real concern about protecting people's privacy. It did not even bother to take the necessary steps to table its proposals before it embarked on the recent survey. It has belatedly done so under great pressure, again from the Opposition. That is a clear example of the fact that it has introduced a Privacy Bill only because it is clearly needed from a political point of view to justify the passage of the tax file number legislation.

If it had not been for the Government introducing this Privacy Bill there is no way in which the Opposition would have entertained supporting the tax file number system. Indeed, the Government introduced the tax file number proposal without the Privacy Bill having been brought in. It was only at a very late stage, when it realised that the only hope it had of persuading the Opposition to support its tax file number legislation was to have adequate privacy legislation, that it did so. We have been asked to deal with this privacy legislation in great haste, and I shall deal with that problem in a moment.

As I said, the issue of privacy and the concerns in the community about privacy are of long standing and of growing concern. This has been revealed in the clearest possible terms in the great public debates that have taken place over the last year or so involving the Australia Card proposals and the tax file number proposal. It has clearly greatly concerned large numbers of Australians, who have expressed in no uncertain terms their feelings about this type of legislation. Australians are very concerned about the whole range of privacy matters, and these concerns have been given a sharp focus only as a result of the Government's proposal for the Australia Card which it first introduced a couple of years ago.

The debate on these subjects has been going on for a long time, but there are many other matters about which people are worrying in relation to privacy. Those concerns have no doubt arisen because of the onset of the computer age and the fact that the Orwellian nightmare has now become a reality. The computer age has enabled a vast amount of information to be easily stored and exchanged, to be penetrated in many cases by people who have no authority to have it and to be used by people who have it without regard to the reasons why they have it. The very ease with which information can be exchanged and collected about a particular target has no doubt given this very sharp point to the problem of privacy. Therefore, I believe that we as parliamentarians have a responsibility to address the concerns of so many Australians on the subject.

There is no doubt in my mind that Australians believe that they have a right to privacy. I dare say many people who have thought about it in the past would have taken that view. The onset of those events has led to a much wider concern about this matter in the community. It comes at a time when people have developed a very healthy scepticism about governments and bureaucracies and what they are up to in regard to these matters. That has added even further importance to taking action about the problem.

We have a situation where people demand a right to privacy. This has been denied to them by the common law and has only been partly addressed by parliaments in certain pieces of legislation. The most notable example of Parliament having recognised a right to privacy is shown in a section of the Income Tax Assessment Act, which imposes an obligation of secrecy on the officers of the Taxation Office-with some exceptions, of course-in relation to tax information. The success of taxation commissioners and the Taxation Office has developed a very notable standard of observance of that secrecy provision. There is a general confidence in Australia that taxation information has been kept secret. That is another reason why Australians are very worried about the dissemination of the tax file number. It is seen by them as the ways and means of breaching those secrecy provisions, although there are protections against that occurring. It is important and people do demand that type of secrecy which is contained in this legislation. There are other examples of this; I mentioned this only by way of example. This has been a concern for many years. It has been addressed in a piecemeal fashion in various different laws that have been passed by this Parliament.

What we are now talking about is a more general right of privacy and how it may be protected. It is unfortunate that the common law has not developed a right of privacy. Like parliaments, it has dealt with certain questions that have arisen, including defamation laws. Laws which are now developing in relation to protecting confidences are in place. Like the common law, they are the subject of development from time to time. There has not been a general right of privacy in the common law, nor have we in Parliament addressed the question until this parti- cular Bill.

Unfortunately, this legislation has been rushed through the Parliament. It was introduced into the House of Representatives on 1 November and debated on 2 November. Admittedly, it had been given to the shadow Attorney-General a few days earlier and had been considered by the shadow Cabinet but it was not available to members or senators before it was introduced into the House of Representatives. That means that it was introduced in conjunction with the tax file number system proposal. The general attention in this debate has been more on that legislation than on the detailed provisions of the Privacy Bill. It is quite disgraceful on the part of the Government that it has taken this cavalier attitude to such an important problem.

The Privacy Bill, which I support, does have major benefits in that it introduces a number of information privacy principles which are set out in the legislation. It establishes a watchdog on privacy known as a Privacy Commissioner. It gives that person a great many powers. It gives people some limited remedies in relation to breaches of privacy that is created in that legislation. It applies only to information about individuals which is held by Commonwealth agencies-that is, agencies of the Commonwealth Government, including departments, statutory authorities and so on. It also applies to the tax file number information that may be obtained by people in the private sector or by private individuals under the tax file number scheme. We know that employers, banks, financial institutions and so on will be in possession of that information. It applies in a limited sense to the private sector. Essentially, it is legislation which applies to the Commonwealth. It does not apply to the State governments. It does not apply generally to information that is held about people in the private sector. Although this is a reasonable beginning and we support it for that reason, it is nevertheless not adequate. The report of the Australian Law Reform Commission clearly indicated that the problem was a much wider one than information held by governments, serious as that may be. It is a problem which is much wider than that which is addressed in this legislation.

I am well aware that there are certain limitations on the powers of this Parliament under the Constitution to deal generally with the problem of privacy. I am also well aware of the fact that there are countervailing questions. When a person claims that he has the right to privacy about a particular matter or particular information there are some countervailing considerations which have to be taken into account.

Numbers of people are entitled to have such information. Employers are entitled to have information about people they are proposing to employ or they are already employing. Credit agencies and credit providers are entitled to have information about people to whom they give credit. The main concern that people have is that information is being obtained and held about them which may not be correct. The second concern is that a lot of information may be held about them by people who have no real interest in the information and are going to use it for improper purposes or give it to other people to use for improper purposes. I do not suggest that all of these problems should have been tackled in this legislation. It may well be a matter which can be built on over time.

I do not notice anything in the record of this Government, nor do I notice anything in what has been said by Government speakers in this debate, which indicates that the Government is doing anything more in relation to this matter than bringing forward this legislation as a means of getting the tax file number system through the Parliament. Clearly, the Government ought to be discussing these matters with the State governments because if there is going to be some general right of privacy it is a matter which will need to be widespread in Australia and which will need uniform legislation brought in by State governments. State governments ought to be encouraged by the Government to provide decent privacy legislation in relation to its own information that it is storing, the same as applies in relation to Commonwealth agencies. I would like the Government to indicate whether it will seriously pursue these matters. The Standing Committee of Attorneys-General is a very appropriate body to look at uniform legislation to protect individuals' rights. I would like to know whether the Government is pursuing this through that channel in regard to uniform laws that would apply widely through the private sector and in regard to information held by State governments.

The Bill contains a provision to set up a Privacy Advisory Committee. The terms of reference of that committee do not seem to adequately address the questions I have raised. I believe that the time has come for some general right of privacy to be recognised by our law. It will probably have to be recognised by Parliament. The impetus will have to come from Parliament because I think the common law has run out of steam in that regard. As I said, it is a pity the common law did not develop it because it would have been better to have developed it in the way the common law proceeds by dealing with individual cases as they arise over a period and thereby developing certain principles which can be applied to later cases. I do not generally favour Parliament bringing in detailed legislation containing a lot of bureaucratic structures and providing the sort of complicated detail that occurs with legislation. I am certainly conscious of the problem, but I would like some assurance that the Government is seriously prepared to look at the matter to see whether it can come forward with further solutions than are contained in this Bill.

I have some concerns about certain aspects of the present Bill, and in particular about the structure of the Privacy Commissioner and his great and diverse functions and as to the remedies that will be available under the legislation. The remedies here relate only to the limited areas I have mentioned-namely, information held by Commonwealth agencies and those who have the tax file number information. Some remedies are given, but it would have been far better if a general remedy had been granted for people to be able to take proceedings in the courts if they believed that the information privacy principles had been breached by Commonwealth agencies or by people in possession of a tax file number. Although the Bill contains limited rights, they fall very far short of that general right. I am pleased to note that the Opposition will be moving amendments in this House to take care of that problem so far as it can.

The fact remains that there is a confusion of roles in relation to the Privacy Commissioner. His functions are most diverse and cover large administrative responsibilities, such as research into and monitoring developments in data processing and computer technology, and the function of advising the Minister about various matters relating to privacy. Also involved is the question of promoting privacy principles in the community and educating people about those principles. Furthermore, there is a responsibility to conduct information audits and also to encourage the private sector to develop systems of privacy of information, which is itself a huge problem to which I have already alluded.

In addition to all these diverse functions, the Privacy Commissioner is obliged to investigate complaints about breaches of the legislation. As I understand it, he can call compulsory conferences to try to resolve complaints, presumably by conciliation, mediation and so forth. At the same time this person is given the responsibility, if that does not succeed, to proceed in a quasi-judicial way to determine and resolve any complaint. He can give remedies, pronounce that conduct should not continue and can give people compensation and costs. There are some odd statements as to how he can direct people to perform certain reasonable acts-what lawyers would call remedy of specific performance, which always presents some enforcement problems.

This seems to me to present a confusion of roles and a basic lack of conceptual thought by the Government about this important aspect of the legislation. I believe that there are better precedents for dealing with matters in this type of legislation in the race discrimination and sex discrimination fields, where there has at least been some semblance of separating the functions-the administrative, investigative, conciliation and mediation functions, which may appropriately be those of the Privacy Commissioner, from the actual adjudication of complaints and decisions as to whether there has been a breach and the granting of remedies. It is beyond the Opposition, except by way of numerous amendments, to fix up this problem. I hope that the Government will re-examine the matter.

When this legislation is enacted and the Privacy Commissioner is in business, I am sure that many problems will arise because of the creation of this bureaucratic structure. Certainly Opposition senators have had no time to study this matter in full. Clearly, the Taxation Laws Amendment (Tax File Numbers) Bill must be passed with the Privacy Bill. Indeed, the Government has brought in the two Bills together and the Senate is debating them together, despite the fact that they relate to two large serious and important subjects.

In supporting this legislation with some misgivings in relation to both Bills, I welcome the privacy initiative. I believe that the Government is to be given some praise for the fact that it has at last now introduced a first step-and it can only be regarded as that-in giving effect to that general right of privacy which such vast numbers of Australians today believe they should have, and indeed demand that governments and parliaments accord to them.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cooney Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Durack devoted his speech to the question of privacy, as was proper, and challenged this side of the House with the proposition that the Government has introduced the Privacy Bill as a means of getting through the Taxation Laws Amendment (Tax File Numbers) Bill. He suggested that the Government's only interest in the affair is that more revenue should be brought into the Commonwealth coffers. As a matter of reality, the Government has looked at the question of privacy and is the first government in Australia to bring in comprehensive privacy legislation.
—And the first government to get a report on it.

—And the first government to get a report on it-and a very good report it was. Following Senator Durack's remarks and taking up his challenge that the Government is more interested in the collection of revenue than in the privacy of the citizen, it is worth going through the Bill and seeing what it provides for. It seeks to stop unwarranted interference in people's privacy. It is true, as Senator Durack said, that the Bill is limited in its cover. It does not stop State governments or the private sector interfering with people's privacy unless that interference arises consequent on the operation of the proposed tax file number. There is good reason for that-not the least being the Constitution and its provisions. Clause 13 of the Privacy Bill defines the areas within which the legislation purports to operate. It says:

SPEECH.PARA: For the purposes of this Act, an act or practice is an interference with the privacy of an individual if, and only if, the act or practice: (a) in the case of an act or practice engaged in by an agency . . .

I interpose that agencies are confined to Government bodies-either departments or government instrumentalities. Agencies as defined do not go beyond the Commonwealth Government and its instrumentalities. Paragraph (b) reads:
in the case of an act or practice engaged in by an agency . . . breaches an Information Privacy Principle-
I will turn briefly to information privacy principles later-
in relation to personal information that relates to the individual
in the case of an act or practice engaged in by a file number recipient-
that is, a tax file number recipient, under the tax file number legislation-
breaches a guideline under section 17 in relation to tax file number information that relates to the individual; or
involves an unauthorised requirement or request for disclosure of the tax file number of the individual.

In effect, the Privacy Bill takes on board two streams of information. There are the provisions directed at protecting privacy in the use of the proposed tax file number and there are provisions safeguarding other information about people that the Commonwealth and its instrumentalities hold. Sanctions for the breach of proposed laws protecting tax file information are more stringent than those protecting other forms of information kept by the Government. For example, the provisions in clause 26 of the Taxation Laws Amendment (Tax File Numbers) Bill relating to a breach of a person's privacy are quite stringent.

The reason for that is that the Commonwealth has more power to regulate the information that it accumulates under the tax file legislation than it has in respect of other information that comes within its power. That is because the Constitution gives the Commonwealth more extensive power in legislating to protect the tax file number information than in other areas. I want to make it clear, in light of what Senator Durack said, that the Commonwealth has limited power in protecting private information about people but, in so far as it has that power, it has exercised it to the fullest extent possible. Where it has considerably more power, as in the case of the tax file number, than it has in respect of other information that comes within its keeping, it has brought in stricter sanctions than would otherwise apply. That is an indication of its dedication to the privacy of the Australian citizen. Hopefully, arising out of this legislation, other governments in Australian will follow down the line which the Commonwealth has marked, or go down the path that it has already gone down, because privacy should be an essential feature of the society in which we live.

Senator Durack spoke about the Privacy Commissioner and was critical, to some extent, of the Commissioner's functions. The office of Privacy Commissioner is set up under clause 19 of the Bill. Clause 36 gives any individual, any citizen of Australia, the right to complain about interference with his or her privacy, so long as that interference is of the sort defined in clause 13; that is, it has to be an interference with the privacy that he or she can expect in respect of information supplied to government.

I spoke of the information privacy principles. They are set in clause 14. They define the way in which information coming into the hands of the Commonwealth Government should be dealt with. Those privacy principles are supplemented, in respect of the tax file number information, or any information coming into the Government's hands under the tax file number scheme, by clause 17 of the Bill, which obliges the Privacy Commissioner to set out in writing guidelines concerning the collection, storage, use and security of tax file number information. Those guidelines are subject to disallowance by either House of the Parliament under the Acts Interpretation Act.

The Government has sought to give Parliament the right to oversee guidelines in respect of information coming into government hands-that is, the tax file number information-and it has sought to provide tests, through the information privacy principles, as to how other information should be sought. The Opposition, through Senator Durack, has said that this Government is not concerned fundamentally with privacy questions. However, the provisions of the legislation indicate that it is a well thought out scheme, a scheme dedicated, uniquely in Australia among the governments of Australia, to the preservation of people's privacy, to the establishment of tests which will be applied to people in government who have information about citizens coming into their hands, and it provides remedies for people if that information is surrendered where it should not be surrendered.

Senator Durack spoke about the Commissioner's functions and said that they were too broad. That was the general thrust of what he said. The functions are set out in clause 27 of the Bill. As there are several I will not read through them. However, some should be chosen for particular mention. The clause states:
Subject to this Part, the Commissioner has the following functions:

(a) to investigate and act or practice of an agency that may breach an Information Privacy Principle and, where the Commissioner considers it appropriate to do so, to endeavour, by conciliation, to effect a settlement of the matters that gave rise to the investigation . . .

If conciliation is not successful he can even go ahead and make a declaration that a person whose privacy has been violated should receive some sort of compensation and that declaration can be enforced in the Federal Court. Other functions set out in clause 27 include the provision that the Commissioner should promote an understanding and acceptance of the information privacy principles and of the objects of those principles; that he should provide advice to a Minister or an agency on any matter relevant to the operation of the proposed Act; and that he should conduct audits of records of personal information maintained by agencies for the purpose of ascertaining whether the records are maintained according to the information privacy principles.

It is worth repeating that this legislation will, if passed, give limited but nevertheless comprehensive protection to people's privacy. Hopefully, it will provide-I agree with Senator Durack on this-a precedent that will be expanded upon and adopted by other governments. It is a Bill that can be, I think, legitimately criticised in the ambit of its operation, but against that it is a Bill which has blazed a new trail. It should be said that the Privacy Commissioner will operate through the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission. That provision is part of a package of measures aimed at helping people protect their privacy.

The information privacy principles are set out in clause 14 of the Bill. Those principles are akin to the guidelines on the protection of privacy and the transborder flows of personal data developed by the Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development (OECD) in Paris in 1981. The interesting thing is that the OECD guidelines are not confined to information held by government. Even though this Privacy Bill deals only with information held by or originating with government, plus information relevant to the tax file number scheme, and even though the information privacy principles set out in clause 14 of the Bill are confined to that purpose, they are based on the OECD guidelines, which, in turn, are not confined to government. Those guidelines are expressed generally. That is apt, because a person's privacy can be prejudiced by the private sector as well as the public one. It can be prejudiced just as much by a State government or a local council as it can by a Federal government. Hurt to people through a violation of their privacy can be gross, whether inflicted by public servants or officers of a private company.

In that context, it is often said that people who have nothing to hide have nothing to fear from having their lives laid bare. I often think that that statement presumes that those receiving information about others will treat it fairly, will judge it accurately and will use it honourably. It is presumed that revelations about people will be reported fully or, if selectively, kindly. I will not give examples, but people in this chamber will know that over the years this has just not been so. People's reputations and lives can be quite dramatically influenced and, in many cases, ruined because of statements that are made about them. Had some respect been paid to their privacy, their feelings and their right to a good reputation unless it could be conclusively proved otherwise, many a reputation that has been besmirched would not have been treated in such a way. People's reputations have been besmirched in this place, in other parliaments, in courts, in royal commissions, in judicial inquiries and in the media. They can be besmirched in conversations in all sorts of places, even in people's neighbourhoods by those who are supposed to be friends.

Senator Durack touched on this matter, saying that the common law does not afford a right to privacy, and that is correct. I also agree with him that it is bad and a tragedy that it does not. We probably do not have time to deal now with the question of why a concept of privacy has not been developed in the common law, but I think it is a question that should be dealt with at some other time. In any event, that lack in the common law ought to be progressively remedied from here on in.

As I have already indicated, some people believe that privacy can at times be quite nonchalantly compromised. It is argued that people should not worry about that because if they have nothing to hide they have nothing to lose. I have already said that that is a proposition that does not bear close examination. In the general context of the right that we should have to lead our lives as best we are able without undue interference or unwarranted intrusion from outside, the Privacy Bill is one of a number of measures which both sides of the political fence in this Parliament have sought to do something about over the years. In this respect, I am talking about a package of Bills to which the Privacy Bill will be an honourable addition. This package includes legislation such as the Freedom of Information Acts which was passed under the previous Government; the Ombudsman Act 1976; the Administrative Decisions (Judicial Review) Act; the Administrative Appeals Tribunal Act; the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission Act 1986; and the Merit Protection (Australian Government Employees) Act 1984. So there is a package of legislation aimed at giving people protection against the intrusions of government.

As I say, I think the great lack in this area lies in the fact that, although people are protected to some extent from intrusions of government, they are not sufficiently protected from intrusions by organisations which may have information about them stored in databanks, which may be able to interfere with their private lives and which may, to their ruin, talk about matters which they, as victims, cannot correct sufficiently. I think it is time that State governments, which can legislate in this area, looked at how people can be affected by the private sector and brought in legislation in that regard.

Senator Durack has criticised the Labor Government for not going far enough in its actions to protect people, but what would the position be if the coalition were now in power? What would it do about the rights of citizens? What would it do about providing freedom of information (FOI) legislation, privacy legislation and equal opportunity legislation if it had the opportunity? In that respect, I notice that the Greiner Government, which has now been in power for a significant period, promised that it would introduce freedom of information legislation when it took office. Indeed, it did introduce a draft form of legislation. But that, for whatever reason, has been put over now for consideration next year.
Tim Robertson of the New South Wales Council for Civil Liberties had some comments to make about the proposed freedom of information legislation in New South Wales. On 21 September 1988 he said:
Freedom of information is about power. When a Government resolves to introduce a Freedom of Information regime it is involved in the process of power sharing.
That is correct. But later in his address he had this to say about the New South Wales legislation:

I referred earlier to the possible consequence of a good FOI law, one that recognised that the devolution of power from the Government to the citizen was an important value. There are four provisions of this Bill-
that is, the New South Wales Bill-
which, taken together or severally, will prevent this law from achieving that purpose.
that is, the purpose of devolving power from the Government to the citizen. He continued:
Briefly, they are the provisions for charging,-
that is, for imposing a charge on people who want to make use of the freedom of information legislation-
the power of Ministers to give a conclusive certificate in relation to restricted documents,-

In other words, under the draft legislation, as I understand it, the Ministers will be able to give a conclusive certificate which cannot be challenged in any court or similar tribunal about whether the documents ought to be revealed under FOI or not. He continued:
the absence of any requirement to give adequate reasons for refusing access to documents-
that is a provision one would have hoped would have been there; that if somebody is going to be refused access to documents, some explanation should be given to him or her-

and the power to refuse to process complex FOI requests if, in the opinion of the agency concerned, it would involve too much work to do so. The last ground for refusing to deal with FOI users is a favourite one with the Federal Government.

I do not want it to be alleged that I have not quoted fully. What is shown by Jim Robertson's address is that when the Liberal Party and the National Party of Australia have the power to introduce legislation of a category in which the Privacy Bill which we are presently debating would fit, firstly they are very circumspect about doing so; and secondly, the legislation that they do introduce is very restrictive in the rights it gives to the citizen. So when criticism in this chamber is made of the Bill by those in Opposition, I challenge the Opposition to indicate why we on this side should expect that it would act any differently from how Mr Greiner has acted in New South Wales in respect of the freedom of information legislation which he trumpeted about so proudly before he was elected to office. Contrast that to the freedom of information legislation that was introduced in Victoria when the Cain Labor Government came to power. The contrast is striking. That is an Act which is very generous to the private citizen. It has a public interest provision which overrides any objection that might otherwise be made-in other words, even in the case of documents which prima facie are restricted and cannot be made available to somebody seeking them under the freedom of information legislation in Victoria, if a person can show an overriding public interest, then those documents are made available. The contrast between the legislation in Victoria and the proposed legislation in New South Wales is marked.

So the criticism that comes from the other side, that this Privacy Bill is simply a mechanism or instrument to get the tax file number legislation through the Parliament, cannot, on examination, be sustained. Indeed, if one looks at the very detailed provisions in the Privacy Bill and at the very severe penalties attached to breaches of the law regarding the tax file number in the tax file numbers Bill itself, it becomes apparent that this is a Government which is very serious about privacy, very serious about the rights of citizens and very serious about maintaining those broad freedoms which we enjoy in our society.

I am glad that the Opposition has joined the Government in supporting this legislation. I hope with some confidence that the provisions in the legislation will expand over the years and that the guidance and the lead given by the Federal Government will be adopted by the State governments as time goes by because privacy is something that is very much worth while protecting and it should become an entitlement which we can all enjoy. I hope the legislation will ultimately prevent people being blackguarded, from having their reputations besmirched and from suffering hardships to themselves and their families in the way that happens all too often in this society at the moment. I think there is time to look at where we are going as a society and to draw back from the readiness we seem to have to ruin reputations.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coulter Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is interesting that the previous speakers in this debate from both sides of the House have drawn particular attention to the need to protect the privacy of ordinary citizens. As honourable senators will have noticed, the Australian Democrats are moving an amendment to the motion for the second reading, an attachment to the motion, because we believe that by quite a simple mechanism a much more effective protection of privacy could have been achieved but both the Government and the Opposition have failed to take up this very simple device.

SPEECH.PARA: This evening we are debating the Taxation Laws Amendment (Tax File Numbers) Bill and the accompanying Privacy Bill which seeks to protect the privacy of individuals. The tax file number is being created as a high integrity number so that financial transactions information involving citizens, transactions which are tax relevant, can be reliably linked to that high integrity tax file number and through that mechanism citizens will be prevented from evading tax. Of course, the Democrats are wholly in favour of such a procedure. The procedure involves an improvement in the integrity of the tax file number so that every individual will have only one tax file number, and that number will be linked to every transaction which is tax relevant.

The other matter we are debating this afternoon is that that process shall not involve an invasion of the privacy of that individual. Once one has a number with a very high integrity, which is linked to an individual and which links that individual with a number of financial transactions, the provision of that number leaves that individual open, through the great capacity which is now available in computers, even at the home computer level, to the possibility that that information could be abused and misused. It could be to the detriment of individuals if that high integrity number should fall into the hands of those who have no business to have it. The Democrats are proposing that that number should be known only to the individual and to the Australian Taxation Office, and that that is quite easily achievable.

As Senator Cooney has already indicated, information can readily be linked from different sources through the use of that universal identifier-that high integrity tax file number. People can draw quite wrong conclusions from linking those bits of information and those wrong conclusions can be readily promulgated. The individual need have very little knowledge of who has put that information together and where that false conclusion has emanated from to that person's detriment.

Let me give an example which demonstrates the point quite easily. During the last election I asked a number of friends to provide me with names and addresses of people who may be sympathetic to my election to this Parliament. Through that process I accumulated a database in my home computer which involved several thousand names and addresses. It was very easily done. I did not want to send information unnecessarily to the same address to service several people, so through a couple of quite simple key strokes I asked my computer to put together the names of all those people who lived at the one address. Within a few seconds I had those names and addresses on the screen. I was quite interested and surprised to find out certain information. `He is living with her, I didn't know that', and `He's living with him'. Knowing certain other bits of information about the people concerned, I might have drawn some conclusions which may have been correct or incorrect. Certainly, I could have used that information in ways which could have been damaging to those individuals. That is a very small example with a home computer which can be done very easily.

Once one links that type of information, information on health and all the tax relevant information with this high integrity identifier-the tax file number-the possibility for misuse becomes extremely wide and extremely worrying. I do not think that honourable senators in this place realise the increase in the power of modern computers, which is developing very quickly. For instance, it is now possible to have on a home computer information on every citizen in Australia. That is quite achievable with a computer costing not much more than several thousand dollars. If one allows that, information on a person's tax file number will very quickly become available, and that becomes a very powerful tool in the hands of a large number of people in the community.

The task which the Australian Democrats set themselves was very interesting. It was an attempt to devise a scheme which would allow everybody to have this high integrity tax file number so that anti-tax evasion requirements could be met and, at the same time, ensure that that tax file number was known only to the individual and the Tax Office. Such a scheme is very easy to devise. We are extremely disappointed to find that the Government has not adopted that scheme and that the Opposition is not prepared to support it.

The scheme would work like this: when an individual went into a bank or to a potential employer-in fact, was about to enter any transaction which was tax relevant-the individual would be asked to provide certain information. That information would be provided on a form with several carbon copies. Imagine a person was opening a bank account. The bank would ask for certain information to be provided by the individual opening the bank account. The bank would then send the second copy-the carbon copy-of that form to the Tax Office. The other carbon copies would be provided to the individual who opened the account. The individual would simply provide the tax file number on the next carbon copy, so that all the information which was already entered on the form would still be there, plus the tax file number in this case. The individual would then provide that copy to the Tax Office and the Tax Office would simply marry those two forms. When the Tax Office had the information relating to the opening of the bank account together with the tax file number, it would notify the bank that it had the tax file number for that person and that there was no need to withdraw tax at the maximum rate. In that simple way, the Tax Office would get the information it needed and the tax file number would be kept private to both the individual and the Tax Office. Nobody else would have access to that number.

Objections have been raised to such a scheme. It has been claimed that the Tax Office and the bank would be flooded with paper work. Again, I suggest that honourable senators in this place simply do not understand the way in which offices have become so extensively computerised. Most of this work would in fact be done by a computer. Already the Tax Office will have to receive notification from the bank when an account is opened. That form will go to the Tax Office anyway, but it will not be dealt with by the Tax Office by way of a piece of paper. As soon as information is received it will be entered into the Taxation Office computer.

Under the scheme I have just outlined, when the copy of that form sent by the person who has opened the bank account is sent to the Tax Office, it includes the tax file number. Again, a keyboard operator would simply enter that information directly into the Taxation Office computer; the matching would not be done by hand but by computer. The computer would immediately indicate that that information matched. If there were any difficulties-that would be a very small number of applications for employment, bank accounts and the like-the Tax Office would go back to the original forms and make sure that they did indeed match. If they did not, the bank would not be notified by the Tax Office that it had a satisfactory tax file number and tax would be withheld.

The other objection to the scheme has been raised, I think, by Senator Stone. He said there is not an absolute necessity to provide the tax file number; one can have tax withdrawn at the maximum rate and then, at the end of the year, through the processes of submitting taxation returns, groups certificates and the like, claim that tax back. That is a facility which is readily taken up by the rich in our society but not so readily taken up by the poor. That argument fails substantially on the grounds of equity. I simply point out that on my home computer I certainly keep extensive databases on a number of people. As soon as the tax file number becomes available and that falls into my hands, I will certainly use that as an identifier because it will be far more reliable than either an address or a name. That will happen throughout the community very quickly, both in State and in Commonwealth government departments. It will happen with private databanks and, of course, we are then right back to the situation which we attempted to avoid with the Australia Card legislation.

In conclusion, I point out that there is indeed a very simple mechanism by which the joint and laudable objectives of preventing tax evasion and also protecting the privacy of individuals can be achieved. It is simple, it is cheap, it is effective and it does not involve protecting the rich compared with the poor. I believe that we will very quickly live to regret the day that this Parliament did not impose onto this system the proposal which the Australian Democrats have put forward. It is for that reason that the Democrats will be moving the amendment to the motion for the second reading to which I referred earlier. All we can say is that we are disappointed that the amendments which would have given effect to our proposal have not been supported by either the Government or the Opposition.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill Sen R.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —In this debate on the Government's Taxation Laws Amendment (Tax File Numbers) Bill and the Privacy Bill, I want to concentrate on the latter. As has been said by previous speakers, the Opposition is supporting both Bills, although we will certainly be looking to some amendments to the Privacy Bill at the committee stage. We agreed to support the tax file numbers system Bill when it became, in effect, a voluntary scheme and, furthermore, when we were satisfied that an adequate privacy Bill was being put before the Parliament, the operation of which would commence at the same time as the tax file system. It took some effort before the Government was prepared to meet that objective. Nevertheless, it was achieved and therefore, as has been previously said, the Opposition is supporting both Bills.

SPEECH.PARA: I suppose any discussion of privacy should start with article 17 of the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights, which came into force on 23 March 1976. The key provision of the Covenant, article 17, states:
No-one shall be subjected to arbitrary or unlawful interference with his privacy, family, home or correspondence, not to unlawful attacks on his honour and reputation.
Everyone has the right to the protection of the law against such interference or attacks.

That is a laudable objective which we on this side of the chamber would obviously support and objectives that were based on the 1948 Universal Declaration of Human Rights. I guess the next stage in the development of privacy as an international concept is the role that has been taken by the Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development (OECD), and as is stated in the Bill itself, Australia has agreed to the guidelines set out by the council when it recommended that member countries take into account in their domestic legislation certain principles concerning the protection of privacy and individual liberties. Of course, in some part this Bill is based upon those guidelines and recommendations.

For some time there have been those learned within our community exhorting us to take action in relation to a lack of provision within the Commonwealth law protecting personal privacy. I will only mention the contribution that was made by Sir Zelman Cowen. I refer in particular to his Boyer Lectures of 1969 in which he examined the manifold threat to the privacy of the individual that has existed in this century and suggested how, as a society, we should face this problem as a matter of social policy and law. He quoted the American writer Clinton Rossiter as saying:

Privacy is a special kind of independence which can be understood as an attempt to secure autonomy in at least a few personal and spiritual concerns, if necessary in defiance of all the pressures of modern society . . . it seeks to erect an unbreakable wall of dignity and reserve against the entire world. The free man is the private man.
He concluded with these words:

The protection of privacy would be better assured by appropriate legal protections and procedures, but it also depends to a very great extent upon the attitudes of men and women in a democratic society to the values which are enshrined in the claim to privacy. It seems to me that in our lack of awareness and indifference, our responses to the growing threats to privacy are too often feeble and flabby . . . we cannot assume that privacy will survive simply because man has a psychological or social need for it.

I think that they are words that we should heed. They were certainly heeded by this side of the chamber when the former coalition Attorney-General, Mr Ellicott, referred to the Australian Law Reform Commission a reference to examine the question of privacy, which reference, was referred, I think, in 1976, but it was not until 1983 that the Law Reform Commission put down its three-volume report, and it has taken from 1983 until now, in late 1988, for this Bill to appear. Nevertheless, better late than never. We, on this side of the chamber, are pleased that with our support and our contribution-I will detail that in a few moments-we are now going to be enacting through this Parliament privacy legislation. We believe that that is an important achievement.

Of course, Australia will not be the first of the Western nations to have gone down this path; in fact, we lag behind quite a few of them. For example, I note that the Federal Republic of Germany passed its Federal Data Protection Act in 1977. Sweden, which I understand was the first country to pass this type of legislation, passed its Data Act in 1973. France passed its law on information, databanks and freedoms in 1978. The United Kingdom's Data Protection Act became law in July 1984. Part IV of the Canadian Human Rights Act of 1977 also gives some protections in this regard. So we are moving down a path that has been taken by a number of the Western democratic nations, and although we might be a little behind some of them, we in the Opposition are pleased that it is now occurring.

What I wanted to do at this stage is very briefly look at the structure of the Bill. I will be brief because it has also been covered by other speakers. Basically the Bill will establish the office of a Privacy Commissioner within the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission and the Commissioner will be empowered to take privacy protection measures in relation to the Commonwealth departments and agencies and tax file number users. The Bill establishes rules of conduct called information privacy principles (IPPs) for the collection, retention, access to, correlation, use, et cetera, of personal information about individuals. As I said a moment ago, in part based on the guidelines provided by the OECD the Bill treats breaches of these IPPs as an interference with privacy. Commonwealth agencies are required to avoid doing things which amount to interferences with privacy.

With regard to remedy in case of breach, the Privacy Commissioner is first instructed by the legislation to look to a resolution by conciliation. We support that. However, if that does not prove possible, he can then make determinations that could include a declaration that an agency which has breached the IPP should not repeat such conduct and/or that the agency should pay damages by way of compensation and also meet any expenses that have been suffered by the individual concerned. In addition, the Privacy Commissioner will be empowered to investigate complaints concerning the misuse of tax file numbers in the public and private sectors. We also support that. In relation to abuses, again, the Privacy Commissioner is given a responsibility first to attempt to conciliate but, subject to the failure of that, to make determinations which might be enforceable in the Federal Court of Australia.

We are pleased that the Bill now includes interim guidelines in relation to the tax file number system which must be adhered to by agencies and recipients of tax file information. Of course, the Bill did not originally include such a provision. Just for a moment I want to put the Bill in the context of a series of events. When the Government's identity card, the so-called Australia Card, failed last year, with it failed the 1986 Privacy Bill. The Government decided, and stated in the May economic statement, that it would, as an alternative go down the path of a tax file number scheme. What the Treasurer (Mr Keating) did not say in the May economic statement or in the expansion that concerned tax file numbers, which included the business part of the supplements to that statement, was whether there would be any separate privacy legislation at all. One can presume that at that time the Government, in any event the Treasurer, did not intend to go down the path of legislation that we now have before the Parliament.

The next stage in the scenario, particularly after that point had been made publicly and objected to by a number of commentators, was that the Treasurer stressed in a press release of 14 June 1988 that there would be adequate, strict privacy safeguards within the tax file legislation itself. Again, when in due course the Taxation Laws Amendment (Tax File Numbers) Bill 1988 appeared, in the first instance that seemed to be the direction which the Government was still taking, except that the Treasurer, again after being pressed, indicated that the Attorney-General (Mr Lionel Bowen) would be preparing a Privacy Bill. It was not intended, however, to be part of this package. Even when the Attorney-General himself subsequently made reference to the Bill which he was preparing he said that it was to be supplementary and introduced and dealt with at a subsequent time.

The Opposition found that totally unsatisfactory. As honourable senators will be aware, the Opposition insisted that if we were to deal with tax file number legislation we would expect to deal with a Privacy Bill at the same time. As that also appeared to be the attitude of the Australian Democrats, the Government had little alternative but to cooperate with our demands. Of course, Senator Tate, acting for the Attorney-General who was overseas, produced a draft Bill that was given to Mr Neil Brown, our shadow Attorney-General, for his consideration. That Bill, as is now history, was found to be significantly deficient and caused the Opposition to write to Senator Tate setting out a series of very significant criticisms; setting out the major shortfalls that were obvious from a perusal of the Government's intended Privacy Bill-what the Government intended to become the privacy law for this Commonwealth. For example, there were no specific provisions in the Bill for privacy of tax file number information. The Bill provided only for guidelines to be issued at some time in the future by the Privacy Commissioner. Even then, it was the case only that they may be issued by him; not that they shall be issued by him. Government agencies were to be able to obtain exemption from such guidelines on the ground of public interest. It does not take much experience to see the enormous loophole that could be presented by that exemption. No complaint could be made to the Privacy Commissioner for the first six months. What was to happen in the first six months was that the government agencies were to have the opportunity to apply for exemption on the ground of public interest. Again, the scenario that would have developed was quite apparent from a reading of the Bill; departments would have used that six months to apply for exemption, they would have demonstrated that it was in the public interest, as so many government departments do so easily, to justify exchange of personal information between them.
