That experience would have recurred in this instance.

The Bill provided also that the Privacy Commissioner could enter premises of Government agencies, but only on notice. Of course, that caused us to ask why the Privacy Commissioner's powers were to be weaker than those of the Commonwealth Ombudsman. There was no right given in the Bill to sue for privacy-something I will come to in a moment-and, of course, we criticised the fact that the injunctive power simply was not wide enough. We also criticised the fact that the tax file number legislation was to come into operation on receiving royal assent but that the Privacy Bill was to come into operation only on proclamation. Therefore, even at that stage, on the production of the draft Bill, it seemed that the privacy legislation was to come into operation at a later date-something that we regarded as unsatisfactory. There was no objects provision in the Bill showing clearly what the Government was trying to achieve. Principles 10 and 11 which were said to provide an exemption for the protection of public revenue obviously again showed a serious deficiency and a serious escape mechanism. The requirements on the Privacy Commissioner to report to the Parliament were inadequate.

That was the form of the Bill that was presented to the Opposition and which the Government, if it had had the numbers, would have passed through this Parliament. It was a very significantly deficient piece of legislation. I am pleased to be able to say-no doubt it only follows from the fact that the Government has not got the numbers-that most of these criticisms we made were then addressed positively by it. In other words, the Government recognised that it simply would not get its tax file number legislation unless it ensured that the public was protected against the abuse of information, particularly tax file information, through an adequate form of privacy legislation. As I said, most of the recommendations that were made were accepted. Because they were accepted we indicated that we would therefore support the legislation before the chamber.

There are two remaining areas in which we indicate now, as we indicated in the House of Representatives, additional amendment is required, in our view, to make the Bill satisfactory to be passed. The first relates to the question of remedies, something that I mentioned a moment ago. We on this side of the chamber believe that there should be provision in the Bill to enable a citizen who has suffered an invasion of his or her privacy to seek damages in the common-law courts. We believe that the remedies that are contained in the Bill as it stands at the moment are inadequate.

The second area in which we say that there should be further amendment relates to appeals to the Administrative Appeals Tribunal (AAT). The Bill as it stands gives a respondent the power to seek a review of an order for compensation and/or expenses, but there is no power for the AAT to give compensation in the event of the Commissioner determining not to give that compensation. We cannot see why private individuals in this country should not be treated in the same way as governments in being able to utilise the provisions of the AAT in this way, and we will therefore be seeking to amend the Bill.

In those two areas we will be seeking in the committee stage to have amendments passed that we believe will result in a better piece of legislation. Having said that, we do not claim that the Bill that is in the process of being passed is perfect. We are aware that a number of civil liberty organisations around the country would like to see changes and further strengthening; nevertheless, it has been a long time in coming and we believe that, with the improvements we have been able to force upon the Government, it is a worthwhile starting piece of legislation in an area which is critically important and which the Opposition believes requires the support of government through legislation.

Those of us who served on the Senate Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs when it dealt with the whole question of the information that governments hold on individuals and the way in which governments so readily transmit that information between departments were somewhat shocked, firstly, by the enormous volume of personal information that is held, and, secondly, by the way in which that information is shunted from department to department, in effect building up very comprehensive information banks on individuals, that information often being of a very personal and private nature. Of course, governments now have the further capacity to compulsorily gain information from the private sector to add to those banks of information.

We on this side of the chamber strongly believe that it is necessary to have in place a piece of legislation that would in some ways protect individuals from abuse by government of personal information, and we believe that the Bill that will be passed in the next day or so is a very worthwhile step in the right direction in that regard.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brownhill Sen D.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Opposition has consistently made it clear that it is totally and utterly opposed to taxation fraud and welfare cheating. In fact, it was in October last year that the coalition parties said they would give full support to any reasonable measures which effectively eliminated tax fraud and which welfare cheating, which were cost effective and which did not unreasonably intrude upon personal privacy and individual liberties. At that stage we made it quite clear that we supported moves that would upgrade the integrity of the tax file number system and would consider favourably any proposals designed to improve the use of the tax file number for proper taxation and welfare purposes, such as those already provided for the Income Tax Assessment Act. However, we emphasised that we would vigorously oppose any attempt to turn a tax file number system into a de facto Australia Card system.

SPEECH.PARA: The essential purpose of this Bill is to improve the efficiency and effectiveness of the Australian Taxation Office's income matching system as a means of furthering the attack on tax evasion. There is no doubt that we reject all degrees of taxation fraud and welfare cheating. Our tax system is supposed to be built on the premise of equity, with every person paying his or her fair share of tax. If one person or one organisation does not pay his, her or its share, somebody else has to cover the payment of that tax.

To ensure that the tax file number system did not threaten civil liberties Mr Neil Brown, the shadow Attorney-General in the other House, insisted on a tightening of the secrecy provisions and the introduction by the Attorney-General (Mr Lionel Bowen) of separate privacy legislation. In addition, the Treasurer (Mr Keating) accepted many of our amendments and put it beyond doubt that the scheme would be completely voluntary-one of the things that Mr Brown was concerned about-while at the same time retaining the essence of a withholding tax where the tax payer chose not to quote his or her tax file number.

I congratulate Mr Neil Brown for conducting extensive negotiations with Senator Tate over the privacy legislation which has resulted, in my opinion, in the determination of adequate safeguards under the tax file number system. This system, as it now stands, after a series of amendments, does not threaten the civil liberties of any individual to any degree. Under the guidelines that have now been agreed to, people will have a tax file number which is not to be used as a national identification system by whatever means. The tax file number recipients are not to use the information for matching personal information about a person. They are not to use the information for unauthorised purposes such as the building up of a database on individuals or the cross-matching of information for non-tax purposes. Government agencies may not disclose tax file number information for cross-matching without parliamentary approval.

All these amendments, which Mr Brown brought in with the concurrence of the Government, have made this Bill a much better Bill than it was in the first instance. I am sure that many Australian citizens would be pleased to hear that a large number of Australians will not need to register for a tax file number at all. This legislation will go a long way towards catching some of the tax cheats in the community. I refer to another area that Mr Brown has made sure is covered properly. There are many people and numerous financial transactions and accounts in respect of which no quotation of the tax file number will be required. For example, it will not be necessary to use the tax file numbers for loan accounts of all descriptions, including mortgages, credit cards and leases. For existing-and I emphasise the word `existing'-interest-bearing accounts with banks, building societies and credit unions where the interest paid or credited each year remains below $120, it will not be needed. It is understood that about 70 per cent of accounts with building societies and credit unions fall below this level.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Australian Capital Territory: Self-Government-Australia Small Business Awards-Young Achievement Award-United States Election

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! It being 7.30 p.m., the debate is interrupted. Under sessional order, I put the question:

INTERJECT.PARA: That the Senate do now adjourn.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McMullan Sen R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak briefly about the question of self-government in the Australian Capital Territory (ACT). I am greatly disappointed that I have to rise to discuss it tonight because like many other people here in Canberra I had hoped that the matter could be discussed and resolved tomorrow. But now we have the situation where, as a consequence of decisions of the Australian Democrats and the Opposition parties, the Minister for the Arts and Territories, Mr Clyde Holding, has today issued a press release headed `ACT self-government in jeopardy'. He has said that the progress towards self-government has been placed in jeopardy and he is seeking urgent discussions to try to resolve it. I do not blame the Minister for that. I understand the circumstances that have led him to it.

SPEECH.PARA: We have had a situation for a lengthy period in which the Democrats have, under the guise of negotiation, refused to budge at all. We have had the situation where it has been extremely difficult for the Minister to find out what the policy of the Opposition parties has been, is or will be. I want to say a few things to those parties. I am not clear, after reading reports and hearing the news, about the position of the Opposition parties, although I am disappointed about the adjournment. I want to say to them, if it applies-and certainly to the Democrats-something about what I think needs to happen in the political negotiations. I have been involved in the business of political negotiations for a very long time. It seems to me that there are some things which some people have not learnt. One is that if one is negotiating one has to shift one's position from time to time. I found the frustration-and I know of two Ministers in the time that I have been here who have had the same concern-that each time the Labor Government makes concessions that concession is swallowed up. People say, `Thank you very much' and then reiterate their original position. They think that because they keep smiling while they are doing that that is what is called negotiation. It is only the 1986 butcher of self-government with a smiling face.

The original position of the Labor Government was for single member constituencies. That proved to be unacceptable so we made a concession and offered what became known as the Mackerras model, a combination of the House of Representatives and Senate models in one chamber. That was unacceptable and self-government was butchered. In 1988 we have the Government coming up with the proposed d'Hondt electoral system, then modifying it and modifying it again to meet various concerns and queries that have been raised. In all that time no agreement has been reached and there has been no indication that any movement at all from the other side is possible.

I remind the House of the statement made by the then Minister for Territories, Mr Gary Punch. He said, `We have shifted a mile on this; all we are asking you to do is come towards us one inch'. That remains the situation today. The alternative situation that is proposed, which is that the whole of the Assembly should be elected under the Senate system, can lead to the situation in a small chamber of 17 where the person with the sort of vote that former Senator Wood received-1.5 per cent of the vote-could wind up being the de facto government of the ACT, holding the balance of power. After the last Australian Capital Territory election held under that system the Chief Minister of the Australian Capital Territory, who was the leader on the Liberal ticket, received 25 per cent of the vote at that election. That is not a circumstance that I think is a reasonable proposition or something that the people of the ACT would lightly accept. The sort of instability that may well arise would give self-government in the Australian Capital Territory a bad name.

There have been some outrageous allegations made about the reasons why the Government is supporting the d'Hondt electoral system. I want to say only two things. Firstly, it is not the Labour Party's or the Government's preferred position. Our preferred position is single member constituencies. It is as far as we feel we can go towards balancing the reasonable objectives of having the composition of the Parliament reflect the wishes of the voters-which various other systems do but this does also-while creating the pre-conditions for a stable government that can give the people of the Australian Capital Territory the sort of government they deserve.

I simply want to warn those involved that although self-government has not had a stronger advocate than myself in the Australian Capital Territory-I supported it when I was the only one and I continue to support it in my Party and publicly-the people who are purporting to negotiate ought to remember that I do not support and no one in the Labour Party supports self-government at any price. They should not think that we can be forced to accept what we have said is unacceptable. We will go a long way. We have gone a long way. If there is no possibility of getting self-government with an electoral system that allows for stable government and reasonable representation I would support the view that the Labor Government should not proceed with the legislation. If we did we would have a tragedy, a re-run of 1986. I hope it never happens. I hope that good sense will prevail. I want to say to people that they should not take the flexibility and tolerance of the Government as a sign of weakness. They should not believe that because we have made a lot of concessions there are a lot more to come. We have almost reached the bottom of the barrel, if we have not already. I urge those people who are responsible in the other parties represented in this chamber to consider that and to come forward to accept a proposal for a reasonable compromise between the interests of all the parties that protects the best interests of the people of the Australian Capital Territory. I hope that can be reflected in the very early passage of a reasonable and agreed self-government package.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Reid Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I had intended to speak on another matter on the adjournment but I cannot let the remarks made by Senator McMullan pass without comment. He says that the self-government situation is in jeopardy. I find that totally surprising. I had taken the view at one time that the Australian Labor Party was not serious about self-government although in more recent times I have come to the view that it was. But with the threats that are being suggested now it makes me wonder whether I have been on the wrong path. Maybe Senator McMullan was not referring to the Liberal Party. I would hope that that would be the case because that would make more sense. Senator McMullan must know that only about 24 hours ago I-and I assume he and others-was handed a stack of amendments from the Australian Democrats. This was a pile of papers about an inch thick. This morning we were told that there are more amendments to come. I know that the Labor Party pushes legislation through the House of Representatives with absolutely no scrutiny whatsoever of any consequence but that is not the way we do things in the Senate. It would be irresponsible of all of us not to look at the amendments that are being proposed and not to look at all aspects of this very important matter which we are dealing with.

SPEECH.PARA: We are talking of setting up a government in the Australian Capital Territory (ACT). That is a matter which the Liberal Party is very strongly committed to and has been for a long time. We are equally determined to see that we set up something that is of value to the people of the Australian Capital Territory. Of course, it includes the electoral system. That is important, as Senator McMullan knows, as he referred to it. I shall come back to that. It includes a whole range of other activities and functions as well. The manner in which they are handed over needs to be looked at very carefully. For the consequence of what we are doing we have not had this legislation from the Government for very long at all. In regard to the electoral system Senator McMullan quoted the former Minister saying that the Labor Party had given a mile and all we had to do was give an inch. I do not know how we measure a mile or an inch in these terms. I also recognise that the single member electorate was the position from which the Labor Party first started. I take the view that it is important that we get an electoral system which reflects the views of the voters of the Australian Capital Territory. To best do that one would certainly look at the Senate electoral system. The Labor Party rejects that and we have been looking very closely at the modification of the d'Hondt system that the Government says it will now agree to. I believe an arrangement can be arrived at whereby the electoral system can be sorted out. It is not something that one just throws into the ring.

I would be surprised if Senator McMullan has not read sufficient material in the Canberra Times in recent weeks and months to know of the anxiety and concerns felt by a number of expert people about the electoral system and the fact that those with a small number of votes will be wiped out altogether. I recognise what he says the Labor Party is trying to do and Senator McMullan should recognise the Opposition's concerns on this matter. We have shifted a considerable degree in looking at the system as it now is. He knows that it has been modified significantly since the d'Hondt system proposal-a system which was strongly rejected by the electorate when it came up in the first place. I find this a funny place to be told about how we should go about negotiating, but again perhaps I will give the honourable senator the benefit of the doubt that he is not talking about us. I believe that we have been looking carefully and closely at the legislation which the Government has brought forward. We have looked very closely at the massive volume of legislation that the Democrats have brought forward this week. We do not take the view that it should be rejected out of hand and not looked at at all. It may be that we will reject it, but I believe that we should read it first. I was surprised that it arose tonight in this fashion, but as the President did not rule the matter out of order, I thought that I, too, should respond.

I wish now to come to the matter on which I intended to speak briefly this evening. I refer to the awarding today to the Australian Capital Territory finalists of the Australian Small Business Awards for 1988, which took place at the Hermitage Restaurant at Woden Plaza. The Australian Small Business Awards have now been going for some years, and until now have been run by the Department of Industry. They are now run by the private sector. The major sponsors for the Australian awards are the ANZ Bank, Australian Airlines and TNT. Locally there are sponsors-Light'n Easy Radio 1053, Thomas Cook Travel, the Commonwealth Government Bookshop, Video Channel and the Canberra Times.

There were three sections to the awards that were made today, and the presentation was made by the Minister for the Arts and Territories, the Hon. Clyde Holding. The first section, to a small business, was to the Gallery Bookshop. In the second section, for non-manufacturing, there were two certificates of commendation to Stratagem Computer Contractors and The Battery Factory. The winner in that section was Canberra Wholesale Stationers Pty Ltd. There was a third section of manufacturing and again there was a certificate of commendation to Kendon Industries Pty Ltd. The winner in that section was Spectrum Joinery. These businesses are doing well in the ACT and are to be congratulated on their success. I wish them well when they come to the final of the Australian Small Business Awards and hope that they will be successful.

The awards now are substantially run by the Small Business Bureau of the Canberra Development Board, and the judging of those who entered was provided from the Fyshwick Chamber of Commerce and the Canberra Development Board. In addition today, Mr Donald Allan, the National Executive Director of Young Achievement Australia, presented an award to the school of the ACT which was the outstanding school in the Young Achievement Award. This is a program with which all senators will be familiar-a program which has grown and which seeks to show young people what business is about and how to run and manage a business. I understand that in Australia this year there were 260 projects comprising about 5,000 young people. The winner in the ACT was Radford College, which entered the competition under the Youth Australia Radford College 1988 section. The school won $2,000 in book vouchers, and each student in the group also received a $20 book voucher. I commend those who devoted themselves to the young achievement program and think it is very worth while, as also is the Small Business Award program. I congratulate the ACT finalists.

TALK.START.PARA: —I congratulate the new President of the United States of America, George Bush. It was a long-time predicted result, but in politics, as we all know, the show is never over until the fat lady sings. That is how George Bush ran his campaign.
